Posts.Content: Hi 232pookie Not sure if you have been taking note of the BRANDS of Letrozole you have been taking.  The different brands can give worse or minimal side effects!  It could just be an accumulation of this drug in the system.  For Anastrozole I only had hot flushes but watched which brand I got even to the point of making my GP ensure that only a certain brand was prescribed on my repeat prescriptions.  Having said that I note on some of the discussions that getting a particular brand which has less side effects for them is becoming difficult to source for pharmacists!  Don't know why that is.  Both these drugs work in the same way to suppress ER/PR pathways.  Letrozole didn't work for me, by the way.  Not on any of these endocrine tablets at the moment but may be again in the future. Hopefully more ladies will come back with what they have experienced.
Posts.Title: Letrozole to anastrole

Posts.Content: Hi Ali Owl I had mastitis and mastalgia in LEFT breast years before I got breast cancer. I was suffering pain particularly from the seat belt. They tried to aspirate but the silly s.d! didn’t get anywhere near the cyst which had become inflamed. Put on antibiotics and seemed to settle down but not go away. It wasn’t until pressure seemed to force a channel to the surface in my auriolar when it finally broke through. Discharge was a mix of yellow’ish lymph, blood and of course the infection. Was as right as a ‘boobin’ after that!  Hopefully this is all it will turn out to be so keeping fingers crossed.  .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: re occurance

Posts.Content: Hi Tina Rose When I went for a consult I think I asked at the BC reception how to go about this.  They referred me to the radiology reception.  I filled in a form and then went to the Cashier to pay the dues.  I could either come and pick them up or they would send them in the post to me.  I opted for the latter.  I received the cd of the scans but not the paperwork.  Rang and advised that I had paid for the documents as well and it seems that they had not read the form correctly.  However the guy I spoke to got it all sorted and I eventually received the hard copies. Best of luck
Posts.Title: I want to look at my scans and other tests

Posts.Content: Hi Pat H Are you on the endocrine therapy?  I am on Anastrozole and had a blood test which showed raised levels of Alkaline phosphatase and Serum triglyceride.  All of these raised levels are to do with the endocrine therapy which can affect other 'enzymes' in the body - so I am told.  My GP at the time didn't know this and it was only after further tests that this was found out.  They were putting these raised levels down to a problem with the liver or the bone - which in our heads could say we have metastatic cancer.  I didn't by the way. In reading your levels they don't actually correspond with my levels above on these enzymes so your level must be for another enzyme which I can't help you with. All the other enzyme levels from my original blood test don't match the normal levels you quote (asked for a copy of the blood test results from my GP and received it.   Would be very interested to know what this particular blood test was - if you can find out. I assume they are doing more tests so all the very best to you and hope that the outcome turns out as satisfactory as mine. .... still fighting this nasty little critter .....
Posts.Title: liver function tests.

Posts.Content: Hi Stoatie I think everyone has changed their diet to some degree.  Just getting rid of junk food is a change of diet.  I have cut out dairy, red meat, all processed food, no tinned foods, no ready meals and eat lovely vegetables particularly broccoli, cauliflower and Brussels, eat fruit and drink water and green tea.  I try to buy organic where I can.  Of course we all have failings but keep these to as little as possible.  Today I have been stuffing my face with a wonderful box of choccy biscuits someone bought for me and am I suffering.  I am bloated and burping! All the best, from someone ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: I am reading lots of info re diet and did not realise a change was...

Posts.Content: Hi Tina Rose All hospitals should be able to 'sell' you copy of the scans and records held under your name.  I got all my scans and records for the princely fee of £30.  I can then load them up and see them over and over again to see where they are coming from or at least be just as 'aware' as they are of my case.  This has helped me no end particularly as I am not your usual BC patient!  I haven't gone down the road of standard treatment.  You can see my post "To have the op or try alternative" to get the gist.  For the written records you will get photocopies and cds of the scans.  Make sure that you request everything from the time it all first started.  For me I have not got the 2 mamms from 2007 or 2010 when I was told all was okay.  It was only when I went again in 2012 that they came back with a 5-year growing tumour but what those mamms will show I cant say.  I may ask again as I took my case for a second opinion at another hospital.  Tumour was not palpable when diagnosed or even now so how I was supposed to be able to find it beats me.  Best of luck in getting your records
Posts.Title: I want to look at my scans and other tests

Posts.Content: Hi tallgirl1969 Welcome to the site which no-one really wants to be on.  You will however get so much support and virtual hugs from like-minded people. How true is your comment on the aches and pains.  It is only when something like this comes along that we generally 'feel' and think what's that 'gripe', what's that ache doing there, is it linked to the BC, etc,.  More than likely you have had these before, passed them off and they have disappeared as your immune system gets to work on them.  As a slow growing cancer that is very good but once you know you have BC you want to get something done.  It's the same with every lady - and gent - on this site.  Staying positive has kept me going for 5 and half years since diagnosis.  Don't have lobular but more than likely someone will be along to tell you their story. Love and virtual hugs
Posts.Title: Diagnosed but still waiting for tests

Posts.Content: Hi RubyRock Now WHOA on there girl!  As GnJ said microcalcifications are common and in 80% of cases are nothing to worry about.  With a tumour in place this goes down to 75%.  Mental attitude is sooooo important so STOP the panic attacks - this has a negative effect overall.  Take each bit of diagnosis as it comes, think on it, digest it and then make a decision in discussion with your consultant.  There's no harm in searching the web just use your common sense in sorting out the rubbish from the illuminating.  You can see what I have done, treatment-wise - by clicking on my name. Use your time as you would normally, good sleep, good diet, good exercise and if people are negative - get rid of them. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: mammo found clusters of microcalcifications. Very scared!

Posts.Content: Hi mrs d. I got a screening letter as well????  Seems that one hand doesn't know what the other is doing!!!! Well done for finishing your chemo. ... still fighting this nasty little critter ....
Posts.Title: DONE IT !!!

Posts.Content: Hi francesthegardner Just wondering why they say the tumour is larger than originally advised (unless its grown of course)!  My thought is that it could be microcalcifications around the tumour which they consider pre-cancerous and would want to cut out anyway.  Hopefully you got your answer/s on the Thursday before the op or afterwards.  Hope all is well now with you. Let's keep those nasty little critters running.....
Posts.Title: Further surgery for 'wider margins' and more lymph nodes to be re

Posts.Content: Hi fern2018 I tend to fast 16hrs a day.  Have meal in evening and then don't have breakfast until about 1-2pm.  BUT then I am retired and do not need to go out to work where you need more nourishment.  My chemo sessions are scheduled for mornings so all I take with me is a banana for afterwards, ginger biscuits as I get each of the phials of chemo in to take away the metallic taste you get, and of course the water.  I do heavily supplement, all natural stuff, not from Tesco's, etc., which I do believe has helped an awful lot with side effects and these are taken in the morning before a chemo session with OJ followed by a cup of green tea.  Started off good when hair still there at Day 17 1st cycle but when washing hair on Day 18 found that it had started to come out.  Warning sign for me was the 'hurt' I felt in hair follicles at the front of my head but didn't know it at the time.  Found loads of hair on my hands even though I have very gently washed it before, then and ever since.  Know of a lady who is using the cold cap but as successive chemo cycles go on, and she has had a few, this lady is worrying now as she is losing hair.  She is however continuing to go on with the cold cap - I tried and had to stop after 3 minutes.  Just could not take it and it's a bit too late now to try again as I have lost most of the hair on the back of my head and thinning everywhere else.  Just another joy of this chemo train we are on!  I don't like losing my hair but resigned to it and have a nice little cache of hats to put on until I finish the chemo and it starts to grow back.  I really do hope the cold cap works for you.  There have been some good reports on it. My love and hugs to you
Posts.Title: Is anyone trying FASTING (restricting Calories) before chemo to reduce...

Posts.Content: Hi jmp Never been prescribed Arimidex, just straight onto the Anastrozole.  I understand that Arimidex is the original drug - possibly more potent but with greater side effects - with Anastrozole a generic but works in the same way and is cheaper.  According to my research this little pill only costs 7p per tablet!!! All of my supplements in one tablet.... - I'd have to have a mouth as big as an elephant!!!  Used to take pro-biotics but stopped that.  As mistymoley says in her bit PRE-biotics (which I have only just learnt about from a TV programme 'Food Unwrapped' on Channel 4 broadcast on Mondays 8.30pm) looks a better way to help your gut flora. No dairy.  I do occasionally treat myself to some cheese.   Recommend dark chocolate all the way.  Less milk but only have 2 squares when you do.  No meat except for fish and chicken but again occasionally treat myself to lamb.  Supposedly this is the lesser peril of all the red meats.  Water has been filtered for years although now I use bottled (unfortunately plastic bottled) for drinking the green tea as my water supply even when using a filter receptacle tastes tainted when boiled. Microwaves heat/cook out all the good nutrients from food so always use the cooker.  When cooking veg I use my steamer and like them al dente - even the sprouts!  You can have potatoes.  I class them as a veg and give you the necessary carbs for good health.  Cook as normal (soft) - or have a baked potato and eat the skin - good nutrients here.  Basically, eat a rainbow diet (and there's a book called it) and bring into your diet a varied range of food and herbs.  The rainbow diet also tells you the benefits and nutrients you will get from each food.  A nutrition workshop I attended asked each person to write down what they eat in a day and I did this after got home.  The lady speaker said that most people would have cereal with milk for breakfast, sandwich for lunch, eg bread and cheese, which already meant that people had eaten two meals with only wheat and dairy therein.  She said that in her estimation people only ate 10 different things a day.  When I did my survey for that day in September 2014 I found that with all my supplements I had taken 53 different items!  Heaven knows how many individual beneficial nutrients that would have meant! Well that's all for now. ... someone still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Post BC Treatment Low Immune System.

Posts.Content: Hi jmp Just been reading some posts again and forgot to answer your green tea question.  I use Clipper as the tea bags are not bleached.  I did accidentally pick up a box of Twinnings and immediately tasted the small residue of bleach therein.  Had to go out immediately and buy the Clipper.  I now find that my taste buds are picking up these small anomalies - just one of the 'benefits' of getting rid of the junk food and having a clean palate! .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Post BC Treatment Low Immune System.

Posts.Content: Hi All Was going to open a discussion on this before I saw one had already been started.  Caught the programme on Catch Up on my Virgin.  Bloody interesting stuff to say the least!!!!  Professor Iona Heath was the lady who told us of the likelihood of the possibility of as much as 10 and possibly even 20 women having 'aggressive treatment' like surgery, chemo and radiotherapy when in all likelihood the cancer wouldn't amount to anything life threatening!!!!  and these women would eventually die of something else.  What a statistic if it is true.  It was also confirmed by another doctor that we need to find out which of the breast cancers are aggressive and need to be treated rather than a blanket approach for all women with breast cancer.  Dr Michael (presenter) did say that 'it was not possible to tell if a cancer is aggressive or not'.  Another stark revelation. Having said that my cancer was found through screening BUT crucially it was not palpable even though the size was eventually confirmed as 13x7x21mm.  I hadn't clue I had it at all.  AND I am like the 5 men in the bit afterwards on prostate cancer who have elected NOT to have aggressive treatment of surgery (which, it seems, can leave them incontinent and impotent) and use a watch and wait approach.  I believe that I have DEFINITELY taken the right approach.   Science is advancing our knowledge of cancer and I think it is important that people, not least of whom are women diagnosed with breast cancer, that they are fully informed of options and not pressurised by well meaning doctors and family to undertake aggressive treatment.  I do as always back any women's decision to follow any course of treatment they decide on.  That is THEIR  right - NO-ONE ELSES. Had I known of this episode's real value I would have video'd it so that I could have it to watch again. .... still fighting this nasty little critter.....

Posts.Title: Magnesium for hot flushes

Posts.Content: Hi jmp See that no-one has answered you so thought I would put my '2pennorth in'.  I list below all the supplements I am taking: Astragalus – immune booster Resveratrol (red wine extract) – fights yeast and fungal growth, anti-inflammatory, acts against COX-2, stops tumour cell growth, suppresses metasteses, attacks cancer cells in body by increasing levels of two proteins – perforin and granzyme B Mushroom complex – additional help for immune system Turmeric – inhibits multitude of cancer pathways, stops action of enzyme COX-2, inhibits vascular epithelial growth factors essential to blood supply to tumour, kills B-lymphoma cells, limits environmental damage, inhibits leukaemia cells, gets rid of metals in body Chlorella – communication help between cells and immune system, boosts white immune cell levels – interferon and T-cells, enhances levels of lactobacillus, beta carotene (10 x levels in carrots), organic iron (58x richer than spinach), vitamins D & K Spirulina – as Chlorella but each work better with each other Red Clover – contains isoflavone and phytoestrogens, blood purifier, contains genistein (blocks receptors to oestrodiol, also good for getting rid of microcalcifications and macrocalcifications (0 grade DCIS) Nettle – helping to get rid of microcalcifications, macrocalcifications Magnesium – for absorption of calcium tablet into the bone Aspirin – possible cancer prevention, halt metasteses, extend survival times Immiflex (stimulate immune system) – beta-glucans Immunokinoko (immunosenessence that works on older people and their immune system) – mushroom complex Krill Oil (omega 3 fatty acid – anti-inflammatory – has omega 3, 6, 9, Vits A and E, astaxanthin Pancreatin (enzyme support) ActivaMune (Diindolylmethane - oestrogen blocker) – Vit C, D3, E, very potent broccoli extract Pomegranate – combats yeast infection in gut Multivitamins Cranberry Garlic capsules Anastrozole Calcium with D3 Raspberry ketones - to help lose weight Drink green tea (EGCG) – shown to block an enzyme that multiplies cancer cells causing their death, promotes beneficial bacteria in gut, anti cancer aid   Most are taken am and pm although some are just once a day.   You can get some from Holland and Barrett and if you are close to Revital - a health shop chain - for some of the others.  Others like Immunokinoko and ActivaMune can be found on the web to purchase but shop around as there is a great difference in price.   As you can see  I am on Anastrozole and except for the hot flushes I don't suffer any side effects.  Haven't had a cold for 2 years at least but then I am old enough, I think, to have run the gamut of the 105 cold viruses going!   Good luck   .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Post BC Treatment Low Immune System.

Posts.Content: Hi FreyaO Thanks for the heads up Carolyn28.  Just a quick look around the internet and came across some studies as well as the websites promoting PEMF for injuries that athletes suffer in their different sports.  Seems this has been around for donkeys years.  Unsure of the person who quoted the potential harm if a person has had cancer of it causing more tumours.  PEMF also acts on the macrophages in cells to get them working on your behalf.  It's a lack of electrical activity in these macrophages, very important to the efficient running of a cell, that causes health problems.  PEMF electrical stimulus is akin to the pulse of our planet earth.  Some people go and 'earth' themselves, ie, walk around on the grass!  That's the level of the PEMF impulses that are given.  Can that be bad?   No, I don't think so. I had sono photodynamic therapy.  The sono in this treatment was the sono machine that is used to blast kidney stones to pieces but was used for my tumours in my right boob.  Oxygenated blood is circulated around the body every 1 minute.  My first RGCC blood test came back with a reading of 4.0 for circulating tumour cells.  The next one 5 months later came back with a reading of 2.5.  Therefore, some 'stimuli' can be advantageous for various things. Gotta admit that I haven't been walking on grass in my bare feet since I was a little kid.  Maybe this is why I got cancer - I am not in tune with our earth!  Sounds absolutely stupid and wacky, yes, I know, but it's got me thinking...... The medics, for once, seem to have got it right for your stress fracture.  As they are advocating it I would take them up on it without any quibble. You have gotta come back to us on how you do if you take this up. Love and hugs at this difficult decision making time.
Posts.Title: PEMF therapy and side effects for cancer patients

Posts.Content: Hi bevb47 Never had full blown flu so having to deal with it, as well as chemo, is a bit much isn't it.  I think I did have a 24hr flu, had temperature but it was gone the next day!  Glad you're feeling a bit better today and hope this keeps going.  Sometimes when going for a pee I don't make it and blow me if it isn't a little pee.  Big pee's I can hold!  but working on my pelvic floor to try to remedy. Keep on trucking .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: This new flu

Posts.Content: Hi  Cal57 Arimidex is the original with Anastrozole the generic equivalent (works in exactly the same way - so we are told).  Arimidex is more expensive since it is the original.  I take Anastrozole but have insisted with my GP that I take the Teva brand.  I was put on the Accord brand and found that I started to have aches and pains around my thumb and wrists within 5 days.  Now back on the Teva brand that side effect has gone.  The only other side effect I suffer are the hot flushes which I am dealing with.  Arimidex comes with its own side effects of which you know and possibly are dealing with.  It may be that your GP wants to try the generic equivalent which would be cheaper for the practice.  If however the side effects are decidedly worse for you on that brand you can try others like Teva, Accord etc.  Suggest you get only 1 month's supply at a time to see how it works out.  If in the end of trying all the other brands Arimidex is the best one for you then insist with the GP that your quality of life is affected seriously with the generics and you need to go back on Arimidex.  I read on another website that hypromellose, which is in the Actavis brand, can cause some of the side effects.  It seems that it is these 'fillers' that cause the side effects! Best of luck, from someone ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Actavis Anastrazole

Posts.Content: Hi LondonLass I am a bit worried that 8, yes, 8 MONTHS after your surgery you are still suffering with pain!  I thought pain was an indication of a problem!  There is of course pain and discomfort after surgery but for 8 months after! Or am I just too naïve to understand the ramifications of surgery!  Not having had surgery I cant say how long you COULD have pain afterwards but had I been in pain as you have described, for as long as you describe, then I would have been shouting the hospital's walls down and the GP's for proper management or at the very least an investigation.  Unfortunately your pain is in the way of any of that - mamm's will squash, MRI's will pull as your boob/s dangles and US will need contact at the least.  Sheesh, talk about being between a rock and a hard stone!  No pun intended. I fractured my little finger and it only took 5 WEEKS to heal.  Our bodies are designed to heal so I really don't understand why you haven't healed and are in so much pain. It could be inflammation and Snowys Mum has given you a couple of things to take.  I like jowoomot's take of going to a hospice who can look at your pain management in a more effective way but I still harbour thoughts that EVERYTHING should be checked out first in your boobs. Sending you the best cyber hugs ever and I hope you can get this resolved. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: HELP......

Posts.Content: Hi All Interested in this discussion due to the rash.  I am just about getting over the flu.  Put my clothes on yesterday as I mentally wanted to feel on the mend but I haven't been feeling well enough to cope with having a shower during this time.  By the evening I had severe itching on inside of my arms from my sweatshirt type jacket top.   When I took it off and looked, sure enough, there on the inside were the tell tale signs of either my concentrated liquid detergent or could it be my softener in those areas from not having been properly rinsed out in the washing machine.  Crucially I had already made the decision NOT to put softener on my whites which include my underwear and as I DON'T have any itching around those sensitive areas I can only assume that the softener is the culprit.  Obviously there was a build up of this chemical on my skin and my skin suffered as a result. Today I did have a shower and my arms are much, much, better.  I have a little redness and it is slightly 'knobbly' but not itching any more.  Hopefully by tomorrow it will completely resolve itself. Learning Factor - no more liquid softener for me!  Build up of these 'safe' liquids on your skin can cause skin rashes!  Was given an organic 'pack' to clean house - will look into this a bit deeper and start using this to clean my clothes.  Another unnecessary toxin in my life consigned to the bin.  I thought I was fine with these but obviously not. So, my suggestion to everyone is - look at some of the things that, ultimately, end up next to your skin! .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Lymphangitis

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969 Can't advise about the tenderness which I assume is from surgery/chemo/lymph node removal etc., etc., - not had them.  I am assuming that most ladies do get rid of the tenderness a while after surgery etc. but I don't know for certain.  I have heard of a loss of feeling in the area. All the very best for tomorrow.  Remember it's your body.  Make sure that what happens happens on your say so.
Posts.Title: First Surveillance Mammogram after diagnosis.

Posts.Content: Hi Rach1969 Right Rach, this is now the time to take charge.  You do NOT have to have a mamm that clamps your boob flat so that it hurts. Make sure you advise the radiographers that you are still tender and you have no intention of putting up with anything that hurts.  If it does hurt SAY SO.  If they don't respond SCREAM BLUE MURDER.  That way there will be no denying that they are actually hurting you and it lets everyone outside know just how insensitive they are being.  They also have a foot peddle which releases you so ensure that this is in play at the time.  They also have a small wheel, to the left of the 'plate' which they sometimes 'tweak' to make it a little tighter on the boob - you can turn this to have less pressure - I think it turns down to tighten and up to lessen but LET THEM KNOW. I am having a mamm after 3 years in July - I will definitely be getting them to play my game, not theirs. All the best for tomorrow

Posts.Content: Hi Lee26 Has my strategy to get to sleep worked for you? ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Insomnia help please

Posts.Content: Hi Lee26 Having just had an op I can imagine you are STRESSED.  Not having had one for my BC ... but that's another story. When I find I can't sleep it's because I'm not relaxed.  This manifests itself through a clamped jaw and even though my eyes are shut I find that I am looking up behind the lids.  I get 'my head' into a relaxing approach by sleeping on my side (which could be a problem post operatively) and concentrating on relaxing my jaw and making my mouth natural but lips together and making sure my eyes are looking downwards.  I sometimes do end up having to turn over but repeat the process and before I know it I am waking up with the alarm.  Concentrating on the relaxing will take your mind off what other things WILL be going through your head at the time.  It's this that is keeping you awake. 7 hours in 3 days is not good.  You know you need your sleep to help your body recover so the sooner you get a handle on this the better. Good luck to you and wishing you all the very best .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Insomnia help please

Posts.Content: Hi G n J Pharmacy having difficulty getting the Teva brand of Anastrozole.  They are trying to locate the Teva brand elsewhere and when I went back to collect said that they had already tried 3 suppliers.  They have however been able to get Zentiva.  Does anyone out there know if the side-effects of this brand are strong?  I still have the rest of the week for my existing Teva to finish.  At a push I still have two packets of the Accord brand in my cupboard but I know they will give me joint pain so not looking forward to that. You just get settled with a brand that really works for you and then get stumped because of supply!
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors - All Brands of The 4 Hormonal Therapy Table...

Posts.Content: Hi medusa525 You may need to seriously think about what you are eating.  No red meat - only chicken and fish - recommend salmon but any fish will do provided its not been farmed.  No dairy products.  No sugar.  Eat fresh fruit, strawberries, blueberries, blackberries, raspberries, apples - would suggest eating the pips as well but lay off these until the 'gastro' has cleared up somewhat.  Pears or any fruit.  I don't eat bananas because of the potassium which I am already getting from the Losartan Potassium for high diastolic blood pressure.  Vegetables are good when on the mend.  Absolutely limit alcohol.  I drink lots of green tea which is a massive change from being a confirmed coffee drinker and of course bottled water - I cant take the tap water any more - its the chlorine in it - wish it was ozonated like France supplies.  Absolutely no canned food or junk food.  Put good healthy stuff in your body.   Found that making these changes stopped my 'gastro' problems full stop and I've felt better than I ever did. When I did have gastro problems I took Asilone but now have in readiness 'cos I do sometimes go 'silly' Pepto Bismol - its pink.  Seems to work just as well as the Asilone.  No Rennies as they can rot the teeth over time. Haven't had chemo so I hope the Pepto doesn't conflict with the chemo. Best of luck .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Terrible tummy :(

Posts.Content: Thanks GnJ.  May get a month's supply of this just to try it out and will come back with a report.  You can be sure that if anything adverse happens in the first week I will let everyone know!!!! .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Aromatase Inhibitors - All Brands of The 4 Hormonal Therapy Table...

Posts.Content: Hi purplesarahd44 You and/or your Mum need to talk to your allocated BC nurse about this.  Your Mum does have the choice of opting out of the chemo or at the very least have some other medication to deal with the problems that chemo is creating.  Additionally this 'pulling sensation' needs to be looked at so make sure that another appointment is made to see your consultant and/or oncologist. Can you advise if Mum's cancer is hormone fuelled?  If so then she can start using the endocrine therapy instead.  This will be much less harsh on the body but does come with its own side effects.  Mine are just hot flushes which can be dealt with quite easily.  Aches and pains in limbs and joints are another but luckily I don't get these. I'm hoping that you go with your Mum to her appointments with the consultant or oncology - not necessarily to her chemo appointments though I am sure you do.  Arm yourself with a lot of questions and get answers.  Alternatively you can surf the net and I am sure there will be lots of help given from our community champions. Take care of yourself and Mum .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: my mum is struggling with chemo

Posts.Content: Hi treacle321 No, in my personal opinion, I wouldn't cancel your holiday.  You have had the surgery so are 'protected' in some measure.  Chemo CAN wait and CAN be re-scheduled.  A friend of mine had a holiday booked before surgery was intended.  She stopped the surgery to have the holiday and although an aggressive cancer came back from the holiday and then had the surgery.  She is still alive and kicking today. Don't be rushed into doing things by the medics.  I would have thought that a wonderful holiday with your kids BEFORE any further treatment would be a godsend.  You will be revitalised and hold in your heart the fun memories of that time - especially as your daughters have been looking forward to this holiday. Go on, have the holiday.  Be sure to tell the hospital of your decision so that they can re-schedule your chemo. Have a wonderful time.
Posts.Title: can you put treatment on hold for a couple of weeks?

Posts.Content: Hi Rosethorn Just been on the web and I must admit that the first item I looked at seemed to be a selling pitch!  At first I thought this was some organic earth for growing food!  So I thought, how about a list of foods that people can eat that contains silica which it seems diatomaceous earth food grade is. Banana (yellow, peeled), 250g - 13.60mg Beer, 1L - 19.2mg High bran cereal, 100g - 10.17mg Bread (wholegrain), 200g - 8.94mg Raisin (California seedless), 100g - 8.25mg Mineral water (high silica), 500mL - 7.23mg Green beans (cooked), 250g - 6.10mg Carrot (raw, peeled), 200g - 4.58mg Bread (wholemeal), 200g - 4.50mg Brown rice, 200g - 4.14mg Mineral water (regular), 500mL - 3.44mg Bread (white), 200g - 3.38mg Wheat biscuits, 100g - 2.78mg White rice, 200g - 2.48mg Cornflakes, 100g - 2.42mg I stay clear of bread or wheat as much as possible but after eating it for so many years I can't quite give it up.  Don't have cereal as such except as a muesli with fresh fruit added and coconut-almond milk.  No dairy milk.  Only use mineral water to make hot drinks or drink cold from the fridge.  Steer clear of the white rice if you can - that always 'bulks' me out!  Love cornflakes but so much sugar and salt is added so totally given up any other cereal. Other than that do some research on this so you can make your mind up.  Me - I would prefer to eat the other items above for the silica. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: diatomaceous earth

Posts.Content: Hi bonica53 Totally agree with you on Chris Woollams.  Went to his event in Bracknell on 15 May.  Took loads of notes but knew most of it from his books, website and further research.  Glad someone else is listening. HI Isingbass A lot of the supplements mentioned on here I actually take.  It was in a chemist window as well that they advertised that people were not taking enough Vit. D.  Alternative doctors also quote taking this in big doses.  They recommend at least 5,000 iu a day but I supplement with 8,000 iu on top of my Calcichew + Vit D3 (of 400iu) per tablet x twice a day.  Magnesium good as well - 1 tablet per day. You are doing your research so I don't think you can go far wrong. ..... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Vitamin supplements & diet advice ?

Posts.Content: Hi Bluebell22 Good news.  Just shows that where there's a will there's a way.  Information well and truly salted away in my brain for the future. Good luck on the op on 26th.   I'll be thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Hi Tingk Think you need to have a REAL, IN DEPTH discussion with your surgeon.  It is one of the main questions I have about surgery after complete pathological response to chemotherapy.  The fact that they don't know where the original tumour is is not a good enough excuse for a mastectomy.  All this means is that the nuclear medicine would not be able to find the original site without the marker as a guide or your tumour.  It could most certainly be mapped from the mamm and ultrasounds that have been done (I assume that they have been done) but the doctor/surgeon is just not willing to do this for your minor tissue conservation surgery.  I think that a 'step' in procedures was not carried out also so I would question the doctor/surgeon on this. Alternatively, you could use the wait and see approach.  You don't have to take any treatment further unless you are confident in the answers you are getting and trust in the team to go forward.  Only you can decide that after you have been given all the facts.  You do have to be strong and assertive and not just take any old crap that doctors give out.  As far as you are concerned to them, and in my case it is exactly as I relate, you are just a patient listening to the 'god given word' of the medic - I think not! If you have anyone by your side in all this get them to help you build a list of questions you need answers for and make sure they accompany you.  There is nothing more disconcerting to them to have a patient who always has someone with them who can jump in to ask other questions in response to things that crop up.  It is at these most trying times that someone by your side fighting in your corner is the best possible way forward.  Make sure that they are fully conversant with your diagnosis. Sending you virtual hugs and support in abundance.
Posts.Title: Looking for anyone in similar situation, marker not put in during...

Posts.Content: Hi dash123 So sorry to hear that your cancer has come back again.  It's such a tenacious little bu..ar isn't it.  Hopefully the new treatment they give you will knock it flat on it's arse! Sending hugs galore
Posts.Title: its back for the third time

Posts.Content: Hi Bluebell22 Very interested in your docs feedback on this.  I have had a blood clot on the lung NOT a PE and was not hospitalised.  They found it on a scan and immediately put me on innohep (low molecular weight heparin).  What your doc comes back with will have a direct bearing on whether the medics will be of the same mind in my case! I am on chemo but boob is developing lesions on or under the skin which show.  One is quite big and very red but my medics just seem to want to deal with a lesion in the liver by more and more scans.  I am more worried about what I can see!.  Have a Radiotherapy/Oncologist appt on Wednesday to get the low down on this for those lesions.  Will know more if radiotherapy would potentially be used for rest of the breast as well.  Would prefer another treatment but being given the run around on this.  A dedicated Breast MRI being done on 19 November will see if the chemo I am on - EC-Paclitaxol (3rd cycle of EC just undertaken with one more to go in 2 weeks time then 4 Paclitaxel every 2 weeks) has done any work in knocking the tumours into submission.  BUT everything depends on the results of the Breast MRI.  I have my next consult for that on 21 November. Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Fed Up!!

Posts.Content: Hi KerryJane38 Both chemo and radiotherapy hit you for six!  As you have pre-existing conditions, I imagine that you feel things more keenly.  You could do as I have done - just simply go onto the endocrine therapy - mine is Anastrozole.  I only suffer a small amount of hot flushes.  However Tamoxifen brings its own set of side effects - so I have read on this forum - and it's whether you will be able to cope with these as well.  It may be that you will have no side effects from Tamoxifen!  Each woman (or man) is different and we can only know, truly, when we actually do the treatment. It's a thought for you to take forward. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Advice / Feedback please on stopping chemo

Posts.Content: Hi Grey Bird It is a bit like a 'smack in the face' but its also a wake up call.  The support you will get on this site is amazing.  So many lovely ladies (and gents) here to give you the strength to carry on.  You don't say if your DCIS had a tumour factor in it!  Nor its size and whether it is ER and PR responsive, HER2+ responsive or triple negative!  If you give this info I am sure you will get some responses to what to expect next.  You can opt not to have chemo (if you are having it) or radiotherapy or the hormone.  BUT the choice is yours. I haven't had any surgery or radiotherapy and am on Anastrozole (hormone therapy) only.  Other ladies have opted for the surgery but no radiotherapy, but have opted for the hormone therapy.  It depends on how much control YOU want to have. Whatever your decision we will be here to support.  Love and best wishes from someone .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: I didn't see this coming!

Posts.Content: Hi jmp I have been on Anastrozole since October 2012.  At one point my chemist gave me the Accord brand and within days I started to suffer wrist and thumb ache.  Putting 2 and 2 together I put it down to this particular brand as well as discovering that other ladies also suffer more side effects from some brands from looking at other discussions on this site and checking the internet.  I went back to my GP and got another prescription for the TEVA brand and this works extremely well for me.  When renewing this prescription I always remember to ensure that I write the TEVA brand on the counterfoil (if not already there) so that the doctor and chemist are in no doubt as to the brand I want.  Before leaving the chemist always check that you have the right brand as you cant take them back to get swapped.  The only side effect I seem to get is the hot flushes.  These however have lessened and I only seem to get these after a meal !!!! It DOES seem that it IS the fillers in these generic AIs that cause the side effects.  Finding a brand which gives you less of the side effects is the key.  Try the TEVA brand first for a month and see how it goes.  If that fails then you can discuss the option of Arimidex (more expensive I understand).  A friend of mine was put on Letrozole and had really bad side effects and consequently stopped taking them.  She was however already suffering from arthritis so the AI only made it worse.  From discussions on here I understand that Tamoxifen is worse. I am finding that doctors/consultants don't understand the impact that these side effects have on our daily lives.  Be a b....y minded old cuss and work with your GP to find a brand AI that works best for YOU.  When you go back and see the consultant (time permitting) YOU can tell HIM that YOU have sorted this out !!! .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Femara ( Letrozole) V Arimidex ( Anastrozole) advice please !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Londongal My first MRI was back in 2012.  What I didn't know was that I would be tum-down on the 'bed'.  Having just had sandwich lunch I could only stand it for 10 minutes before I had to come out.  It wasn't claustrophobia but chronic indigestion!  I'm not a lay down on my tummy person anyway.  So when you know your time for the MRI make sure you work around it with your meals.  Give yourself at least enough time for the meal to get out of the stomach - or don't eat.  My last MRI took 45 minutes - I think that's just a little too long to stay flat on your tum. ....still fightin gthis nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Surgery pushed back a week, surgeon wants MRI beforehand

Posts.Content: Hi Veritas When I started the change my GP said I should take Evening Primrose Oil and I took this daily in tablet/capsule form.  However when I was diagnosed with BC I did a bit of research and something niggled in my head telling me to stop taking it.  Although I haven't had conclusive research to say yay or nay I have actually stopped taking it.  Can't say overall if there has been any benefit!  I'm on Anastrozole and calcium tablets with D3 which have a lovely lemon flavour to them - prefer the orange ones though.  Bone density is fine (I'm 60). .... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hi NN17 From my records they estimated that my cancer had taken 5 years to get to its size of 13x7x21mm - so slow growing. As to pathology report I asked for it and was given it when I underwent further scans in September 2012.
Posts.Title: When do you get pathology report

Posts.Content: Hi Genorm I am on Anastrozole from Teva and have had no problems.  However I do use filtered water!  This is from the water unit! you can buy from Tescos' etc and the charcoal! filters and from the tap if you live in the UK.  In talking with a gas man a friend of his went on holiday and found that because he was drinking bottled water, as he didn't trust the water supply abroad, his arthritis was eased/helped by doing this.  As soon as he got back home to the UK it would flare up again.  Putting two and two together his son bought him a water filter jug and is going great guns again. I also told this to a friend of mine with painful knees and joints. She was given a 'goodly' supply of bottled water and I told her to drink this rather than tap water.  Seems that after only one week her mobility is much improved.  I suggested we give it a month and see how she is at the end of that time. Can't harm you to try this.  Additionally, I keep my water in the fridge so that you have access to a nice cool glass of water!  So buy one that can fit in your fridge.  Any bottled water in plastic should be kept in a dry, dark place to prevent the sun affecting the plastic and leaching into the water.  Alternatively you can buy glass bottles of water but this could be costly. Best of luck

Posts.Title: Cancer One Stop Shops Information

Posts.Content: Hi met428 Just felt I had to send love, hugs and best wishes to you on your treatment by your hospital.  So say that not all has been straightforward is an understatement.  Certainly go to PALS and make a complaint both against the Breast Cancer Team as well as the disgraceful surgery by the emergency surgeon.  It is not on that anything goes and certainly he should be brought to task for such a poor 'finish'.  It may have been life-saving but it is not acceptable to leave it looking as it does. You can get referred to another doctor for breast care should you so choose.  All that's needed is a referral from the existing team and should not be a problem.  If it is then just make a complaint again.  Sometimes we just need to give them a nudge that they are not coming up to standard and have wholeheartedly not  kept their eye on the ball in your case. All the best
Posts.Title: Not happy with surgery.

Posts.Content: Hi Hattie94 Had a core punch biopsy on the tumour to prove it was a malignant tumour.  Local anaesthetic beforehand so didn't feel a thing.  Only knew I had a bruise there was when it went yellow.  Also have had a fine needle biopsy on a suspicious lymph node.  Local anaesthetic again.  Radiographer didn't want to do a core punch biopsy as the lymph node was between two 'veins' and she said I might not appreciate the bruising I would get.  Well I didn't appreciate the bruising afterwards on this AT ALL.  It was really black and blue covering about 3 inches!  But no pain.  I really don't understand how some people say that the core punch biopsy's hurt.  I never had any pain!!!!  Even afterwards. Years ago I did have cause to see a doctor because of mastitis with mastalgia.  He also was 'looking for the infection' with a fine needle aspiration.  No local.  After quite a number of 'tries' to see if he could find it, it did start to hurt.  I gave him one last try and then I called a halt.  You have watch these doctors like a hawk or they would quite happily carry on not realising that they are now beginning to hurt you.  Eventually the 'infection; 'wormed' its way to the surface near my nipple so I was able to express the 'gunk' and it healed up nicely.  Never bothered me again. In my experience they have always given a local anaesthetic.  Just make sure you get one also. Best of luck
Posts.Title: 22yo terrified of core biopsy - and, well, everything

Posts.Content: Hi alemapdroffilc I was diagnosed with Grade 2 INVASIVE Ductal Carcinoma of right breast August 2012 BUT I am unconventional.  I have chosen not to have surgery and radiotherapy as it would have been in my case (so no chemo) and am just on the endocrine therapy - Anastrozole.  Click on my name and you get most of my write-up. This has been a very individual decision which has been based on the scary thought of surgery and radiotherapy and trying to find a way forward without any invasion to my body by looking to the web for alternatives. Every person should be told by their doctors all about their case and the way forward they would like to take.  Only then can you make the choice of following their recommendations or embarking on a different route.  For me, NOT going down the conventional route was the only way. ...... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: All about face!

Posts.Content: Hi tropicof In some ways this diagnosis is MAKING us look at the treatments the team want you to take and whether you can actually cope with them.  In taking responsibility/control you are then in a position to help yourself.  It pays to use your voice. You say your diet is not good to say the least.  You are what you eat.  In fact if your digestive tract is out of order then your health is out of order.  Just taking control of this one thing can do wonders for the psyche - and your figure.  Dairy, in the end, is a bad thing.  You can get the requisite calcium as a supplement or as part of the endocrine therapy which also contains Vit. D3 - very important.  It is said that all Europeans don't have enough Vit. D for our bodies to work properly.  I also supplement and take 2 x 4,000 iU's a day.  If you have cancer then 10,000 is better. Most of your diet should be vegetables and fruit.  Lots of people talk about the sugar in fruit but this is natural and for thousands of years humans have eaten fruit.  No junk food.  No convenience foods.  You don't have to eat meat every day just the vegetables will do the trick.  One lady I know just cut bread from her diet and has lost 4 stone.  Says something about our bread today! I am on the endocrine therapy - and only that.  I never went for surgery or the radiation which was my treatment.  My write-up under my name will give you my short story as well as the extremely long discussion I started back in October 2012 -' To have the op or try alternative'.  Had the Anastrozole first with no problems but the docs felt it had stopped working when the tumour started to grow again so put onto Letrozole.  My mamm and ultrasound tomorrow (2nd August) with a consult on the 17th will give answers on the effectiveness of the Letrozole.  I have had no problems with either of the tablets and just wonder if it isn't the amount of supplements I take, change in diet, change in lifestyle, etc, etc, which has gone a long way to stopping potential side-effects and I think a healthier me although I have just had a small stroke which has affected the sight in my right eye.  Had a complete 'white-out' in the right eye but the body's healing system is working to correct the problem and some sight has come back and is slowly, but surely, starting to come back every day.  This was down to high blood pressure for which I am now on tablets and of course for the cholesterol - my diet had slipped somewhat.  Nothing like a kick in the arse to get back on track! So for the endocrine therapy, this is something that you could try and if, worse comes to worse, you find you cannot tolerate the side-effects then you can stop.  Some ladies here have put quality of life over quantity.  I can only report that I am okay with it.  Different brands seem to have worse side-effects.  The originals are Arimidex (Anastrozole) or Femara (Letrozole) if you do suffer bad side-effects from the generics - Anastrozole or Letrozole.  I think they would want to try the generics first though.  Unsure why they want to give you a jab every six months as I take Calcichew (Calcium with Vit. D3)! See if you can't find a Breast Cancer support group.  I found 2 in my area.  Just somewhere to talk with other ladies who have been there, done that and know where you are coming from. Sending you cyberhugs and every confidence that you find your voice to get you through.
Posts.Title: anastrozole and similar

Posts.Content: Hi Dreamthief Interesting bit from NICE. Very carefully worded by them!  Read an interesting article that its the lymph nodes that send out a signal if a piece of cancer hits them to trigger the immune system into working - one other job they do!  Really find this NICE 'bit' soooo interesting.  Many thanks. JammyFiona - as you have a 'query' with their thoughts/choice of 'extra' treatment, you really need to question them on this.  All too often we 'go with the flow' and, in hindsight, wonder what the heck was that!  It is always your choice in the end to either undertake a treatment or not.  If the evidence proves it is beneficial then go ahead but know what you are getting into first. Love and support to all ....still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Title: Chest infection or just a cough?

Posts.Content: Hi Aliandyb I note that your profile hasn't been filled in.  If you are on Everolimus it is contra-indicated although a lass who was on Exemestane from another site advised that a phlegmy cough was experienced by her on this hormone blocker.  I came up in horrible red angry itchy hives.  I had what I thought was a tooth infection.  Was prescribed clarithromycin and then came the hives in 2 DAYS.  After being advised to stop the clarithromycin the hives didn't lessen.  Eventually after 5 days was seen by an emergency oncologist who suggested a week off the Everolimus and put Eumovate cream on the hives.  This started working.  However I then started to have hand and feet problems with the skin hardening and splitting.  This was the final straw.  Told my oncologist I was stopping ALL medications for another 2 weeks to see if they resolved.  Low and behold this was what was needed.  I still have skin issues - due to the Everolimus which I started again at 5mg every 2 days.  Heaven only knows what state I would have been in had I been on 10mg of the Everolimus which I should have increased from the start dosage of 5mg after 2 weeks but I forgot because of the 'tooth problem'.  Clearly research by me has pulled all this information together.  I was told the side effects of Everolimus but not that any other new medications could be a contra-indication. Keep your eyes peeled for any side effect. Sincerely hope that you DON'T have my problem.  Love and hugs
Posts.Title: Chest infection or just a cough?

Posts.Content: Hi All Googled 'partner' and came up with the link below on the Cancer Research UK web.  Have found also that a lot of trials are already taking place in hospitals not listed on this site.  I thought that ALL trials were listed here.  Seems we don't have a central register for all trials taking place in the UK for anyone to look at - so inefficient!  Happy reading.  https://www.cancerresearchuk.org/about-cancer/find-a-clinical-trial/a-trial-looking-at-olaparib-with-chemotherapy-for-early-breast-cancer-partner#undefined Love and virtual hugs to everyone.
Posts.Title: Partner trial

Posts.Content: Hi All Just to let you know my niece Braved the Shave on Sunday, 28th, and has collected nearly £1000 for her trouble.  I was there watching as her partner shaved her head (at a BBQ) and at some points clumsily!.  I haven't had chemo so it didn't directly affect me but I can understand the difference between willingly having your head shaved (to raise money for Macmillan) and having to HAVE to shave your head because of your chemo and looking like you have got alopecia (hope that's the right spelling!).  I thought she was brilliant for doing this as the shave (No.2) also brought to the fore the areas of grey she had been colouring!  Still we are all getting older, don't know about the wiser, but I do love her for what she did.  I was amazed at how quickly I got used to her shaved head!  She said she was going to 'bleach' what hair she had left the next day to hide those nasty little grey bits.  Whether she has done this I don't know as I haven't seen her since Sunday.  I am not even sure that she can.  Hairdressers usually leave a space between skin and hair so that the bleach doesn't touch the skin.  As I don't ever bleach or dye my hair - the new toxin free me - I am happy to continue to see the bits of grey on my head although I think I am lucky in that they are slow to show! Keep on trucking ladies ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Does anyone else dislike the Macmillan Brave the Shave campaign?

Posts.Title: Microcalcifications - what should I be asking?

Posts.Content: Hi Vonnie1 Saw your discussion yesterday and have just finished reading the report.  I ‘think’ I signed the petition but just can’t remember – such is the power of being diagnosed with BC. When I first heard about the increase in the pension age I put my date into the computer on the Government's pension page and it came back as 66 years and 4 months.  It is now 65 years 9 months and 3 days - my birth date being 3 August 1954.  From what I can gather the WASPI petition is trying to amend the transitional dates so that women born in the 50's should not bear the brunt of the cost of this transition.  It could turn out that my official retirement date could change again! I also found a pdf file on the web showing your retirement dates based on the day you were born and it seems that the basic retirement age has increased to 67 years.  I do remember the 1995 'Act' reducing women's retirement age to 60 but since I was far away from it I never really bothered.  As a staunch equality person I couldn’t fathom out why this had been implemented. I just didn’t understand how a man still had to retire on a state pension at 65 while women were retiring at 60!! A friend of mine born on 1 April 1950 was able to retire at 60 but my birth of 1 August 1954 - just 4 years younger - means that I have to work 5 years 9 months and 3 days longer!!!!!  I also noted that some of the speakers in the debate talked about the health problems that women seem to have in later years as well as the many inequalities throughout their working lives that we have had to put up with which will leave us in poor financial predicaments in retirement.  At one point I wondered where this £155.65 pension per week was coming from until I again looked it up on the Government's website.  At this actual moment in time it is £115.95 so the new pension will give - on average - another £40 per week - but will this be enough to live on!  This will come in on 5 April 2016 and will be the same for every pensioner whether male or female (I was actually beginning to think I would be victimised because I was a woman by only receiving a lower pension despite the fact that I have paid into the system for 41 years) as I did ask last year for a forecast from the Government on expected pension for when I DO retire and they came back with £141.50 - I think - but again the goalposts seem to constantly change.  How on earth are we expected to follow all this to'ing and fro'ing!!! So thanks for this Vonnie1. I will definitely keep my eye on this and as I do actually know one of the speakers, Ruth Cadbury MP, from the debate I will be sure to ask her for updates on this. ….still fighting this nasty little critter…
Posts.Title: WASPi petition and parliamentary debate

Posts.Content: Hi Porffor My research into microcalcifications is that if you are confirmed as having a tumour 75% of the time nothing will come of the microcalcifications (they sometimes call these pre-cancerous cells).  You either have cancer or you don't - there's no in between.   However with no known tumour it says it is 80% of the time they wont change into cancer.  Microcalcifications are clusters of macrocalcifications which you find dotted around your boobs.  Just a bit more info to your elbow. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Microcalcifications - what should I be asking?

Posts.Content: Hi L C D This is a hard one to answer.  Are you really going to sell the house or are you trying to make it more homely for yourself?  If you are selling then you will need to be focussed on getting the house staged for selling.  Any 'homely' improvements can wait for your new home.  Then on that tack you can run away to your new home and never see them again - if you want.  We all know it is very hard to accept help.  As an individual you have had to cope with your health issues, generally, on your own.  Accept the assistance and opinions when it is given, freely, and with love.  They really are working hard, for you, to achieve the sale of the house, for you.  Suggest you ask for opinions on what next to tackle and see which is the best action.  Remember only you can sort out the 'stuff' you are still holding.  I know, I am a bit of a hoarder.  They've found a home and not moved since so do I really NEED, or in this instance you, them. Take care
