Posts.Title: Natural v Chemo

Posts.Content: Hi millie63 Are you taking any supplements?  Recommended is Vit. D3.  It is said that we are deficient of this nutrient as well as Magnesium.  I take 2 x 4000iu of Vit. D3 tablets a day along with what you can get from your food and 1 tablet of Magnesium a day - all supplements from health food store.  Also recommended for absorption is Vit. K.  However as I also take Chlorella and Spirulina I get my Vit. K from those supplements. I was originally on Anastrozole for 4+ years until, it seemed, from a check up with my oncologist and the ultrasound, that my cancer had grown 1mm all round, ie. from original size down to 5x7mm then up to 6x8mm and the ultrasound followed by biopsy said that a lymph node was now involved when previously it wasn't!  I had no problems with the Anastrozole except the hot flushes.   I am now on Letrozole and from stories on this site I had the inclination that the side effects would be worse.  No, not a bit of it - just the same as Anastrozole. You can surf the net for things to supplement that can help you with the side effects but this is a good start.  Getting rid of dairy, convenience foods (cans, pre-packaged stuff, etc), wheat, white rice, pasta, will also help you.  It is a lifestyle change, yes, but will do you no end of good.  Check your personal hygiene products for toxins and parabens and find better ones, ie deodorants contain aluminium - a toxin - as do shampoos, soaps, etc.  Check labels.  I use Bionsen or Missy. Best of luck .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: anastrozole- help with lead joints

Posts.Content: Hi All I have put in the problems I am experiencing.  These are: When choosing a discussion sometimes it goes into basic.  Refreshing it brings it back into your format but can take a number of times.  After refreshing the page sometimes it comes up with ‘page cannot be found’.  Refreshing this sometimes brings it back but also can be as much as 3 times. Sometimes the page refreshes all on the left hand side of the screen in either basic or your page layout.  Another refresh may take it into ‘basic’ or bring the page back good.  Sometimes I see people’s icons with a X Tried unsuccessfully twice to log the problem/s but website would not come back even after refreshing and I had to log in again. Would like to see a way of returning back to my favoured group on any other group I go to.  At the moment I have to click on group, then type in breast cancer, and then click on breast cancer when the choices come up. Went back to them when they asked for further info Browser is Internet Explorer 11.1 Device is a HP Laptop using Windows 8.1 Said they will get back to me.  No phone calls.  Awaiting. Don't use my iPhone or have an iPad when I log on so not able to use 'on the move'.  Still a little bit more 'training' needed on those.  But I am learning. Hopefully they will be able to sort from my angle.  Love and hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: Technical issues - how to report.

Posts.Content: Hi butterfly2212 Try taking magnesium.  Saw an ad in a chemist window which said this can help with aching joints.  It seems that this is a mineral that our bodies are now lacking in this modern age.  Buy some and see how you go.  I take chelated magnesium from Solgar. .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: painful knees and shin's

Posts.Content: Hi DebBee25 So sorry to hear you have BC.  I'm with you when people who haven't had or got BC have absolutely know idea what it really means.  To lose a part of yourself is enormous and when it's such a defining part of you as well - the mind staggers at their ignorance.  What we have to remind ourselves is that it is their ignorance that is speaking and... if you have to... b....y tell them so!  Screwing up your mental state is an absolute no no so just fire a tirade straight back at them.    My 2 sisters (and family) were all for me undergoing surgery and radiotherapy for Grade 2 Invasive DCIS with microcalcifications (and the Sentinel Node excision) but I just could not commit when I was told that they would cut out a 6cm piece of tissue.  This is a tennis ball size of tissue for a tumour which was only 18 x 7 x 21mm.  The surgery would have incorporated the microcalcifications which they call pre-cancerous cells.  From what I have learnt cells are cancerous or not and since not diagnosed as cancer I could not see the necessity to have them taken out as well.  The lumpectomy would have left me decidedly lopsided.  I am however on the endocrine therapy - Anastrozole (tumour has now reduced to 5 x 5 x 7mm - pea size - and the microcalcifications seem to be resolving/dissolving as well!). But back to my sisters - after a lot of negativity from them I told them straight that all I wanted was for them to be there for me, to be my buddy, and not be judgemental - I cannot have them upsetting my mental balance.  I wrote a 7-page 'letter' explaining myself (which I really shouldn't have had to do), my research, my conclusion giving ultimately the reasons for my decision.  From that point on they have been absolute treasures and how I love them dearly. I suppose you could say I too had a few rants but am now in a calm'ish state and trundling along just fine.  The conclusion to me is that having a rant is extremely cathartic so go ahead girl and have as many as you like! Take care and all the best for Wednesday, from someone .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: feeling sad angry lonely and lots more

Posts.Content: Hi All Watched this twice!  Jasmine Smith mentioned a new drug in England.  I didn't catch the name and have searched the web for something sounding like it but can't find it.  Does anyone know?  This was the young lady, 24 years old, with Stage 4 Breast cancer which is being managed due to the mets.
Posts.Title: BBC Scotland Beaston Cancer Centre - Episode One Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Ooooh, thanks for that G n' J.  I wrote something down like ...ni....grastin - like filgrastim but know this wasn't right. Has anyone else been watching the rest of the series?  Second episode was on prostrate cancer with the third on lung cancer.  In the last one docs talking of 'cure'!  Other research showing 'cure' for leukaemia!  What happened to the term NED (No Evidence of Disease)! It has been a really interesting series.  Thanks for the head up.
Posts.Title: BBC Scotland Beaston Cancer Centre - Episode One Breast Cancer

Posts.Content: Many thanks to everyone who has replied to my piece.  Some have been severely negative but then I expected that (as its hard to understand someone who wants to deviate from the conventional route) and some have helped to stop me to re-consider the conventional route.  However, my head still cannot come to terms with the side effects of the conventional treatment though.  Why would anyone choose to go this path! when the alternatives on this Macmillan site show another way.  What also keeps pushing its way into my head is this route was chosen as it is cost effective to the NHS.  Is this the cheaper of the routes!?! leaving your immune system to deal with the after effects? - if it can! Leaning, at the moment, to Photodynamics - looks 'chuddy-blood'.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello there everyone I'M STILL HERE.  New measurement was 5 x 5 x 7mm.  I'm happy with that.  It took 5 years to grow - cant expect it to just disappear.  Consultant was a bit negative in that he laboured on the last figure which had 'grown' by 1mm.  He neglected to say anyting positive about the other measurement which had gone down by 2mm!  As this is generally performed 'free-hand' I'm not worried until there is a consistent growth.  Having said that he did advise that they had found another area of microcalcifications of around 5cm! and were looking at a mastectomy now!  Said no.  Did my research and microcalcifications are only pre-cancerous in 20% of instances.  However you do need a stereotactic biopsy to get an answer and I wasn't prepared to be clamped onto a mammogramme machine for however long it took, take a picture, then local anaesthetic, then insert biopsy needle, picture to see if right location, take biopsy and probably take a few more pictures and more biopsies over the 5cm area to check the area.  Sheesh.  I already have a problem with mamms as one of the very first mamms I had I was clamped so hard it hurt.  I refused to let them repeat these any more for the longest time until a very nice lady said that she would do the mamm very lightly.  Since then altogether I have had two further mamms - a total in a year of 4 in a year of ionised radiation - a known carcinogen.  But hey its a risk anyway isnt it!  There just aren't any other diagnostic tools available!  Lymph nodes still clear under US.   Still watching what I eat.  No meat, dairy, rice, pasta, coffee, processed foods, canned foods, sugar, just fresh vegetables and fruit and heavy partaking of supplements, ie turmeric, resveratrol, basically everything to keep my immune system topped up. Have now got copies of all the scans and records just so I can see what is being recorded.  Have read them but need to analyse them.  Still thinking about and researching all the other therapies around.  Give the Anastrozole a little longer.  My next appointment with the consultant is 9 January 2014.  Keep your fingers crossed for me. Love to everyone having to deal with this nasty little critter......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi ladies Many thanks for all the comments.  I hadn't realised so many had been posted. On the case of the new microcalcifications I found a study which puts the possibility of 25% chance of them being pre-cancerous, as opposed to the 20% I have recorded in the blog if not linked to a tumour.  It also said that there is a 90%+ chance of microcalcifications being present when a person has DCIS.  I yet have to research more studies which may confirm or further increase the possibility of the microcalcifications being pre-cancerous.  I was diagnosed at a time when so many horror stories had been published in the papers.  I just could not submit myself to the slash or slice (surgery) and burn (radiotherapy) treatment offered.  There are other treatments out there but just not on the NHS.  Having said that there is a photodynamic trial (I have mentioned this treatment before) and it is with the Royal Free and the link below is encouraging to say the least!  I just would not agree to the mastectomy bit. (see the link below) http://www.dailymail.co.uk/health/article-2439464/Photodynamic-laser-treatment-kill-breast-cancer-15-minutes.html To Purple Fox and PatricaB I would just say that you have every right to your opinion.  However don’t be so entrenched - the article in the link above says it all.  My research has shown that people could get up to 6 cancers in their lifetimes but the body uses its immune system to kill these off so enhancing your immune system is crucial.  It’s your body (immune system), after all, that gets you well after the surgery, chemo and radio therapies.  Other up and coming treatments are Immunepheresis and HIFU, not forgetting Thermal Ablation and Cryo Ablation. Another thought being floated is that as you have a tumour in situ it sends out ‘messages’ around the body to inhibit or stop other tumour growth.  Yes, Yes, I know, there are a lot of ladies out there with metasteses but WERE they there before the surgery or have they developed after the surgery and treatments and before the endocrine therapy!  The endocrine (and chemo) treats the whole body so would search out ALL tumours.  My perspective is that everyone should be offered one of these to reduce the need for a mastectomy. In my case, I would have had a lumpectomy in October 2012 and when returning after surgery for checks they would have found the new microcalcifications (or were they there already) and I would have had to have more surgery possibly even a mastectomy as now quoted!  Two surgeries instead of one!  Having said that would the first operation have cut out the new microcalcifications!  I have been told that the excised tissue from lumpectomies are sent to the lab, during the op, to determine if there are clear margins so that they can cut out extra tissue if necessary.  Would I then wake up to be told that I would have to have another op, possibly, for a mastectomy as they could not get clear margins!  I would not have given my consent for a mastectomy beforehand, and in any case, they would not have gone any further with the surgery without my consent. My known microcalcifications on my right boob are at 7-9 o’clock, tumour at 9 and the new microcalcifications are at 10-11.  Quite a lumpectomy if all taken out.   Definitely left mis-shapen. My recounting of my case is mainly for my benefit and is not a guide to any other lady out there to follow my lead.  However if my stance has peaked your interest in asking lots of questions, not least of the multi-disciplinary team’s choices of treatment for you, then I have gone, also, some way to empowering you to seek the right treatment for you. I’ll be back when I have more to say.  In the meantime love to everyone having to deal with this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Girls Many thanks for all your comments - I know I'm controversial!!!!!! Hope you do read through the thread as you will see that the tumour was, at the start, 13 x 7 x 21mm.  At the last count it was 5 x 5 x 7mm with the endocrine therapy plus major lifestyle changes.  You will also see that with the microcalcifications  they wanted to take out 6cm of tissue.  That I could not do.  After that they found another area of microcalcifications so then a mastectomy was the next thinking BUT that set of microcalcifications only came to light a year later!!!!!  (It could be supposed that these were either missed or they have 'appeared' during the intervening time.)   Add to this the trial at the Royal Free on Photodynamics, which in its first phase has a catch 22 - they lop off the boob after 48 hours, there has been a good success rate! (and I say that carefully as they have only had 4 very courageous ladies at the last count who have undergone the trial on which to base this evidence).  My sister died at the age of 34 years of cervical cancer some 32 years ago.  You can be very sure I am fully aware of the consequences of no action as she also did not want surgery. Logic says to cut it out but the idea of the word "do'able" constantly bandied about when undertaking surgery and radiotherapy, in my case, afterwards IS JUST NOT ON!!!.  I am appalled that we still see surgery as the only route forward - THAT'S MY OPINION.  Trials on Photodynamics and HIFU are taking place in the UK, Immunepheresis in America, and Thermal Ablation and Cryo Ablation in Europe.  Yes, all are in the trial stage but basically non-invasive and could be used as many times as is necessary WITHOUT the pain, suffering, stress or mutilation. Now I'm no beauty queen - well not at this age anyway, 59,  (nor at any age really!!!!! chuckle chuckle) - but I would like to feel as whole as I can for as long as I can.  I will have to live with the decision as you all have done or are going to do.  I want to see what I can do first with the help of the endocrine therapy.  If anyone is interested a film "Living Proof" tells the story of Dr Dennis Slamon and the 12 years it took to get the endocrine therapy through the trials.  In that time, just in America, 480,000 women died waiting for this to help them live longer or even survive...... Still fighting this nasty little critter.......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Still awaiting the reports on the mamm I had done on 8 May and all the other documents from 4 October but I have received my pictures of the US and mamm.  I have to say that they show a marked improvement in the clearing of the calcifications.  It has however shown up the microcalcifications more.  As they were hidden by the calcifications I cannot say if they too have reduced.  Overall though I think I am doing really well!! Showed the printed pictures to my sister who also saw the improvement.  People I have spoken to also believe that a positive state of mind is really helpful in fighting cancer.  One friend advised of another friend of hers who had gone down the surgery chemo and rad route and was really suffering.  My heart goes really out to her.  Was so pleased to be told on the 8th May that the 12mm referred to the admix of calcifications with microcalcifications and not the tumour growing.  Next appointment is in November 2014 so, for the moment, just awaiting the copies of the written reports and will report when I get them. Still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Katherine Many thanks for that piece of information.  You've added to my knowledge.  Often talk with the nurse at the GP's when I go for blood pressure checks and tell her everything so I hope it gets filtered through to the GPs when they have meetings - if they do!  I have to admit that I do feel tons better about myself when I am able to talk to caring responsive people.  Yesterday I went to a social coffee morning at the Mulberry Centre in Hounslow.  Just talking with ladies there was absolutely brilliant and I intend to continue to attend these even though it is a mixed bag of cancers there are still ladies there who have had breast cancer. ...... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Had my consultation on Thursday, 13 November.  Consultant on holiday so had one of the registrars who just happened to be heavily pregnant.  She asked if I was willing to change my mind about surgery and told her a definite NO.  Told them about the raised Alkaline phosphatase level and they advised that my GP had not sent them anything.  In the interim my GP practice had rung me to make another appointment early December for a blood test again!  Happy with this. However on top of that the registrar wanted me to have more tests as a result of the above and after giving them a copy of my thermogram.  I am now to have a mamm on the left breast just to check out the red line there on 21 November (I do have a very visibly seen vein there UNDER the skin), a CT scan with contrast (iodine based) to check out the liver on 24 November and another CT scan with an injection of radionuclide to check out my bones on 21 November (awaiting the appointment letter as a few checks have to be done first).  Advised them that I had an osteophyte on my L5S1 (lumbar).  Be very interesting to see what they turn up!  Will order copies of all the results before I leave on 24 November.  I then have another consultation booked for 18 December with the consultant/oncologist.  Phewwwww.  Will update you after the 18 December. ... still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Hairworries Nice to hear from you and I am very pleased to see someone else who, in some ways, is taking a semi-different route to the BC treatment.  As your BC was aggressive it may very well be that choosing to have surgery was the right thing.  Chemo, they say, only gives you a small percentage increase in survival times - so I've read - as does radiation therapy but oh does it leaving you like crap - or so I've read! I had my mamm on Friday and got a look at the pictures.  Can't say that it looked any different from the last one I had in August 2012 - so no BC!.  However once I order the pictures later on I will put the two together to check on any differences.  Today, I am having the CT scan of my abdomen (liver) at 2.30pm with the infusion of iodine - takes about 10 minutes. Will try to see if I could get a sneak peek of these too.  2 December, 11am, is when I am having the Bone scan.   Reading the literature it says the radionuclide will be injected at that time.  I can go away for 3-4 hours drinking at least 2 litres of water to flush to the stuff out BUT it also says that anyone with me I cant sit with them BUT I can go out into the public domain!!!!!!  This will take up to 45 minutes. Then on 18 December I have a consultation and will get the results from the team. On 99% of visits to the hospital either one or two of my sisters accompanies me so I have lots of support.  Whilst they don't truly agree with my plan they have accepted it and just 'buddy' me. I am so thankful to them and got a bit sentimental when Bette Midler sang 'Wind beneath my wings'.  The words were just so appropriate to them. So now I must go to bed.  Thank you for your message.  I hope you tinker along 'chuddy blood' . ..... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello there Ladies (and gents) Had my consultation on Thursday  18th after all the tests I had had done.  NO METASTESES.  YAHOOOOOOOO.  However he did say that there is a polyp on/in my gallbladder.  He is writing to my GP to get me to have an ultrasound so that it can be checked out.  If it's over 6mm (from the internet) there is a strong possibility of an op by laparoscopy - would not agree to an op that would slit me open.  BUT it's a decision I will have to make once I know the results of the US.  Consultant also gave me a quick US on right boob and things still seem to be static there. GP came back with blood tests.  In this test she went for the "Anti-nuclear factor level" which says "potentially abnormal" so she is going to check with a rheumatologist on Monday!  I have absolutely no aches or pains - not even from the Anastrozole - but then I do take a lot of supplements which I think is supporting my immune system.  In talking with a friend she was diagnosed with rheumatoid arthritis years ago but had no symptoms then - but does have problems now!   She says she wished she had done more exercises so maybe I should up mine!!!!!  Wrote a note to the GP asking if the raised levels on the blood tests could be something to do with the polyp. I wasn't expecting to be told by the consultant that there were no metasteses but I am absolutely delighted to have been told this.  A big grin came across my face and I nudged my sister who had accompanied me.  Next appointment is in 6 months.  I will send my consultant any information garnered on the polyp on/in the gallbladder.  It's a wonderful Christmas present to be told that 2 years and 4 months down the line that your actions have not hurt you despite protestations from all around you, albeit in the early days. I hope everyone has a wonderful Christmas and New Year.  I know I am. My love and hugs to you all from someone still fighting this nasty little critter
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All DEM - you had your appointment on 3 March.  How did it go? On my front I had a call from some department at Kingston Hospital.  They had a slot for 9.25am on 10 March and would I be interested in taking it.  Said Yes and would they be following up with an appointment letter.  They told me this had been arranged by my GP.  Haven't received an appointment letter but have had two letters from the Immunology Clinic, Outpatients, requiring me to make an appointment.  Maybe the appointment letter will come tomorrow (Monday) and I will find out what appointment, where, I have agreed to!  Could also check with GP practice to see what has been put on my notes.  Post comes mid morning so I could check with GP in the interim and telephone the Immunology Clinic to see if the 9.25am slot is with them.  Got to admit I didn't think the 9.25am slot was with the Immunology Clinic - I thought it was with some other clinic but was so busy writing the date and time down, at the time, I did not ask the clinic/department again. Gotta admit that I am pleasantly surprised and pleased with the care I am being given by the NHS even though I haven't gone down the conventional route for breast cancer.  It is only with being diagnosed with breast cancer that the other things (wrong with me) have come to light.  One discussion said that good can come out of a cancer diagnosis - how true that is!  Report from the 2nd Thermogram - "I am pleased to note that your report indicated that there are no significant thermal changes", "....both breasts are considered to be stable with no current thermal findings to suggest significant contagious spread of disease in the right breast".  YAHOO.  Next thermogram on 14 July. Love and hugs to everyone, from someone ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All DEM - your full post was on 27 February.  Was there another one which has gone missing?  Your posting dates: 27 Feb, 9 Mar and 11 Mar are on this thread.  Can you remember when you posted and what? I cant see any response between 27 Feb and 9 Mar.  I do note that you have accepted the chemo treatment and I'm with you on being scared of that!  I send you all my positive thoughts on its outcome. On my front, I went for the appointment with Immunology.  Yes it was with this department.  The immunologist hadn't a clue why I was there!  I had brought with me the results of the three blood tests I had had done via the GP looking at the ALP test which was 194 when the ceiling is 130!  After lots of questions he suggested Paget's Disease.  Looking this up on the web it starts (linking it to my breast cancer) as scaly skin on the nipple.  Nope, I don't have scaly skin on or around the nipple or areola!  Don't have eczema, dermatitis or psoriasis which can make it difficult to diagnose.  The web thinks this is a pre-cursor to breast cancer.  I know I've got that.  He didn't do a physical.  It could also link with the bone but that has been 'cleared' from the bone scans. As a result I popped into my GP's to find out if there were any notes on why I was sent.  They got back to me by asking me to go in for a review as they didn't have a clue either!!!!  So I go tomorrow - Monday - to see the GP.   Maybe then we can figure it out.  My original GP has left and I will see the head of the practice this time.  Another 'head' to figure this out. For myself, I am actually quite well.  I don't have any other health issues which could affect me - physically and mentally!  Even though I have been diagnosed with BC the only problem I have is the hot flushes from the Anastrozole and they are lessening - so should I be worried about that!!  My head says that the endocrine therapy is working if I suffer from the side effects - how stupid is that as its the 'fillers' which cause the side effects!!  I am also 'aware' from my oncologist/surgeon that he did say that the endocrine therapy can/does stop working but also that it can get rid of the cancer.  He knows of two such cases.  As from my previous discussion we also know that the cancer is 'stable'.  Thoughts, Questions, Thoughts, Questions.  Yeeecccch - you could go nuts over this! Anyway will get back to you all after I have had my conflab with the GP. So, from someone  ... still fighting this nasty little critter... Love and positive thoughts are with you all.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Thought I'd better update you from my front. Due another thermogram scheduled for 8 December but I want to bring this forward a week.  Haven't yet talked with thermogram people about 'same results' from last time yet although I believe the tumour to be smaller. Also have a 6 month consult coming up for the 10 December with surgeon/oncologist.  I want to have an ultrasound just to check the tumour's not doing 'naughty things'. Added to my supplement list Boswellia Resin extract which is the active item in frankincense as well as using frankincense essential oil to rub onto skin from the outside - two-pronged approach.  No adverse reactions on either so carrying on.  This is ancient pharmacy and was worth a lot of money back then, which is why it was, along with myrrh, one of the gifts from the magi - people used it, and the myrrh, in healing. Still ticking along nicely.  No aches or pains or things to worry me.  Working far, far too hard but then I do have to earn the money. Will get back to you when I have been to thermogram and surgeon/oncologist. ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Blimey, what a load of posts.  Thanks for all your comments.  I read them with great interest. The doctors DON'T comment on the link between the various supplements, outside scans, other bits I do, etc, as they can't.  They are not allowed to under NICE instructions and could be brought before the BMA and possibly struck off.  An additional factor is the Cancer Act which stops doctors from going down alternative paths.  In conventional treatments they ARE the experts.  When I chose to go for a second opinion I deliberately chose Professor Keshtgar as I believed the new trial of Photodynamic therapy he was undertaking was a truly brilliant new treatment for BC.  This treatment is way out of the box on the conventional but the catch 22 was that I would have had to have a mastectomy done 2 days later.  I didn't meet the criteria anyway but because of this innovative thinking I chose to stay with this consultant and he is happy to continue to monitor me.  'Almost' every time I am at a consultation (6 monthly) they try to get me to agree to surgery but with the continued shrinking of the tumour I view that what I am doing is the right route for me.  If things change I will think again. The change of diet and lifestyle has had numerous benefits on my wellbeing so that I no longer suffer with dyspepsia, bloating, headaches or any of the niggling things that occasionally take their toll on the body.  Any change in lifestyle to the betterment of health is a good thing.  I still have hot flushes and as the consultant said in one appointment the Anastrozole continues to work so why not continue on this part of the conventional treatment.  When I viewed the video film of Dr Dennis Slamon (discoverer of the endocrine therapy) women were given a second chance of life after the cancers had returned after conventional treatment. For decades we have had surgery and radiation. Innovations have been added along the way - chemo and the endocrine therapy – but, sadly, they have still not cured cancer. Clearly new therapies are/will be added to, systemically, cure cancer otherwise why would scientists still be continuing to research new therapies for BC. On the books are Gene Therapy, GcMAF, Photodynamics, SonoPhotodynamics, HIFU - amongst a few. Will one of these be the end of our cancer/s?  As George says who's to say that something I am taking may be advantageous in the resolution of breast cancer? My sisters have accepted my unconventional route but do sometimes come back with ‘negative’ answers when I ‘spout off’ on something I have learnt. I have learnt to accept their retorts just as I have accepted their stance on favouring the use of the conventional treatment. I understand the ramifications of my actions but so far I am doing fine. This discussion is for my benefit as are all the other discussions on this website for the benefit of the writers. I read the other discussions with great interest and pitch in where, I hope, I can help and support. Thanks once again for all your comments and I will update my discussion when I have something to report. Lots of love and look after yourselves …. still fighting this nasty little critter…
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: HI All Yes, it's me again.  Finger has healed nicely.  Kept the splint on for 5 weeks instead of the 6.  Have the longest nail ever on the little finger from 6 weeks of growing.  At the moment still a little apprehensive about filing it down but will leave it for the moment until it starts to get in the way then I'll tackle it. Just getting over a bad cough which has put the wind up me!  Saw GP who has given me some antibiotics in case of early infection in the lungs, checked lungs which he said are clear!  (Thoughts of metastatic cancer and all that!!!)  GP thought is it was viral flu and for a couple of nights I really needed my hot water bottle as was feeling deep cold.  Was really hot in bed with the hottie but just didn't want to throw it aside.  Think that was a good move on my part as I am 'coming around the mountain' now.  I also didn't want to eat for 2 days so a flu virus seems to be right. Next appointment for me is 21 July for consultation on my BC.  If nothing more! happens to me in the meantime I'll report back after that appointment. ... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi SandySue Very happy to hear from someone who has survived 17 YEARS with only surgery - and of course the Gerson therapy.  We are, I think, a growing number of patients who are beginning to take control of our treatments - and so we should!  There are so many new non-invasive treatments coming up (although research has shown they are being used elsewhere in the world) that if we can keep our cancers under control, now, we can keep going until they become the new treatment.  Amen to that! Keep on trucking, girl .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Steve Believe me when I tell you have been on the internet researching loads of stuff.  I could write a book! As a rider, why is that so much is in the news about new and very promising upcoming non-invasive treatments?  And early indications show they work! Statistics, well we know what can be done with them!!!!! Just saying...... .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Steve Sorry, but I think you are being patronising.  Have extensively looked on Cancer Research UK.  Often am on this site looking for trials and also for any pearls of wisdom for other writers to be directed to. I will say I just saw a video on chemo being directly injected into a tumour rather than a drip and it was targeted chemo for the specific cancer which should finish it off once and for all!  Can't remember if it was being trialled but it was in Germany where so many of these new treatments are being given.  NICE is just not getting on board quick enough. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi kacang Thanks for your reply.  Read the article you 'linked in'.  Raises some very interesting thinking I need to do.  Really did not like putting a load of synthetics into my body which is why I stopped taking them in the first place.  Felt that taking Letrozole (or the Anastrozole when I did) was more than enough synthetic in my body.  Will, however, continue to take the BP and cholesterol tablets until I get resolution of my sight.  Positive thinking no less! Love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Well, had the consult.  Old guy who I have never seen before.  Original Consultant/Oncologist sick again - poor man.  He does overdo it though. Doctor mentioned a new 'tumour' and wanted to do a stereotactic mamm.  I said I had just had a mamm after 3 years of saying no so not prepared for have that.  By the way left boob okay.  In the end it was ascertained that the 'other tumour' was the lymph node.  They also said that the original tumour had increased to 11x9mm - bu--ar!  However I am not sure we are all talking about the same one!!  Got no size for the 'lymph' one!  I will however be having another US on Friday 25th with the Consultant Radiographer and I can tell you I will be asking some very searching questions.  Therefore Letrozole not working for me at all and Arimidex mentioned which I am happy to take.  Also discussed the trial Photodynamic therapy but as the Consultant/Oncologist on sick leave this has been stopped temporarily.  I am however hopeful that this will be resurrected.  According to my BCN nurse they were on the 2nd Phase of the trial.  Will ask more questions when I have a later consult on 7 September.  Hopefully I can talk with someone who knows about it and the criteria for taking part. So not good but not so bad. Eyesight - very slowly coming back.  30 August sees me go for a EchoCardiogram and 24hr Electrocardiogram.  Fun eh!  It just seems to keep on coming.  BORAX!!!!!!!!!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Kay Thanks for the comments.  As you are aware we all hope for another treatment that looks good and can do the 'business' without the side effects but we also know that there can come a time when we have to go down the conventional route.  Everything about my case screams a good outcome on this route and to my benefit there is a little bit of time for me to think things through and do the research.  Not too long though and I have given myself, and in agreement with my consultant, one month before I decide (only 2 weeks in).  Additionally I have today talked with the Breast Cancer Nurse at my hospital and she is going away to do some research so that she also is up to date on the new treatment/s I have mentioned to her. The book dealite recommended, 'Dr Susan Love's Breast Book', is truly enhancing my knowledge and I have individually thanked her on this discussion. I never meant to offend and probably put into words what each and everyone one of us has thought at one time or another.  I'm just not conventional and have to find out as much as I can before making a decision because in the end it is my decision and I have to live with it.  I have a large family and circle of friends who now understand this and are willing to accept my final decision. I send you all the love I have and wish you a speedy recovery.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone Many thanks for all the posts ladies.  I'm still here.  Still not had the op and radiotherapy.  Still taking alternative herbal medicine - can't hurt (but how to quantify).  Saw Onc and now on Anastrozole.  Tiny little tablet!  Read some other blogs that I might have very painful joints with this but see how we do.  Asked for second opinion and waiting for this.  Live in London and I was amazed at what different hospitals offer.  Found one that has some innovative treatments being used as well as studies into new.  Don't think we are quite at the point where these less invasive treatments can be offered (except in studies) but I do think that some of these will be treatments for early stage breast cancers in the not too distant future.  I just got breast cancer too early!  Mostly its down to funding for the studies.  The programme a couple of weeks ago to raise money for these studies was brilliant.  Cant remember how much they raised but all credit to getting this done.  Additionally stories in the news lately which mentions that, maybe, we don't all have to have surgery, radiation therapy and chemo! for our lumps - that I didn't know! BUT what we don't know is whether our cancers would just stay put and not do any harm!  And there lies the rub!  Wasn't too happy about the doctor who pressurised the lady to have the conventional treatment by browbeating her - think I would have kicked him in a sensitive area had he done that with me.  New guidelines coming out now put the onus on the consultants to ensure we are told fully of all treatments and to ensure that each lady knows their options. I felt that with my onc I was just another patient.  It was only when I stopped the op, went away and did some research that we now have a better understanding of each other.  There was just too much hurry! Anyway, when I've had my second opinion will come back to you with an update.  Lots of love and hugs XOXOXO
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies Just a small update.  You could say I have had a slight 'scare'.  I actually pulled my 'gluteus maximus' in my right cheek (done it before) but because it was taking so long to heal my GP sent me for a bone scan x-ray.   Everything alright there but they did find an osteophyte (calcium deposit) at L5 S1 (one of the lumbar vertebrae) with a slightly depressed disc.  Sending me for an MRI and this is just to be sure......  Personally I feel perfectly fine now the muscle has stopped aching but I know that the MRI will confirm for certain. Fighting this nasty little critter all the time.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Many thanks for your comments.  ALL are duly noted.  A friend had/has breast cancer of the aggressive form and has had the surgery and seems to be fine.  Another friend also advised of a friend of hers who didn't have surgery,  died as a result and in so much pain.  Everything anyone says to me is taken on board as is the guy I found who is LIVING with his cancer 19 years on and the two women, as well as others, I have found who used their immune systems to beat their cancers without surgery.  One was a young lass with numerous cancers throughout her body and another did have breast cancer which resolved itself through her actions (what  - don't know). I have to own up that I still haven't rung my BCN nurse! I find that when I do remember it's a Thursday and I know how busy that day is!  It's consultation day and it's crowded beyond belief.  So many ladies, probably, with BC!  I'll try and ring Monday.  I know I MUST do it. I do read most of the threads - mainly it's the ones that have headliners which catch my interest.  I would like to respond in a lot of cases but as I haven't gone down the majority line I would feel a bit ignorant/hypocritical putting forward my bit so I carry on writing on my thread.  What is strengthening my resolve, in my case, are the numerous additional problems that seem to come with having the surgery.  I really do feel for all the ladies that have suffered as a result.  I am still of a mind to have Sono-Photodynamic therapy and if at the next US it shows that it has grown then I will opt for this. I hope you all read the link to the article on the trial for Photodynamic therapy at the Royal Free.  As I have said previously this, potentially, new form of treatment is looking like its the way forward and can be done as many times as is necessary to get rid of BC. Still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies Well.......... I had my appointment with the consultant on 8 May and, low and behold, the 12mm they quoted were microcalcifications - NOT THE TUMOUR.  The consultant did ask if I was ready to agree to any 'intervention' but based on the information I was just given I said no.  I also asked about the trial and now, a total of 9 wonderful, wonderful ladies had taken up the challenge.  I had hoped that more patients would have signed up to this by now but maybe it is designed for specific breast cancers.  They need 30 ladies to agree for the first phase.  I did say that if Phase 2 was to do the photodynamics without lopping off the boob then I would be first on the list!  When I had the US on 1 May radiographer said lymph nodes were still CLEAR, she did a full US on all the boob and after that did a full tour for me showing all the ducts with calcifications but not giving me any measurements.  Those pictures I will purchase at a later date. I also had a mammogram which started off badly when the lady radiographer was becoming a bit 'demanding' when I was just starting to take off my top clothes.  I was contradicting what was clearly a mind-set.  I was very nearly on the verge of walking out but she went to take advice from someone and came back with my wonderful Aussie lady who completely diffused the situation.  Good mamms were done but without the pain.  Having said that one of them did hurt a bit more than I would have liked but we got a good picture.  I get the written report on these in 2 weeks time - can't wait to see what it says.  Additionally will go and order the pictures so I can see what they see for myself.  Now I really do have to say something about the negativity of some of the posts on my thread.  At no time have I made any devastating comments on anyone else's threads.  If you cannot support another lady with their decision and only have negative thoughts on their actions then do not comment!  Keep them to yourself.  You know yourself how a passing off the cuff comment devastates YOU.  So why do YOU think YOU can do it to someone else! My initial response was to stop writing but writing in my thread is acting as a catharsis by sharing my plan of action with the wider world and hopefully empowering women to stop, think and ask about their disease and knowledgably choose their treatment.  These last comments may be the end of this thread and that I will accept with grace.  If I have offended anyone I apologise up front. But please be assured that I will be with you in mind and spirit and will ......still be fighting this nasty little critter.......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi M65 By chance my new batch is Accord also. Can't remember what brand it was before as I had recycled the packaging  before I made the connection.  Certainly the packaging now is different than from before which is why I made the connection.  Have tried to look online for the different brand packaging but wasn't getting anywhere.  Wrist and thumb pain 'seem' to be diminishing so - now - I am not sure if I haven't had a knee-jerk reaction and will say so to GP when I see her. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Alirose Many thanks for your kind encouragement.  My way is controversial and COULD get worse but I do have a plan for that which is the Sono Photodynamic therapy at a private clinic.  How long or what it entails is still a mystery somewhat but if The Royal Free then goes to Phase 2 in their Photodynamic trial and I qualify (without surgery and radiotherapy) then I will opt for that. I am so sorry to hear of the problems you have experienced going down the conventional line.  In reading a lot of the stories on this website plus the few ladies I know have had breast cancer and stories from friends on the horrors experienced by some of their friends I knew I just could not submit to any 'interference' except for the endocrine therapy which is systemic so will 'block' any of the 'nasty little critters' should they try to settle elsewhere. All the very best to you and keep on trucking as they say ..... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Saw my oncologist today and, YEP, the Everolimus not the Exemestane is the cause of my hives/skin rash.  They were under the impression that I was on 10mg of it per day so have given me one week off it to clear the system - and, hopefully - completely clear me of the hives/skin rash then I start taking 5mg per day. UNTIL I got home and found out that I was only, ever, on 5mg.  As I was having to deal with the toothache I forgot to INCREASE the level to 10mg.  HEAVEN ONLY KNOWS what state I would be in had I taken the 10mg!!!!!  Rang them and apprised them of the situation and they have advised that after the one week off the Everolimus I start taking the 5mg tablet every other day, thus making the dosage 2.5mg a day, until I go back to see them on 6 December 2017. So what is Everolimus?  It is a kinase inhibitor (biological inhibitor), mTOR inhibitor targeted therapy and a single transduction inhibitor.  NOT an antineoplastic chemotherapy drug so this is not chemo. I asked what I could expect, next, from this drug.  So how long is a piece of string?  Seems that in the data collected they don't actually record WHEN new side effects happen at particular times with individuals.  Individuals are the key and as with Salamander65 her first problems, within days, was nausea and nose bleeds which I haven't had. I am all for this genomic testing that Prof Dame Sally Davies, our Chief Medical Officer, is after.  Link below will give you the insight into this.  This should help to target therapies which are personalised for your particular cancer. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/health-40479533 I also asked about the life-threatening side effects.  Oh, how they do dismiss these.  Their take is that it hasn't happened yet so why worry.  I feel I need to know what I should be looking out for.  We dismiss a lot of personal health stuff as trivial until it becomes a problem by which time it could have become truly hazardous.  For example, my heart has come up, to coin it, tickety boo.  I would be horrified to learn that the Everolimus or Exemestane had damaged it in some way let alone kidney, liver or lung damage. Cyst in the crease in the armpit turned out to be just that.  Was given a copy of the radiographers report on my US. Will have to get the digital scan.  Have been able to locate 2 of the armpit lymph node involvement - just need to find the other 2.  Mamm done on 2 August shows no sign of any of these!!!!!! So for the moment I am Everolimus free.  Will come back later when more known. Lots of love and hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Just a little update.  The Teva brand of Anastrozole (I think) has done the job.  I sometimes till get a little 'zing' in my wrist (which I put down to RSI) but the thumb has completely resolved.  YAHOO. ...... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Sonia Thanks for your input.  As I have said all along I am well aware of my decision.  In actual fact what I haven't had to experience is the pain and problems from the conventional treatment.  All I have had to do is to fit in appointments with the consultant.  My life has not been changed one iota or on hold due to the treatments whatsoever.  One of my last posts advised that reports show my cancer to be STABLE. Having said the above I went for a blood test with my GP and the Alkaline phosphatase level is quite high - in fact over the recommended ceiling.  However it is not supported by the serum gamma-glutamyl transferase level which would show a problem in the liver.  It could however be something to do with the bones so my GP is referring me back to the consultant/oncologist for tests, maybe.  Possibly need to have another DEXA scan. Other than that I am fine and dandy!!! ....still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Rozzie Thanks for the input.  I am going for a Thermogram on Tuesday in Harley Street - Yes Harley Street.  Been reading up on this.  Initially it will be a one off.  This will be a non-invasive way of finding out if the blood supply to the tumour is still active.  I haven't told them I already have breast cancer so it will be interesting to see what the thermogram shows.  I know what I want to see!!!!!  My two sisters are particularly interested especially as one is due for a screening mammogram at the end of October.  To try to get all of us at the clinic in a three hour slot (each thermogram and consult takes one hour) we would have had to wait until around 27 Oct.  I did not want to wait that long as I am champing at the bit to find out.  One sister coming along anyway with me. Still not heard anything from the surgeon/oncologist about a new appointment.  Will check Monday to see if GP has sent the last blood result. On a 'statin' at the moment for cholesterol and everything that I have watched and read says I should stop taking this tablet.  A growing idea is forming that as I was put on an increased dosage this could have something to do with the raised levels!  Can deal with it in a natural way by eating an apple or plum or 4/5 small carrots a day!! Must research my raised diastolic blood pressure and see if there is anything I can do naturally for that. ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Yeowww, what a myriad of things to think about.  Yay, now this is something to chat about. Clogheen, loved your bit - made me laugh.  Never thought about eating sparrow!  KentStar, so sorry to hear that cancer has been a really nasty critter in your family.  In my case, I have researched everything to do with my case, weighed up the pros and cons and made a decision.  I am always learning as different things crop up, ie when reading the other messages I research some of those things like the DIEP flap.  Yeowww on that one!  I am not in the healthcare business nor in the scientific field either.  I just felt that for all of my life I have not had to worry about my health.  When I needed to see the doc I went and these were only minor things.  BUT being diagnosed with BC is a different kettle of fish and because of the route they wanted to take I felt that I should know more about it. I wasn't advised of a healthy diet, exercise, supplements etc.  I imagine, from the conversations on here, these come after surgery or the chemo, ie no grapefruit, etc.  At the Mulberry Centre at West Middx Hospital I pulled all the booklets off the shelf to do with BC and all the bits on complimentary therapies.  The complimentary therapies only help minimally but at least there is some merit in them to de-stress.  Overwork is another – get used to telling your boss to ‘s.. off’ for constant overtime requirements – you need time for yourself, leisure etc but don’t over-indulge.  Booze is a very rare part of my life. So I went on the web and am truly amazed at what you can find there at your fingertips.  This has led me to my current course of action. Hairworries, herewith list of the supplements I take: Astragalus – immune booster Resveratrol (red wine extract) – fights yeast and fungal growth, anti-inflammatory, acts against COX-2, stops tumour cell growth, suppresses metasteses, attacks cancer cells in body by increasing levels of two proteins – perforin and granzyme B Mushroom complex – additional help for immune system Turmeric – inhibits multitude of cancer pathways, stops action of enzyme COX-2, inhibits vascular epithelial growth factors essential to blood supply to tumour, kills B-lymphoma cells, limits environmental damage, inhibits leukaemia cells, gets rid of metals in body Chlorella – communication help between cells and immune system, boosts white immune cell levels – interferon and T-cells, enhances levels of lactobacillus, beta carotene (10 x levels in carrots), organic iron (58x richer than spinach, vitamins D & K Spirulina – as Chlorella but each work better with each other Red Clover – contains isoflavone and phytoestrogens, blood purifier, contains genistein (blocks receptors to oestrodiol, also good for getting rid of microcalcifications and macrocalcifications (0 grade DCIS) Nettle – helping to get rid of microcalcifications, macrocalcifications Magnesium – for absorption of calcium tablet into the bone Aspirin – possible cancer prevention, halt metasteses, extend survival times Immiflex (stimulate immune system) – beta-glucans Immunokinoko (immunosenessence that works on older people and their immune system) – mushroom complex Krill Oil (omega 3 fatty acid – anti-inflammatory – has omega 3, 6, 9, Vits A and E, astaxanthin Pancreatin (enzyme support) ActivaMune (Diindolymethyl - oestrogen blocker) – Vit C, D3, E Pomegranate – combats yeast infection in gut Multivitamins Cranberry capsules Garlic capsules Anastrozole Calcium with D3 Raspberry ketones - to help lose weight!!!! Drink green tea (EGCG) – shown to block an enzyme that multiplies cancer cells causing their death, promotes beneficial bacteria in gut, anti cancer aid  Most are taken am and pm although some are just once a day. That’s all for now folks … still fighting this nasty little critter…..
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello to everyone interested in my cancer Where do I start on my Oncology consult today Started by getting Biopsy results 2 Lesions are Grade 3 from the high grade DCIS – also said was pre-cancerous! Lesion 1 (had biopsy done in 2012 showing ER8/PR8) (right breast 9am position 2.6cms from nipple) Now ER/6, PR/3, HER2/indeterminate – will go for further tests Lesion 2 – no biopsy taken, ever ER/0, PR/0, HER/0 – effectively triple negative So effectively I still have cancer – in their estimation. Asked how they had arrived at this. Look at the cells first to determine cancer or not, then check on receptor enzymes. There was a 'paper' the oncologist mentioned but she had left on the desk upstairs!!!!!  Can't recall which paper she said it was. NM Bone scan is clear of mets, CT scan clear of mets but noted were the lymph nodes in the axilla. SO VERY GOOD NEWS HERE. I do NOT believe myself to now have the cancer they think!  BUT WILLING TO BE PERSUADED IF OTHERWISE. Sorting out 2nd opinion on biopsies (looking at Royal Marsden). Oncologist said that they are quite happy to send tissue/slides for 2nd opinion but corrected herself to slides only!!!!! Royal Free, however, are still happy to send to chosen 2nd opinion hospital. Still trying to get pathology reports on EACH the 7 core punch biopsies taken. Oncologist stopped Chemo Nurse, attending on a fact finding session, from commenting at one point!!!!!! How can I trust this team when clearly any open comment could have been deemed as enlightening the patient!! During the consult there were a number of errors made by the oncologist to which when challenged were corrected. Lesion 2 ‘has changed’. How can it have changed when no biopsy was done in the first place!! Corrected herself to sending slides only for 2nd opinion rather than both tissue and/or slides when she first spoke of 2nd opinion? Information not been received by me - location of the ‘affected’ lymph node/s (asked for this information LONG BEFORE 27 October ultrasound but still have not received) - location of biopsied lymph node which they say was in Axilla but bruising I experienced did not conform to that location particularly as it sat between 2 blood vessels Questions/Inconsistencies - advised in a letter, from a complaint, that I had metastatic cancer - not locally advanced (it may just be ‘terminology’) but was not told verbally - is the rapid agreement for a 2nd opinion a hope to getting rid of this difficult patient! - have I questioned them too much which has opened up the inconsistencies of their diagnosis/treatment? - some write-up of reports are in error and not corrected - do I trust them (Royal Free) – NO! Do I believe there is an ongoing ‘cover up’? - will the referral letter from the Royal Free be ‘opinion free’? - am I of a suspicious mind also ‘just because I don’t get to hear what I want’! Just give me the requisite facts and I can then make a proper decision! STORY - END OF For some on this website, this write up will be a vindication of their stance. For those of you enlightened enough to see above all this I will be taking this further. An email has gone off to my private clinic for their thoughts on this information with even the possibility of my 5 September consultation at that clinic being brought forward to discuss and potentially plan a way forward. Up to last night I have every indication that I now had fibrosis/inflammation as a result of the SPDT treatment. That All cancer was dead. What I don’t have is TRUST in the Royal Free team who have been undertaking my care. Too many inconsistencies, poor record recording, change of mind on what they have said, off the cuff comments which reveal how rigid they are, belittling any of the alternatives I put forward of advancing breast cancer treatment, writing in letter/s that you have metastatic cancer but not told the patient!, cold consults which demean and belittle the patient who may have a brain in their head – you name it I think I received it! To say that my mental wellbeing is at an all-time low is an understatement. Until I get further answers I doubt I can rise above it, at the moment. Stress plays an important part in cancer - they fail, miserably, to understand this. What I should be is bl..dy angry. It might change to this. For everyone out there, I send love and virtual hugs on this fcuk journey. STORY, END OF
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Update. Clinic come back confirming inflammatory response and scarring, followed by tumour cell necrosis, which then results in scarring, which is what I am experiencing. My 5 September appointment still stands. For this positive response, in my estimation, I am very happy and will endeavour to keep this in mind over the coming month. Love and hugs
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello there my Lovely Ladies (and gents) Had to go to Page 25 to find my discussion!  So many new cases and ongoing cases.  Nasty little b.....r this cancer %$*! So, to an update.  Report on mammo says benign foci of calcification found in left breast with no malignancy. Report on CT of abdomen says 1 x 4mm lesion, could be a small calculus but may be a polyp, no biliary tree dilatation; normal pancreas, pancreatic duct; kidneys, adrenal glands, spleen, urinary bladder and pelvic organs do not demonstrate significant pathology.  They also say that there is scattered colonic diverticulitis!  No evidence of bone metasteses.  Possible gallbladder polyp - suggest US to further assess.  Scheduled to have US on gallbladder 5 February.  When I went into GPs' in January the form was ready and waiting for me to pick up which had been filled out by the GP on 22 December 2014!!!!  No-one had rung me or sent a text to inform me it was waiting to be picked up and for me to ring my local hospital to make the appointment!  Can't have anything to eat beforehand so good job it's at 9am. Report on bone scan - uptake of tracer in skull likely benign possibly related to hair styling (I have short hair!).  3 times I fell off a swing - as a kid, stall holder dismantling stall jumped up to get a piece of wood off the top and it hit my head and, not least, fainting and catching my head on a door jamb with heaven only knows how many other knocks in between!@!!.  Just wondering if I'm mentally stable now after that lot!!!!!  Heterogeneous uptake within the spine with no focal abnormality identified.  (I have a bony spur (osteophyte) on L5S1 which was identified on 9 January 2014 so this could be it.) So there you have it.  Some little things to keep a watch on but then I am 60 now and you would expect a few 'failings' at this age!! Anyway my love and hugs to everyone from someone ... still fighting this nasty little critter....in her own way!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Had the Thermogram.  Doesn't look like its changed but will wait to see report.  Have lymph 'congestion' around armpit area/s which has slightly improved but need to do more to help clear it and that means regular exercise and take some of this extra weight off which I am finding very hard to do.  Must get my head round it as in the end I will be better off for it. ....still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone So, today is Day 18 of Cycle 1 of EC.  Had a late shower before going to my local cancer support group.  MY HAIR HAS STARTED TO FALL OUT.  I noticed when washing it ever so gently that there were areas which 'hurt' and wondered 'what the heck'.  When my fingers then came away with copious strands of hair I knew what was 'up' though hadn't felt this on my scalp before going into the shower.  I also noted that those areas 'seemed' to have gone pink after the shower although that has now gone away.  I dried my hair very gently with the hair drier whilst using a very wide toothed brush.  More hair came out.  Found a hat I had that I could wear to the group as I could see a recognizable bald spot on the top of the head extending down the back. Went into Tesco after the group to buy some beany hats. So now I have to look forward to losing more hair.  Oh joy!  NOT. Love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Results from the GP.  He checked the computer and 'lo and behold' some of the side effects from the endocrine therapy is that it can mess with your other enzyme levels.  All my research never picked up on that one.  So I don't have to worry any more about my ALP, serum triglyceride etc.  I told the GP that the doc from the hospital had taken another blood sample from me and was probably waiting for those results before he can write to him (the GP) with a copy to me.  The GP did say that he would like to take another blood test from me sometime in June - just to check! I also got a copy from the GP on my gallstone.  Radiologist says it is approx. 7mm - a bit bigger than was mentioned from the CT scan!  BUT no action will be taken as there isn't a problem with it now.!!!! Oh, happy days.... Back when I have something more to tell 'thee' .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi dealite Thanks for this.  Haven't got online app or kindle so will have to go out to shops for hard copy.  Been going through the discussions and am learning a lot but oh so many, to my mind, horror stories.......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi puzzler Thanks for replying girl.  What's this 'capsule'?  AND I live alone.  I could actually stay with one of my sisters afterwards overnight if this is needed.  Would have to take the Paracetamol anyway for the boob pain/ache. Such a dilemma.  Wonder when I will get the appointments and what will be contained in them about medications!  Will they have thought about this?  Sometimes I do think I am a guinea pig. Have told them each and every time after cycles 1 and 2 that I thought the 3-weekly cycles were wrong.  In the 3rd week I find that I am prone to a lot of boob ache/pain although I do have it during weeks one and two.  I think I have diarised some form of ache or pain each and every day.  They can't advise what this stems from but if we talk about Lesion 1 pressing more and more against the skin then I think the chemo isn't working on one of the cancer 'types' but which one?  I had hoped that the routine would be changed, at least, to 2-weekly but I don't think that thought has crossed the oncologist's head!  I did mention it at the consult after cycle 1. And I confirmed this again at the consult on Wednesday but 2 different oncologists! Not happy at that as I have said above. So I am still being subjected to this protocol without them thinking on their feet when information given by the patient is showing a cause for a re-think. If they want to do progress to the Paclitaxol then fine or surgery, then fine. Just think a change of treatment is required. Love and hugs to you and everybody
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Went for my Thermogram today.  Should have been in July but 'dipsy' me got the dates wrong.  When doing the 'oblique' scan (this is where you sit partially side/partially front on to the camera) I couldn't see the 'red' of the tumour in my right breast - in other words no vascularity (blood supply) to the tumour making me think that the tumour had possibly gone!!!!  The lady technician quickly cottoned on when I commented on this so had to ramp up the 'red' colour in order to get the tumour to show which came up as a red dot.  My previous therms. all showed a lot of lymph congestion and particularly on the back. When having thermograms the technician has to take various factors into account like room temp, body temp, etc. The same settings are not used each time the thermogram is done. This thermogram is vastly different from the previous 2 thermograms I have had done and the technician doesn't understand why this has happened as I haven't done anything different in diet, supplements or exercise.  Most of the lymph congestion has gone.  However I did tell her that I had increased my intake of Vitamin D3 up to 10,000iu a day.  She didn't think that this could be the cause but has marked this down so that it can help the experts in giving their opinion on these scans and reporting back.  Can't wait to hear what they say!!!!! Was this a good day?  H*ll YES. When I get the report back I'll give you an update.  I have to admit that, as yet, I haven't gone back to the hospital to get a copy of my US nor the report on this done on 2 July but will do so when time permits. Love to everyone on this journey .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi toxophilite Found a trial a while back called START.  Doesn't quite have the dosage that's in mind for me but I think this was the start of the change.  I thought you had to go every day for as long as they thought you needed it, 15, 25, 35 sessions!  But I did find something about how the radiotherapy works - RT induces direct cell death by causing single- and double-stranded DNA breaks.  RT also promotes immune-mediated cell death through the increased release of tumour antigens, the induction of inflammatory cytokines, and the transient overexpression of cell surface receptors. Together, these mechanisms facilitate effector T cell killing of irradiated tumour cells and priming of antigen-presenting cells to increase the adaptive immune response against tumour cells elsewhere in the body, in non-irradiated areas. Interesting.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone Update: So I have now had my first and second palliative radiotherapy sessions (fast track). Unfortunately after the first ‘pass’ of radiation, between myself and the radiation team I had to have a small break. I was having pain due to how the breast was ‘lying’. It didn’t help that I had not been made aware beforehand of a ‘bolus’ placed over the breast which although relatively light added to the ‘pressure’ on the boob. The pain came from below the breast on a lump below the crease line where some nodules are now appearing and red/pink in colour. I can tell you I had tears in my eyes when the first pass finished and they noticed it. I just knew I could not move at the time of the radiation as it would have gone into the wrong areas. I think this made the pain worse as prior to the first session, if this happened, I would always adjust my position – as anyone would. I had to go to the GP for painkillers (Zapain) on Monday (3 December). She prescribed 30mg Zapain (codeine phosphate/Paracetamol) capsules. Can take up to 8 a day under medical supervision, over the counter preps are 8mg. When I showed her my boob she readily understood!!!! Said could get stronger meds (morphine based) if needed. Next day before the session I was actually due a dose of the Zapain but had been able, beforehand, to stretch this to 5 hours which would have included the radiotherapy time. During the 15 minute break I took the tablets, composed myself and was able to do the next bit. However it is clear that it is the ‘bolus’ which was the problem as I started to hurt again in one of the areas below the crease line. Told the radiographer as much. Has anyone ever had a ‘bolus’ placed over their boob? Haven’t been able to find anything in peoples’ write-ups. Web says a bolus is a waxy tissue equivalent material (pad) placed on the skin surface to homogenize or modulate the range of the dose from external beams of radiation. Talked again yesterday with radiographer. They say it helps to level out the beam to the area they want to target. They also have to tape this pad down on the boob. They did it very lightly yesterday (11th Dec – 2nd session) but it still built up to a bit of pain by the time they did the first pass. They told me I am doing well but still causing pain! They also have to tape it down so that there is no air trapped! I don’t know if I am being given a load of hogwash on this! Bought some Aloe Vera gel – maximum strength – from Dr Organics to put on. Saturday morning (8 Dec) I found something irritating my breast. It was a small congealed solid mass of the gel. It had caused one of my lesions to bleed with lymph stuff. Was easy to peel off. After showering noticed lymph seepage. I was able to put on a plaster which the hospital had given me although it isn’t quite big enough to cover all of the lesions and is said to come off easily without damaging skin. Can’t wear bras or soft tops as they put pressure on the boob and it starts to hurt. Stopped using Aloe. Also got saline phials and wipes from the hospital. Every week I have to see the Senior Radiotherapy Nurse! He replaced existing plaster after swab which caused more pain so have had to cut off a piece which he had placed on the boob like a ‘diamond’ rather than the ‘square’ I had done. 3 more radiotherapy sessions to go. 2 would have been 25 Dec and 1 Jan! These ones will be brought forward 1 day beforehand. 1 Jan (31 Dec 2018) will be the last one. CT Thorax Abdomen Pelvis booked for 30 Dec. Consult back with Oncologist 2 Jan 2019. My boob is swollen from the radiotherapy as well. Ordered the R1/R2 creams and have just read that I cannot use them on open wounds. Maybe I can use it around these but since receipt of these have been told not to use them. On 11 Dec swab taken to check for infection. Will get results of that at my next radiotherapy session. One lump below breast but ABOVE crease line (mammary fold) really red and hurts – this is where some of the pain stems from. Did anyone have a swollen boob after their radiotherapy? They say it has to get worse before it gets better!!!!!! Health is fine though a little phlegmy. Cough gone just the phlegm left. Still taking the innohep for blood clot on lung – bruising minimal now that I have got the hang of it – you need to do the injection very slowly over about 20-30 seconds. I had been injecting it too quickly. Love and virtual hugs to everyone
