Posts.Content: Hi All Update: SO, HOW MANY OF YOU HAVE HEARD OF “RADIATION RECALL”? You can find info on the web. Basically this is when you have had radiotherapy and have been put back onto chemo very quickly after it. I have had ‘one hell of a time’ because of this as it manifests as radiation burns! My last session of radiotherapy was 31 December 2018. I was a little pink on the boob and still dealing with the strep infection on the surface lesions. Correction here – advised you of using collogen plaster over lesions, it’s not collogen but silicone wound contact layer/plaster (safetax technology – which means it is easy to take off). Therefore I was told I could not put any cream WHATSOEVER on any of the boob and complied. I was put onto the Paclitaxel on 10 January 2019. Having not been told about it the resultant burgeoning deep redness and peeling of the skin I took it to be a normal side effect of the radiotherapy. Certainly I haven’t read anything on here about it nor in any of the literature received or of any ladies who have reported as suffering from it. AND was neither told by the Consultant Radiologist/Oncologist nor even the Oncologist about it to possibly look for it who had quickly put me onto the next chemo regimen (Paclitaxel) because of the lesions in my liver! In fact when I found out, I searched the web who say this happens in 9% of cases which, to me, is quite large. It is a very poorly understood ‘syndrome’. Clearly here, there is a reason WHY the medics HAVE to give time between finishing one treatment before starting another. This is very likely the reason why we have to wait at least 1 week between each Paclitaxel treatment so that the body can recover from the onslaught. AND a week’s rest after your 3rd dose of Paclitaxel in order that Red and White Blood counts, Platelets and Neutrofils can recover. Certainly these are the only ‘counts’ that are recorded in my chemo book. Over the 5 weeks of radiotherapy all of these ‘counts’ recovered brilliantly and in most cases increased but are now falling off again with the constant 3 ‘weekly’ doses of Paclitaxel. My boob is now recovering from the radiation ‘burns’ but only at my ignoring what the medics say I should do on this point. I asked why I could not put cream on the other areas of the boob not known to have the strep infection. They advised that I could but it would be at my own risk as the cream could cause a bigger infection which they wanted to avoid at all costs. That was told to me when they ‘believed’ that I was suffering from Radiation Recall at the Oncologist consult on 30 January 2019 (my radiation ‘burn’ had begun to manifest on 15 January 2019 – by 21 January it was at its worst). I lashed on the E45 cream after that bit of info and the relief from itching and pain was too immense to explain in words. My boob always seems to feel ‘warm’ to touch and I have niggling bits of itchiness still but at least most of the redness has gone. When I looked at the boob yesterday I thought that this next round of Paclitaxel just ‘might’ be the Radiation Recall coming back. I’m keeping an eye on it and taking regular photos so I have a record. In fact my mobile is full of my boobie!!!!! (Ironically, the strep infection might have ‘eaten’ some of the tumours below the boob and the big lesion I had at the 3oclock position. But the medics say that it is most likely the Pac. What about the use of virotherapy as a treatment! Still so much that they really do not know about.) I still have one lesion below the boob which didn’t have the strep infection but neither the radiation or Pac ‘seem’ to have had any effect on it either! This one can cause pain when trapped between my ‘down south’ boobie and tum! Still taking the morphine which helps with this. I am due to have a CT scan after finishing this 2nd ‘cycle’ of 3 Paclitaxel to check on the liver lesions but have yet to wait for the appointment. Request was made in my notes at my consult on 30 January 2019 to be done but I am still awaiting this. Must give them a ring as it is now at least 12 days since. These people haven’t followed through the request. Next Oncology consult is 6 March and this CT scan ‘should’ be performed before then!!!!!! Saw the Community Palliative Care Nurse on 22 January 2019. Not debilitated far enough for any of these services YET but she went off with a list of things she would research and possibly put in place for me to see so that, at least, I would have the general info for the future. She arranged for District Nurse to see me about my boob ‘wounds’ who finally came on 4 February. Next visit just to check on wounds will be w/c 18 February, no firm date set. Side effects from Paclitaxel: none that I can readily identify except for fatigue. Am finding I don’t have the ‘sparkle’ I used to have. Oncologist was very happy I didn’t have peripheral neuropathy! What about the Radiation Recall! Sheesh!@! Oncologist also ‘felt’ that the breast had got softer! Yeah, right! Noticing an ache at the top of my right lung. Could be radiation damage. Will ensure that when I get the CT scan that the radiographer checks on this. So, my opinion of the standard treatment – ABSOLUTE PANTS. There has gotta be a better way than this. Story – end of. Will bring back an update when I have more. Love to all on this ‘PANTS’ journey.

Posts.Content: Hi All Well I have had my Thermogram and received the results and the pictures.  There's not much they can say at the moment as they need to do another one to make any distinction.  So I am going to have another one in January.  What I do see is that in the area of the tumour there is only a small'ish spot of red.  My left breast is at risk with a red line but fibrocystic in nature and is often associated with lymph congestion.  Dry skin brushing is recommended for this.  My right breast is consistent with confirmed DCIS and no defined vascular pattens are noted to suggest associated angiogenesis - no new blood vessel growth!!!!  Yippee.  And the report says no vascular patterns in the left breast!  Yippee, again. What I wanted to see was no red spots at all but I suppose I cant have everything. ..... still fighting this nasty little critter.....

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Well, I am gutted.  The lymph node has cancer in it.  To be slapped in the face with this after all I have done has left me deflated somewhat.  I am now about to go through the 'staging' process again to check if it has travelled anywhere else.  Tomorrow (Sat) I have a CT scan of thorax, abdomen pelvis with contrast, Tuesday I have a full bone scan.  Wednesday the team meet to discuss my case and I go back on Thursday for a consult. What more can I say, except .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Thanks for the messages and more info to my elbow!  Asked the hospital to continue to monitor me and they agreed.  I don't think they can let you be out there on your own without, so it seems, always trying to get you to undertake the conventional treatment.  Somebody said they wouldn't be paid if I didn't take the treatment but I think they have to be paid something as I am still a patient under their care. With regards to getting this nasty little critter I have read that it could stem from an viral infection.  I had some boils (in a funny place) 5 years ago and was running a temperature and feeling 'wabbit'.  As tumours cannot be seen on a mamm until they have proliferated to 1 billion + cells and takes (well mine did and possibly everyone elses) 5 years to get to my growth size I am linking it with the boils.  At a support group someone told me they knew someone else who had boils!!!!  Now it's only two people, I know, but........ I was also stressed due to being made redundant.  If you get your thinking caps on you might just be able to pinpoint some possible causes.  You need to think about what could have depressed your immune system and caused the cells to proliferate. I don't have any of the other health problems as I have seen from the website message which could account for it.  Start writing them down.  Oh and on an 'upper' make a bucket list of the thing/things you most want to do when you finally beat the cancer into submission.  I have and its for that purpose only. Love you all ..... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies and Gents SCANS CAME BACK CLEAR for any progression.  The only thing to deal with is the cancer in a/the lymph nodes.  They still want to do surgery and take 3cm away as well as the axilla lymph array.  It's amazing how my BCN thinks the same way as me as she said 'she ain't going to do that!'  And that's exactly what I said.  I am now about to try Letrozole and have taken my first little tab!  Let's see what side effects I get from that! The CT scan did bring up the gallstone/polyp.  Their thought is that it is a polyp but I am having another scan on 3rd September to confirm this.  Next consult appointment has been made for February 2017! This is the first time I have been a little 'anxious' about a consult and what results it might bring.  Not even the original diagnosis phased me. But I am a HAPPY BUNNY to say the least and tomorrow I am going on a short holiday to relax and recuperate from all of this - the first in quite a few years. My very, very best and love to everyone fighting this disease. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies Just got the digital scans in the post from the hospital.  Have checked them out all out (and there were quite a few) and to me they all look good.  Went on web for pictures of metastases of bone - none on the web correlate to my full bone scan and I cant see anything in my pictures at all.  Liver shows no metasteses either.  Left boob mammogram sort of OK but that's because the only other one I have (in my arsenal) is the one from the screening test back in August 2012 and it seems that different mammogram machines can make the boob calcifications etc., look a little different. However it all depends on what the experts say when I go the breast clinic on 18 December! Now just gotta go and have the blood test done again at my GP's.  When I get the results of that I'll make sure that I take a copy with me to the consultant for their files.  Hope that one comes back just as good otherwise there is an unknown problem at large in my body!!!! Will get back to you on the 18th. My love to everyone having to deal with this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Kitkat59 Initially with Anastrozole but now Letrozole.  No surgery or radiotherapy whatsoever despite 'the team' recommending them.  BC nurse so in tune with me 'she ain't gonna agree to that' she said.  They 'say' it has grown which is why I am on the Letrozole now but as you know any ultrasound 'measurements' are freehand and I have to say I seem to have had a different 'operator each time - no consistency, see! Slightly 'anxious' about my 2nd biopsy I had for the lymph node which is a minimally invasive procedure but I had such a bruise afterwards!  Know of cases where biopsies have 'seeded' another tumour.  Gotta feel positive though that 4 years down the line I am relatively okay. Now thinking I really need to do something radical!  One on the horizon is Rerum, a better version of the GC-MAF - if you know of any of the alternative treatments - but you can only get that abroad.  Just heard of a new machine whereby it measures the liquid in your body and gives the medical team a readout of 130 'enzymes' in your body giving doctors more information at their fingertips.  However this is used in alternative therapy so that diet, etc., can be tuned to the person, ie. would eating red meat be good for you or would it help the cancer to grow.  Mind-boggling what's going on out there but not in the UK.  This would replace a blood test with good accuracy. Another little gem I learnt today is as I don't do mammogrammes any more, only ultrasound, and if you choose to use thermograms as well they can be up to 98% more effective at giving a diagnosis. Any way, that's all for now.  Thanks for the discussion.  Take of yourself. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hi All Just to bring people up to date on my case. Renewed the Letrozole for the next 3 months.  Currently on Accord and have a couple of weeks to go.   Pharmacist gave me 1 x Manx Healthcare box and 2 x Dr. Reddy's.  Which box should I choose next, I wonder?  You will note that these brands have not hit our discussions so will be interesting to see if I suffer with any side effects!  Not currently experiencing any side effects except for the hot flushes of course.  Does this mean I am still menopausal!!!!!!!!  No periods at all or any indication but then at 62 - heavens, isn't that 'old sounding' - I don't think I should be having any anyway! Next consultation on BC on 9 February at 2.50pm.  No tests done so no idea how the Letrozole has done on my BC.  Methinks I should have an US BEFORE the consultation so that we can discuss it at the consultation but this was not what was booked 6 months ago.  Seems a bit 'arse about face' to me!  When I do get the next US I will ensure the operator checks on the lymph node. Thought a couple of times I could feel the 'little critter' but just lately haven't been able to find 'it' again.  Ho hum, will cop another feel before bed tonight which I should go to soon. Thanks to you all for your interest.  Keep on writing discussions on this web.  I am STILL learning a lot 4 years 6 months later!  Sending cyber hugs and will come back after the consultation. ...still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: HI All Well a few things have happened over the succeeding weeks.  Had Ultrasound on 31 December 2015 on both boobs.  Saw consultant (not the Polish guy - unfortunately he was only a locum - DAMN) on 14 January 2016.  Now they are saying that it has reduced - wait for it - to 7x5mm from 10mm!  I know that the Polish guy mentioned 10mm at his consultation but I have no idea where this measurement came from.  I do know that the tumour on 8 Aug 2013 was 5x5x7mm with the microcalcifications from a report on 1 May 2014 at 10x6mm.  Initially they were asserting that this size was the tumour - and it seems they still are.  So from a positive stance - YAAAYYYY - you could say my tumour is still reducing!!! You will recall that I had started the Boswellia Resin Extract (Frankincense) once a day with Frankincense Oil rubbed on at night.  Wonder if it is this that has made a difference - but how to quantify! I also reviewed the US scans of 1 May 2014 and noticed the tumour with a black blob next to it which wasn't shadowing as can be seen under tumours on US.  Asked the consultant about this and it turns out that when my tumour reduced it sort of split into two - the dark blob is the dead tumour.  Now I didn't know this.  Have tried to google dead tumours in situ but can't find any.  Most tumours that then die are the ones that have been cut out!  This dark blob is weird - it looks like a dried up flat mud pile with fissures/cracks in it.  Having just looked again there is a regularity in the 'fissures'.  I wonder if it is the coils from the titanium clip!!!!!  Interesting!  Not doing any harm so is being left be! Next appointment is in July and as it will have been 2 years since the last mamm on the right boob I think I would like to see 'the state of play' with it.  Acceptable risk and all that. So I am a 'happy bunny'.  My love to all of you dealing with this insidious little b*****.  Will come back when I know more. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Sorry for the delay in getting back to you but much has been going on. Tried to get repeat prescription from GP of Arimidex and was told categorically that they would not sanction it. Now I ask myself WHY some women in the UK are prescribed this and not others? I have questioned this with the CCG as GP had already sought guidance from them who advised not to prescribe. CCG are investigating with GP and hospital. As a result of this stress I checked with Oncology at the hospital for the appointment I had yet to receive and have had that on 4 October. I agreed to be put on Exemestane and Everolimus (the everolimus makes the exemestane work better – they say). Everolimus does have some bad side effects which I am hoping to escape!!!! Like lesions on the lungs!!!!! I was also prescribed Lemon Mucilage which is a liquid anti inflammatory (probably from the exem. and ever.). Exemestane tablets on the web cost £167.59 for a 30 day period and Everolimus £2822 (how much it is for the NHS I don’t know) and certainly the Oncologist said she would have to get approval for the Everolimus. Other potential treatments (for the future) Tamoxifen (in which case I will have to stop the Clopidogrel which stops my platelets from clumping together so that I don’t form clots easily and would become a ‘bleeder’ when combined with the Tamoxifen) or Fulvestrant which would mean jabs in the bum!!! On my new treatment I have to go back on 18th October for another appointment and blood test to see how I am coping with it. So far no side effects although have had a few hot flushes. Received a copy of the BC consultant’s letter which says original tumour is now at 11x9mm with architectural distortion over 80mm in area (boob looks fine here externally but could be distorted internally). Reactive lymph node (existing known tumour) is 11x11mm!!!!! -flaming heck – with cortical thickness of 8mm. New area of concern, from the nipple approx. 90mm, is a 16mm length area of ‘concern’ with bilateral benign calcifications. Can feel this. Can also feel this ‘disappearing’ as the exem. and ever. work (only 7 days in!!!!!). Also mentioned ‘two neoplastic appearing lymph nodes’ – on this I don’t know if one of them could be the one already mentioned or whether there are now 3!!! I now have copies of the scans and I think there are only 2 lymph nodes ‘affected’. Can’t feel either. Letter also quotes putting me back onto Anastrozole!!!!! Not the Arimidex. Sheesh. (GP said £1 for generic or £80 for original.) Wonder what the GP’s going to make of the new treatment costs!!!!!!! On top of all that I am sorting out the house of stuff I really don’t need so that I can sell up to move back up North. Houses there are cheaper to buy and I can use the left over equity to supplement state pension when I retire. However I will also use some of my personal pensions 25% tax free portion to find an alternative therapy outside the UK or try to find out if I can do this at a clinic I have found in the UK – will need clearance and approval from the powers that be in the UK for UK treatment but it will not necessary for outside UK unless I try to get NHS to fund for me!!!!! So much to do. Take care of yourselves ladies (and gents). Will come back on my discussion after 18th Oct appointment with the necessary blood test.

Posts.Content: Hi All Had my consult on the 9th and as I said in previous posting 'arse about face' with the US being done afterwards, just today in fact.  Grilled the radiographer, who was the consultant radiographer, who seemed very knowledgeable.  Had a young woman in tow who was his junior I suppose.  She herself was very confident and actually did the US.  Together they looked at the US done in Sept 16 and the measurements today - tumour is still the same - 8mm (depth) x 6mm (width) - don't know the length!  Lymph node still at 0.31mm which I can't feel now.  Was able as I have said before that I thought I could feel the tumour but over the past week have not been able to (properly) - but it is still there as a marrowfat pea size.  Ho hum. Still it hasn't grown and I suppose I should be glad about that.  Will write more when I have had the consult next week.  Love to everyone.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Lavendergirl Hives have now stopped itching and being an angry red but still have to clear their 'marks'.  Now got something on hands and between toes where skin is 'peeling' and causing a lot of problems.  GP said to continue with Diprobase I got yesterday. Yes, the breast care team and the oncologist - well first time I met with them - do keep asking if I will have surgery.  Frightening statement by them is that you can get to a 'point of no return'.  The breast care team at my last appointment now want to do mastectomy.  That's a bit too far for me.  'Primary tumour' (from MDT team they say at 11x9mm - at diagnosis 13x7x21mm) I have never been able to feel, even now. Latest ultrasound scan report says 6x10x6mm. Still to get the scan itself. I can actually feel the new area of concern more posteriorly at 16mm of which latest ultrasound says 7x12x7mm which hasn't had a biopsy to determine if it is cancerous.  Unfortunately I believe that the FNA they did on one of my axillary lymph nodes has caused it to grow exponentially thus confirming that the new area is very likely cancerous and that with every invasive procedure the potential for spread is coming true.  With the new treatment I do believe the new area of concern to be reducing (as above) and I like to think that this is also coming true for the rest of the tumours.  Certainly the latest ultrasound report is confirming this as opposed to the latest breast care team letter/s. I cannot 'feel' the axillary lymph node at the 6 o’clock position of the axillary array (at the edge of the boob at the 9 o’clock position) although I should as the MDT team say it measured 11x11mm. This is the one I thought they did the FNA on. The new scan report measures it at 11x6mm.  Can't find it on the mamm scan but it is on the US so some resolution here. Also found the position of the other axillary lymph node they mentioned at a previous scan which I can't feel and is located within the middle of armpit area between the armpit and the boob.  Just need to find out where the other 2 are they think may be a problem - all I think as a result of the FNA but could be as a result of the Letrozole not doing a damn thing for me. Crucially this report does not mention the latter of these axillary nodes nor the other 2 suspect ones! The point FOR any surgery is that the tumour cell load is reduced thus allowing your immune system to mop up any stray circulating tumour cells. The Exemestane and Everolimus seem to be doing a good job on the tumours so I expect it is doing the same to the circulating tumour cells. Just wish this treatment hadn’t come along with the hives/skin rash! Still, will keep on using it. One of the letters from the oncologist to my GP said “with systemic endocrine treatments there is a law of diminishing returns in that the strength of response to each agent in turn tends to diminish with line of therapy”. AND I read somewhere that surgery is the CORE therapy of conventional treatment. So – can I find a surgeon willing to take out 2 areas of concern in the boob and simply take out the affected axillary lymph nodes? Could I find one that would use a CO2 laser rather than a scalpel and cautorising blood vessels that leads to pain afterwards? Questions? Research? All ongoing. New things heading our way but still a ways to go: Intrabeam (radiotherapy) Radio wave breast imaging (you lay down like in an MRI with boob in slot) this maps WHERE the tumours/differences are in the boob using an algorithm which can identify normal, dense, fatty tissue and discount them  to show only the solid lesions. You will also see the shape of the tumour/s leading to better surgical excision/s I suspect. This will replace mamms so that no longer will we be clamped in a machine and have ionised radiation. That’s all for now. Take care everyone. As usual Love to all.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Been diagnosed with cancer, 3 small (largest 1.5cm) nodes of cancer and Grade II DCIS in right breast with pre-cancerous cells around the nodes to a 4.1cm area.  Lymph glands in armpit clear.  Seems that the only treatment on offer is to cut it out and give radiotherapy. I was happily going down the route of “slice and burn” when I was told that a 6cm lumpectomy would be the slice (this is almost the size of a tennis ball)!  Even though a date was set for the op I had to cancel.  I felt I was being propelled into it both by the ‘team’ and family.  All were ‘for it’ and ‘doing it in my interests’ but I just could not commit. In checking out websites I find that most of the blogs are to do with secondary cancers and I am more than ever nervous at being cut.  I have however given myself a month to check out other therapies to settle my mind.  I would dearly love to talk to ladies who have been in the same predicament. Is there anyone out there?
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Consult done.  Measurement they say is 7.8mm (depth) x 6.1mm (width) so partial response to Letrozole.  Waited 2 hours 15 minutes for that!  Head Consultant's list had extended to that long so was seen by another doctor - a nice young one!  We had a chat, he copped a feel of the tumour and the lymph node and we then talked again.  He saw the note about my polyps and wanted to refer me to another doctor with a view to having my gallbladder out!  No thanks I said.  It ain't bothering me, I'll think about this if it does!  Sister who came with me likes the this doctor - not the wrong way ladies!  As he was looking at the whole of my case, I think she felt that rather than concentrating on the one thing - the cancer - he was also looking at my whole health which she liked. Anyway, booked appointments for August for US and a mammogramme.  Yes, a mammogramme.  I think I need to see what's going on as well.  Last one on my right boob was 8 May 2014 - stuck to US only to monitor.  The left one had a mamm on 21 November 2014 when I felt a lump there - it was only a cyst.  Consult has been booked for after these scans.  Got it the right way round this time!!!!!!! On the point about waiting for 2 hrs 15 mins, I did notice that 2 ladies had very long consults with 1 lady's daughter, I suppose, accompanying her.  She kept coming back after the consult asking questions of the nurses on duty.  I can only assume that our ranks are swelling.... Other than that, my cyber love to you all and sending hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies (and Gents) Well, tomorrow I have my mamms and Ultrasound.  Must remember to make sure that the mamm radiographers don't squash me hard. I really will do mischief to them if they do!!!!! On another note have suffered a minor stroke.  Lost the vision in my right eye - a right (eye) retinal artery occlusion.  However  sight does seem to be coming back - although slowly - as my body starts to find new pathways to correct the problem. This was down to high blood pressure - readings ranging from 213/102 to 197/98 - which I had said was not the cause but obviously it was!  What do I know!  On BP tablets of course and seems because I had been slipping on my diet I am back on the statins.  Spent 12 hours at the hospital as they did an eye scan, and due to the high blood pressure also said I should have blood test, as well as go to Casualty to be given urgent treatment - Amlopidine for the BP.  Didn't work.  Thoughts were to take me into hospital but eventually let me go home with prescription for Ramipril and Clopidogrel.  The sroke was just in the eye, nowhere else.  Lucky!!!!!!!! On 20th July was seen by the Stroke Unit where I had ultrasound of arteries in neck - all okay, MRI of head - no evidence of any stroke in the brain (that's if I have one!!!!) past or present and an electrocardiogram - lady consultant was highly delighted with this one.  Diet: No Red Meat, No Dairy, No Salt.  Consultant wants my Cholesterol to go down from 6.1 to 4.0 with the LDL's less that 2.0 which at the time of the blood test were 3.3. Now as if I haven't got enough to deal with!!!!!!!!  But let this be a warning to all not to discount high BP readings.  I felt perfectly fine and healthy but as with BC there is another silent predator in the wings.  Will come back with update on the mamms, US and consult when all complete. Love to you all.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Skylight Thank you for asking.  Had the mamms on both boobs.  Was really only interested in the right boob so didn't ask to see the left boob mamms.  From the quick glance I saw of both craniocordal and mediolateral scans on the right boob most of the microcalcifications and calcifications have gone.  Couldn't see the lymph node with cancer as at this size - .33mm - they don't often get seen, radiographer said.  Original site of the tumour still there with ductal signs of it - hence the 7.8mm x 6.2mm size.  It is never seen as a 'lump' per se but as an 'erupting volcano' with 'lava sliding down it'.  You can sometimes see these on mamm pictures on the internet.  Additionally had the setting on the lowest (lightest) - which was 3 - which you need to get any proper definition of the mamms (otherwise they will be blurred, asked the lady radiographer on this).  I didn't feel as if I was 'clamped' hard just slightly 'pressured'.  I'm just not sure whether mamms on maximum setting would give any clearer pictures!  To me, on my quick glance I think I am doing bl..dy good!  Thanked the lass for being so considerate. Ultrasound - angle of the screen did not allow me to see what she saw.  However I can do a good thorough check once I order copies of the scans and pay for them.  Had a good chat whilst she was working.  Constant interruptions from people coming in though.  Was a lengthy US as a result.  Radiographer said scans showed - as she put it - 'vague' pictures.  Didn't ask her to clarify...  She looked up my old scans for confirmation of where it is!  She also had a look at an area just outside the armpit at the top towards the right boob where my old bra had pinched and caused me pain and inflammation.  Unknown as to what she thought of that or what she will report.  You could say that I am clinging on to the 'vague' bit she quoted from the US but from the clearness of microcalcs and calcs on the mammogramme I am fairly hopeful for my consult on the 17th. Will come back on that after the consult.  All my love and support to everyone on this rollercoaster.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: So!  Why a second post? Well, after the February consult debacle I DECIDED I WAS GOING TO DO SOMETHING MYSELF.  It took a bit of time to get sorted but I have had the Sono Photodynamic Therapy, privately, in the UK in April.  Yes Ladies, I have.  Self empowerment is a brilliant feeling. The course covered 2 weeks.  The first Monday was to give a bit of blood for an ordinary blood test but also some to be sent off to Greece for an OncoTrace.  This OncoTrace determines what enzymes are causing my cancer and takes up to 3 weeks to come back.  A new OncoTrace is set for September when I have my next consult at the clinic.  We then had to get the photosensitizer, Sonnolux-1, into my system.  This is done through a dropper under the tongue and took 1 hour to achieve – only a small bottle, and it makes your tongue blue!  For one lady it took 5 hours, but then I was asked to come thirsty and no food, so early appointment, for it to soak in.  We then had a look around the treatment room which contains both the Photodynamic equipment and the Sono.  The Photodynamic is delivered through a far infra red bed – a bit like a suntan bed, you wear goggles.  The Sono is delivered by your standard sonograph machine that is already used for zapping those pesky kidney stones, etc.  After a cup of my green tea I was able to leave.  (After Friday’s treatment I left clutching another bottle of Sonnelux-1 to be taken the following Monday at home.  I took this after I woke up before any breakfast or drink.  It is absorbed better and quicker this way.)  It takes 48-72 hours to ‘attach itself’ to cancer. Wednesday, Thursday and Fridays’ (nothing Tuesdays) were devoted to the Sono Photodynamic treatment over the next 2 weeks.  The treatment times for this increased each day.  1st Wednesday was 5 minutes, 5 min. break, then another 5 mins under the light being emitted onto my body even underneath with my right arm above my head and you do this totally stark naked!  You are then moved to a couch when the Nurse uses the Sono machine and gives you 5 mins on the boob and, in my case, 5 mins on the axilla with a 5 min break in between.  The Sono treatment stays the same for all treatment days.  1st Thursday was 8 mins light, 8 mins rest, then 8 mins again under the light.  1st Friday was for 10 mins light, 10 mins rest, 10 mins light.  2nd Wednesday was 12 mins light, 12 mins rest, 12 mins light, 2nd Thursday and Friday saw us reach 15 mins light, 15 mins rest, 15 mins light. Nurse is with you at all times.  You can chat with her or ‘contemplate your navel’ if you want.  I found that chatting away to the nurse made the time go quicker. Prior to each treatment day we had Ozone Therapy.  This means taking some of your blood into a bag which already contains the Ozone.  Your blood drips down into the bag, set down lower than your heart, and when enough is taken, about 50mls, the bag is then raised to drip back into you.  It is absolutely amazing just how red your blood becomes from the ozone.  I asked if I was going to get ‘high’ on this.  I had read that having hyperbaric oxygen can give you a ‘good’ feeling so was hoping for something like this.  Not to be for me.  One lady they said DID get high.  Tumours tend to be hypoxic (lacking in oxygen) so the effectiveness of the SPDT treatment is IMPROVED. Now to side effects.  You WILL get inflammation and can last between 4-12 weeks.  This is as a result of the dead tumour/s being attacked by your immune system as it mops up those dead cells.  The Sono zaps any cells deeper within the tissue, supposedly up to 12cm deep.  From this you can get pain for which Dexamethasone (a low dose steroidal anti-inflammatory) is given to you.  I only experienced a few gripes in the early days after treatment.  However when my right breast nipple and areolar went white they recommended I start the Dex.  I carried a card for this drug but after about 2 weeks I had to be weaned off it.  You cannot just stop this medication but it only takes 1 week to do so by taking the drug on alternate days.  So, what are the physical effects on me.  My right boob is a bit mis-shapen from the inflammation.  I have an elongated egg-shaped slight bulge at the 9pm position and a bit of dimpling which I never had before – very likely due to the bulge.  Lately I have had a few sharp pains in various places though not too uncomfortable.  Therefore the inflammation is still resolving nearly 2 months (8 weeks) after the treatment has finished.  The bulge has a central area which ‘feels’ hard and I have assumed that this is now ‘scar’ tissue which in the early days had about a two inch ‘hard’ feel to it but which has reduced since then – just checked my boobie!!!!!  ‘Think’ I can now feel my primary due to the inflammation which I have never been able to do.  It is recommended that any scans are not done for 12 weeks (3 months) as a false positive could be indicated. When the hospital MDT team told me they wanted to do an MRI instead of the Ultrasound I sought out another private clinic who could do this.  Having had this done I can report that she couldn’t see the tumour/s.  Additionally, and crucially, she found no blood supply to the tumour/s.  There is, however, an area in the axilla that looks like a ‘black hole’ which needs further investigation.  We’ll also see what the MRI will bring up when done. So there you have it – chapter and verse.  Comments welcome.  As always, love and hugs to everyone on this journey. [edited]
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Thanks to KateG and Sacha Rose for comments. Cancer is oestrogen receptive and could take Tamoxifen, if necessary, pre-op.  Still looking on web and two good therapies have come to light, Hyperthermia and Photodynamic - the latter looking very encouraging.  Only problem I don't think they have been used on patients in the first instance.  I am still dithering and the kind sentiments of copy letters I receive from the consultant to my doctor make me, only sometimes, lean towards surgery.  The negative effects of conventional treatment are definitely not for me! (and I say that with tongue in cheek).  It does seem that yes it does work but only after you have gone through the mill with the treatment.  Not happy with future expected outcomes though. In the meantime, looking after health, diet and exercise (more than usual).  Funny thing though, just today I felt the area of my breast (still cant feel the lumps) and it felt cool!!!! Going to sit and watch TV now with heat pad on the area!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Now had the hyperbaric oxygen. In the chamber with 3 other new ladies and 2 old hands – capacity 6. Can’t say that I feel any different. However as with anything, I was told afterwards you cant expect too much from the first outing. You need to carry on. Initially they said to do 15 sessions over 3 weeks, daily basis. One lady came out of the chamber before I went in. She says that she can ‘feel’ its effects straight away but then that lady did have MS and she goes every week. She also says that she does ‘miss it’ when she doesn’t get her weekly ‘imbibe’ of oxygen. Her session was at 24 feet. After a small chat on safety I was given an oxygen mask. Deposit for this is £25. If you decide to stop taking the hyperbaric oxygen this deposit is returned to you. Session for the oxygen is £30 for private patients who don’t have MS. No shoes allowed in the chamber but luckily had socks on. It is said that bare feet can get cold. I took my watch off (didn’t have to) and left handbag outside in care of operator – everyone did. Took some magazines into the chamber they had available to read. Also took a washing up bowl which you turn upside down to rest your feet on. Some of the chairs can be a bit high which leave your feet dangling. For bare legs there were blankets available. You are locked in, have the oxygen face masks on and we start pressurizing. Found the mask to be a bit heavy on my nose but coped. We get up to 8 ft when the operator advises that he is now about to send us up to 16.5 ft. At this point the 2 ‘old hands’ put their masks on!! They like to chat you see! Except for the noise from the pressurising we are quiet. When we get to 16.5 ft we are either reading books on our iphones/book or like me reading the magazines. The longer you keep your mask on the better to get pure oxygen. Chatting is hard through the mask! Phone usage – no signal but there is internet access. After an hour at this pressure he starts to depressurise the chamber. We then finish and exit. I did have a couple of coughs during the oxygen and had to remove my mask. I found that I was constantly breathing through my mouth. It may be how first timers respond to having the mask on. I did try to breathe through my nose but kept going back to mouth breathing. This could have dried my airways so I ended up coughing. Back out of the chamber I had a quick coffee for which you donate money. I then paid my bill, talked a while to an MS patient who also had had cancer and left for home. Didn’t get back until 2.50pm. I’m definitely booked for 16 August but 9 August was fully booked. I am however on the waiting list for the 9th August session should there be a cancellation. See how I feel at the next one. I had hoped to have a ‘euphoric’ feeling but not to be. Love and virtual hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi there ladies Just returned to the website and thought I should update you. Well I'm still here.  Have been on the Anastrozole since 31 Oct .  Correction to first blog - it is only one tumour not three.  Dimensions were 13 x 7 x 21mm.  In April 2013 they measured 7 x 5 x 6mm - reduced from taking the Anastrozole? and I put a question mark here because as you are aware from the thread I have been trying other ways in which to try to deal with the cancer.  Lymph nodes still clear from US's done. This tumour is now under 1cm all round.  I had a further US 2 weeks ago and will be going back to the consultant on 1 August for those results.  US technician seemed to think it was almost the same (I am hoping there has been a further reduction if only a small one!).  I hope her comment was less than the truth!!!!! I did get my second opinion and am now under that consultant.  I am very happy that he chose to continue with my lead - more than likely he hoped I would be changing my mind!!!!  I did state that I hadn't totally discounted surgery but I did think that taking away 6cm of breast tissue was a little excessive (only 0.27mm short of the size of a tennis ball - if its a ball size lump they will take away) from the initial measurements first taken last year.  I wasn't enamoured of my first oncologist.  We had no rapport or understanding of each other - possibly going mob-handed with two sisters in tow could have unnerved her!! Strangely, with all the other complementary therapies I am taking I am feeling extremely well.  I have no side-effects from the Anastozole, have only had one or two headaches, I have no indigestion at all which was driving me mad, a radical change of diet and with the good news of the reduction in tumour size I also have a positive outlook.  I do hope this is not the calm before the storm....... But everything is still noted in my head and I will report back to you all after my meeting with the consultant on Thursday. In the meantime I have been reading up on blogs since last November when I first wrote and I commiserate with, and support all the ladies who have been given the devastating BC diagnosis.  I do urge you to do the research and ASK LOADS OF QUESTIONS.  I have a long list (still) for Thursday. Love to every one of you
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi dealite Received my copy of Dr Susan Love's Breast Book.  Many many thanks for recommending.  I've started it and can't put it down but need to get some sleep now.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi there fellow sisters Just a short update.  Signed the cyberknife petition (from a posting on this site/group) but lots more names required!  Was told of a conference happening this weekend 17/18 Nov in Totnes (www.totnescancercare.org - if you want to look it up).  Not sure yet if I'll go but looks interesting.  Still waiting for 2nd opinion but I have been told that the wheels are turning.  Still following healthy lifestyle change which is reaping benefits on my weight.  Still positive.  Additionally onc has written to my doc advising of endocrine treatment (Anastozole) and that they will see me again in 2 month's time (after 2nd opinion, etc.) Additionally, can any ladies advise me if they have ever had flutterings/grumblings in the boobs from Anastozole?
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone Thanks Dreamthief for making me laugh at your comments and to all others for their comments. Had my MRI on Sunday 29 December at 6pm at a mobile MRI unit - YES on a Sunday.  Laid on my back this time rather than on the stomach for breast MRIs!  Go back to get results from the Bone Consultant on 9 January. Additionally have my check up with Breast Cancer Consultant same day.  Will advise the Breast Cancer Care Nurse before then of this additional bit of news and ask if they want to do any more tests before we meet.  Need to be updated anyway on the ultrasound I had done on 4 October 2013...... Health still good.  Constantly, it seems, I keep trying to 'feel' the tumour.  Sometimes I think I can but other times not.  Could I even be feeling the titanium clip they have put in??????  Will get back to you after the consults Still fighting this nasty little critter......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies Petina - I got my histology copy on the tumour when I was organising the surgery (which I didn't go for in the end).  I asked for a copy and was given it.  All the other bits I have paid for.  One hospital was £50 and the current one is £20 for the block of scans each time.  They burn them to a disk and send to my home.  At the moment I am awaiting the reports which are from a different department and will get a letter telling me how much.  Should only be a couple of pounds and to me this is well worth the money.  I feel the more I understand the more I can be involved in my own treatment IF I should choose to go down the conventional route but this will only come after trying the Photodynamic Therapy.  I am hoping that the 2nd or 3rd trial at my hospital, and I fit the criteria, will not contain the necessity of lopping off the boob after treatment.  It takes time though to go through these trials, and money of course.  I do have a private clinic in reserve that does the Sono Photodynamic Therapy. MaryQ - good for you on your decision to not have radiotherapy.  This is a choice that all women have to make.  Some will have it, some will not.  Those decisions will be based on what knowledge they have gained and how this treatment could affect them.  I think we are rapidly coming to a time when most women want to know what the hell is going on.  I know my surgeon/oncologist on consultation days has an enormously busy day ahead of him.  I plan all of the questions I want to ask but try not to overstay my welcome.  I can find more information on it from the internet.  I asked if they would continue to monitor me and they agreed.  You can be sure that if anything changes considerably I will be taking action.  Just not prepared for the slash, bash and burn approach which has been extolled for decades and decades and which I believe to be outdated otherwise why would so many new potential treatments be undergoing research with some excellent initial results in the labs! I'm not brave just not ready to take the first thing that's offered... Love and hugs to everyone ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies  Back to give you an update. Had the results from bone guy on 9 January and MRI confirms X-ray.  He’s not recommending any treatment but suggested I did some swimming as exercise rather than the light jogging I was intending to do.  He wants me to build up my muscles!!!!  Also had the results of 4 October 2013 US the same day at my other hospital.  They say that ‘it’ has increased from 11mm to 12mm - pardon!!!!!!  I didn’t even know it had increased to 11mm!!!!!   So I decided to check the reports and digital pictures (I paid for these) plus the copy letters to my GP and I can’t find this measurement anywhere!!  Previous US was on 18 July 2013 where the supposed 11mm has come from but I was told verbally and in a letter to my GP that the tumour was 5x5x7mm!!  On the 4th October US, verbally heard the radiologist (I think he was head radiologist - previous US were done by a very nice lady) said, whilst dictating, 12mm so there could be some correlation to the new measurement but I would have thought they would have told me it had grown, substantially, but they didn’t!  OR, are they be referring to the micro-calcifications which they said was 18x5mm on the 18 July 2013 at the 7-9 o’clock position - but they didn’t.  It was the Registrar at the appointment on the 9th who advised me of this new measurement not the consultant/oncologist.  Now that I have checked all my records will have to give them a ring to get this inconsistency resolved.  Have been naughty with my diet and have eaten far too much red meat!  Stopped that now and plumping for the vegetables and fruit.  Can have fresh fish and free-range chicken.  Drink only green tea with honey in.  Do have an occasional ‘drink’ but may be exaggerating if I said I only have 1 glass a fortnight.  Still healthy (except for the BC) other than a ‘catarrhy’ chest - always get this in winter.  My thoughts are with you all  still dealing with this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi toxophilite Would love a hug.  Absolutely adore cats.  Visiting cat called Lola on my bed as I write this - obviously asleep but at least I have company.  Dinner being served as I write by lodger who is a member of the family so will have to disappear for half an hour. Lover to everyone as ever
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi DEM Thank you so much for your input.  Here's where research is providing you with the necessary information to question their choice of a treatment.  We all hope that whatever treatment is chosen for us will do the trick BUT we should also be told the risks and long term side effect.  From your discussion I assume you are not in the UK so continue researching so it gives you potential questions to ask on their choice of treatment, possibly even coming up with something yourself.  I've looked up your two chemo items.  Sheesh!!!! - and people think I'm somewhat 'du lally' for not undergoing the standard treatment! I will very very interested in your reply when you report back after your meeting with the consultant and oncologist on 3 March. Wishing you all the very best, from someone ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Dear All Well hello there ladies.  Due for my 6 month check up with surgeon/oncologist on 18 June.  Want to have an US beforehand due to a bit of an 'ache' in my right boob which I think is from my titanium clip from when I still try to 'cop a feel' of the tumour so will be ringing the hospital soon to set that up.  But just wanted to tell you a little story. Received in the post a Breast Cancer Screening letter for an appointment 21 May.  As you are aware I haven't had the conventional treatment but am on the endocrine therapy - still.  Now I didn't expect this appointment as I thought as I was still under hospital care!  I meant to ring the screening people to cancel and tell them this but they actually rang me on the day.  Seems that the mamm machine had broken down.  They couldn't take my cancellation over the phone and said they would be sending me another appointment letter!!  I can then return it to say no. Seems one hand doesn't know what the other one is doing!!!  Anyone else getting screening letters 3 years down the line? ...... still fighting this nasty little critter ....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello Ladies Wow....  I was so nervous when getting into the site that I really thought that my posts would have been pulled.  When I found it still there I was even more nervous of what some posts might say.  I really shouldn't have worried.  You are lovely people and totally well aware of the disease and what it can mean to all women (and men) fighting it.  I'm just, for the moment (or 21 months!), taking another route.  The consultant did say that there had been cases of resolved cancers through the endocrine therapy.  He knows of 2 such cases so this is not an impossible result even though the number is low. I will write again once I have the written report on the mammogram taken on 8 May. Still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Well, I had my check and all is okay.  Will be having a US in two weeks time to check on the boob.  I can then get a copy for my records.  Right boob is aching a little at the moment from the breast check.  Left is fine and dandy!  Must be the titanium clip?  Consultant also checked under both arms and for the first time he checked (I think) my ovaries.  All good. In talking with him I learnt that as I still get the hot flushes the Anastrozole is working!  Now I didn't know that!!!!!!! On the Photodynamic trial front - sorry news - only 10 ladies have signed up when they need 30 for the first part.  However the consultant is trying to get the trial re-configured so that ladies with DCIS type cancer can be brought on board who would only require a lumpectomy afterwards but this is proving very difficult.  Probably NICE being absolute berks! Other than that I am a happy bunny! .... still fighting this nasty little critter......
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Had a blood test last week, ostensibly for cholesterol check, and 3 of the 'enzyme' tests have come back 'elevated'. White blood count above range at 11.2 (normal range is between 4.0-11.0) Not too worried about this as I take it to mean my immune system is 'working hard' unless it has something to do with the other elevated results! Serum triglyceride levels above range at 2.26 (normal range is between 0.0-1.8) Alkaline phosphatase level above range at 194 (normal range is between 30-130) GP talked about this last one as it is to do with the liver!  Yikes!!!  Have I got some metasteses!!!  Or could it be down to my being an extremely naughty girl by not sticking to my healthy diet.  I own up to the fact that I haven't eaten many greens or fruit lately and have plumped for eating red meat!  Now that I know I can make the adjustments and get back on track. The middle 'above range' one is to do with the cholesterol although the reading that came back for that was 4.0 which is good, I think.  However I have been eating some chips lately so will knock them completely on the head. Go for another blood test on 9 September so have some time to work on the 'levels'. .... still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Heather - in trying to find out why doctors prescribe either Anastrozole or Letrozole I came across a paper in the British Journal of Cancer.  Simply, Letrozole works 99% effectively on eostrodiols, etc (suppressing these 'enzymes' slows/kills off cancer cells) whilst Anastrozole is only 90% - hence the difference in side effects between the two, possibly.  It also says that the doctors choose which inhibitor a patient has - possibly based on the 'aggressiveness' of the cancer in the patient OR just what they describe.  It is also possible that as you were 'contemplating' surgery at the time that this would have significantly reduced the tumour to ensure only a small lumpectomy would be needed.  You don't say if you are also having the Sentinel Node excision which seems, always, to accompany the lumpectomy.  As to the radiotherapy the decision will be yours. In researching what inhibitor we are prescribed I came across Triazole which is an anti-fungal drug.  I think our aromatase inhibitors stem from this and gives a little credence that possibly some cancers or cancer stems from a fungus (which one doctor I read about seems to think that is what cancer is) which may have triggered cancer cells to form.  With time I imagine more research will actually identify why cancers are formed.  In the meantime making sure you eat the right foods (or supplementing - with resveratrol and other items) will help to keep your immune system actively working for you as well as being physically active. Lulubel - when I read of your recurrence being egg-sized I actually said Yeowww.  Bl***y h*ll !!!  So sorry to hear of this.  I checked up on your Salvestrols and as you are aware these are a big part of my regimen.  I am now having fresh strawberries, raspberries and blueberries on top of my 50% fruit muesli.  Along with the unsweetened almond milk its a really good breakfast.  Someone said that eating fruit for breakfast was the best time as it won't be sitting on top of previously eaten food and so not 'ferment' in the stomach - although I do still eat fruit during the day!  Love my greens as well which also provide the salvestrols. Heather says to get a second opinion and I think this is right if your surgeon will not commit to a double mastectomy.  It's so logical to only have one operation but I note that you say it takes 10 hours to do a mastectomy for only one breast!  It actually only takes between 2-3 hours but will take longer if having reconstruction.  When reading up on the mastectomy surgery it is critical that you have a good support network following surgery if you go down this line.  Arm movement will be severely compromised thus limiting your ability to care for yourself.  With only one mastectomy at least you would have one arm free to do things.  Another lady on this site wanted to have a double as well.  She decided to only have only the one boob off in the end as the other was still healthy.  BUT as you know I am a lady who believes in the individuals' right to make their own decision on their health care and will go with your 'flow'. My love and positive vibes to both of you. .... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hi Optimistic Allred score is ER 8 and PR 8. Anastrozole did work for 4 years but tumour began to grow so went on Letrozole which did absolutely nothing.

Posts.Content: Hiya Ladies Had my ultrasound yesterday.  Young lass said 'can't see much change' but wouldn't commit to saying whether it has grown or reduced!!!  Later on will order the US scans and add to my records as well as having a good old look.  .... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Well had my blood test to see if any problems are occurring with my new treatment– all came back okay. Had a number of questions as well. I wanted to know where my 2 affected lymph nodes are physically located and the computer records just do not show it! Unbelievable or what!!! They quote them so often to me yet can’t identify WHERE they are. As a result I am having an US again and this time I will ensure they tell me where they are.  Just awaiting the appointment letter. This all came about as I have a ‘lump’ (but lessening now) right in the crease of my right armpit. I think this had been a cyst which got infected (as it had oozed pus) but ironically has left a hard ‘bit’. I just wanted to be reassured that my assumption was the case. They couldn’t answer. They did have a look though and it is somewhat smaller than yesterday. On Tuesday I had to attend a funeral and what with all the ‘chatting’ that went on after the committal, before the wake, I ended up with a bit of an ache in my back on the Wednesday. They were more interested in this probably surmising that I could have metastatic bone cancer. But I told them no (I do know my body) and they have asked that I keep an eye on it. They did touch me in a certain area but no pain came as a result. As I write it is resolving itself. Hat’s off to them for their concern though. So I have another appointment on 1 November at 11.45am with another blood test. I will report back after that. For the first month of this treatment they see you every 2 weeks. After that it would be in a month. I think after that it is every 3 months but as you know we are not always told everything up front. Sigh……..
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Had my US on the gallbladder on Thursday 5th Feb.  His opinion, initially, is that it is a gallstone!  Forgot to ask for a measurement but will get that from GP when report sent to her.  Will follow that by getting copies of US and report for my records. Have absolutely no pain whatsoever so it's obviously not giving me any problems - for now!  I wonder if you can use shock wave treatment on these?  All I have read is to have an op (if it starts to cause problems) but then I am running away with myself.  Let's wait and see what the GP says. Fleetingly, somehow, conversation touched on my BC and he (the radiologist) was astonished that I hadn't gone for surgery but didn't comment further, thank heavens!  Was unprepared for this negativity but I've passed it off now. ... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies Results confirmed from GP on US on gallbladder shows a gallstone so nothing sinister and no need for an op as I haven't got any pain from it. Going for my second thermogram today.  Will get the lady to bring the latest one up alongside my last one and have a look see at vascularity activity.  Will come back later today with my thoughts on it. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All So, update on the eye stroke.  Doc pleased that some sight returned.  Covering my good eye he started waving his fingers at various points in front of me whilst I looked straight at him so he could check peripheral and central vision.  Also said that they just do not know WHY this happened.  I am therefore going to be put on a heart monitor for a week.  Just waiting for an appointment for fitment.  They think that the 24hr one was not long enough.  YET all tests on the heart including the echocardiogram were fine.  Unsure if I will be able to shower/bathe!!! but no doubt will be advised when it is fitted.  Don't want to go around smelly!?@!  Had a blood pressure monitor once fitted for a day.  Believe it or not it didn't wake me up at night but then when I fall asleep I never hear anything!!!!!! Great explanation for the Everolimus as I had since found out that it was an immunosuppressant! which didn't make sense. (Everolimus works by interfering with the action of certain enzymes in your body called mTOR kinases. These enzymes help both healthy cells and cancer cells to grow and multiply. When kinases don’t act normally, they make cancers and tumours grow out of control. Everolimus inhibits mTOR kinases and stops the tumour or cancer from growing. This prevents the spread of the cancer or tumour in your body. Love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Started re-taking the exemestane and everolimus on 29 November. Not taking the Lemon Mucilage as I haven’t been experiencing the mouth ulcers they seem to think is the most common side effect. I do however still keep taking my Corsodyl mouthwash and mouth is doing fine. Hives on arms resolved and sores/dry skin on hands also. Feet still peeling but no new hard skin forming. Dosage – exemestane 1 x 25mg tablet daily, everolimus – 1 x 5mg tablet every 2 days. Experiencing prickling and itching in the hands but dealing with this with hand cream and when the itching is maddening – Lanacane. Oncologist appointment on Wednesday 6 December. 2 out of the 4 doctors did not turn up! Had to wait 3 and half hours to see the consultant. My appointment was for 12.15pm and I didn’t get in until 3.40pm! Still got a cough so asked if I could have a CT scan to rule out lung lesions. Would have been nice if she had readily agreed but I had to insist just to make sure. Awaiting an appointment to come through the door. I am to continue with the above dosage until next appointment which is on 3 January 2018 due to the side effects I have experienced. Overall we were in or near the hospital for 8 hours!!!! Ordered the reports from the blood tests taken and will order copies of outstanding scans once I have had the ultrasound on 9 January 2018. Now have in place my heart monitor which I wear all the time except when I take a shower. The plaster/ed contacts to the monitor give me the itch! Wonder what is recorded when I scratch them!!!! This comes off on Wednesday (13th) when I have to take it back for the data to be downloaded. Other than the above I am truly okay. If I don’t come back before then I wish everyone a wonderful Christmas and a very Merry New Year.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Marlog - Invasive Ductal Carcinoma in Situ is DCIS that has broken out of the duct before being spotted.  If it is contained within the duct I assume this has a slightly better outcome as it should be easier to get out with surgery. From what I can gather RFA can be placed into all tumours at the same time so if you have 2 or 3 or however many they will treat them all in one go.  By chance I did see that my hospital does have RFA but not for breast cancer.  A question I will pose to the consultant tomorrow.  It may need clearance from NICE for it to be performed on the breast. I forgot to say in my last piece that I may be put onto Letrozole as it could be that the Anastrozole may not be working any longer.  I'll give Letrozole a try and see how I do given the increased side effects I have read that this brings. Many thanks to all others who have posted.  It is always nice to have someone comment back.  You don't feel alone when things turn an unexpected corner despite having  sister/s who makes the time to come along with me for every consultation. Here's hoping for the best tomorrow ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi DEM Left you a private message for you to read.  Just wanted to say on this discussion that I hope you are still okay from your Herceptin injection.  Sometimes we do get ourselves so het up about a treatment by reading up on it that it can affect our perceptions.  The relief that it's not that bad is monumental.  I had that when they did a CT scan for my bone and putting in radioactive stuff.  I grilled them mercilessly about it.  Having been told that it has a half 'shelf' life of 6 hours, the next 6 hours another half 'shelf' life and so on, it was going to be 'out of me' within 24 to 48 hours but it did screw with my head, I tell you!  AND all this radioactive stuff goes into the sewerage system which is then treated to return back as drinking water.  O Oh!!! I also think we have to be truly compus mentis when having treatment - as you have found out yourself.  Not found any evidence to the contrary but I wonder how many wrong boobies have been operated on.... Talk soon - stay well - keep your wits about you - love and hugs ... still fighting this nasty little critter
