Posts.Content: Hi All Further reading on this treatment was approved by NICE 21 December 2016 - question answered.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hello everyone Hopefully, just a short note.  I have had to stop both the Everolimus and Exemestane.  My hands just could not take it any more.  They were peeling and had hard skin which broke out into sores.  No matter what I did they just weren't resolving.  The only constant was Exemestane so stopped them both and told onco nurse that I would be stopping these for two weeks until all healed. She was supposed to get back after speaking to the oncologist but didn't.  I stopped taking them from Monday 10th November.  In some areas I use the Eumovate when I get an itch, other parts of the hands I use O'Keefe's Working Hands which does seem to keep them moisturised.  The 'sores' in my palms just need to heal over now.  Still have a lot of rough areas where peeling still trying to resolve.  Due to start taking these tabs again on Wednesday 24 Nov. I think Have also had to deal with an ear infection.  The pain was quite bad.  Got 2 lots of antibiotics from GP both for the ear and a chest cough from a cold which just would not clear and what followed taking them were bouts of the trots.  What more can happen to me!!!!!  One antibiotic was for 5 days and I took the last one yesterday (Sunday).  I still have to take the other for another 2 days.  The ear pain has gone and up to yesterday (Sunday) I still had some loss of hearing but I can hear fine now.  Unsure if these problems are related to Exemestane or Everolimus - there is nothing in the side effects list for these. Winterwolfsoul - these drugs are not chemo but you have made me think that they could be 'akin' to chemotherapy although called an mTOR kinase inhibitor. annieYour username - missed registering and the webinar link you kindly gave.  Did you watch/participate? Sadly, we seem to have lost Salamandar65 from this website.  I do wish her well as I do for everyone on this site.  Take care
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Don't know where the link sent me to but even your humble Vit D and C have contra-indications.  Don't think it's worthwhile!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Everyone A very Happy New Year to you all. So, I have had my CT scan on the 2 January and the appointment with the Oncologist on 3 January (yesterday). CT scan for thoracic, abdomen and pelvis CLEAR for anything wrong with my lungs with regards to the cough I have or anywhere else except for the known tumours and the suspect lymph nodes. Oncologist did comment on them having increased - as from the last CT scan in July 2016 - but we already knew this.  Anyway, really happy that nothing wrong with lungs or growing anywhere else. So GOOD NEWS. Asked if we were increasing the Everolimus dosage today? Together we decided to wait on the Ultrasound on the 9 January to see if the new medications are doing their job – at this dosage or not – then we will decide together if an increase is needed or whether I am just ‘stable’. Once again, one oncologist did not turn up on the day so we had a bit of a wait. I think I waited at least an hour but since I fell asleep whilst waiting (in the care of my sister who accompanied me again) it didn’t really affect me!!!!!! Having given blood on arrival at about 10am, which was a bit of a palaver as I wasn’t booked in for a blood test, both my sister and I went to have a vegetarian breakfast and I am afraid with a good meal inside me I just needed to have a nap whilst we waited! Still getting some minimal skin issues on my hands, arms and legs but the Eumovate dealing with them. However, on Sunday the nipple on my LEFT breast had gone red. Worrying. Used the Eumovate and most of the redness has resolved although the nipple was still swollen and a bit ‘perkier’ than normal. Showed it to Oncologist and she is not concerned but we will still keep an eye on it for any change and will make an urgent appointment if any change happens here. A good day today – HELL YES. So keep on fighting ladies – as I am. Love as ever
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Winterwolfsoul Go to Holland and Barrett for some of my supplements so have written this down as something I need to get. Many thanks for this.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Thanks for the input. More research I have had to do to explain. From what I can gather good levels of sodium sulfate (USA) or sulphate (UK) (so it’s basically a salt, I think) are in the following foods: spinach, silverbeet, swiss chard, cabbage, cauliflower, cucumber, celery, pumpkin, onion, apples and strawberries – the ones italicised are the ones I eat. These are what I need to cut down on. The sodium sulfate/sulphate also comes up as a drying agent in detergent and paper pulping!!!!!! Clearly there is a demarcation between being in natural foods and the manufactured stuff but under the same name! I probably need a chemist to make some sense here. With regard to the K2 I will have to buy it. Clearly not enough K2 is in the Chlorella or Spirulina I take. Looked at the breadmaking. Bit of a chore but I will try it without the salt. Richmond, Middx, has a wholefoods store so will try picking up organic from there.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Undertook, when passing a chemist, to have a Food Intolerance Screening done with sample from your hair - £59.  Report has just come back. 2 important nutritional items are low - mineral Calcium (despite food and supplementation from Calcichew tablets), and - Vitamin C (despite 3 weeks of liquid supplementation before but still continuing - but then I think it depends on which part of the hair they sampled) Have also been sent a list of foods that are Calcium-rich and will undertake to incorporate these into my diet. Also advised to cut down on sodium sulfate foods. For the first page and a bit on the second there are foods I should stop altogether of which there are only 4 out of the list of 12 I am eating.  I may need to put the ones I don't eat onto Google to see if there are any other foods that I eat, in that genus, I need to stop. The next is a list of foods showing 'stressed' in my sensitivity list which I have to cut back on or at the very best to stop altogether. Out of a list of 18 items I am only eating/drinking 6 – 1 is sodium sulfate (as referred to above) and another, food additives (probably in the bread). Will look at my diet again with a view to amending and getting my nutrients balanced and my body stress free from things that it doesn’t like – more research! The lady said that my test was interesting and she wants me to do another FOC in 6 weeks’ time.  Something free for once. She loved that I didn't eat Mackerel and no dairy, that I was taking a supplement of 8000iu Vit D per day. I owned up to eating some cheese but I will knock this on the head and very likely has the bad sodium and additives added to it!  Blood results from oncologist do show high levels of sodium, 146mmol/L as opposed to the highest level in the range of 145mmol/L, so I am 1 point over the upper limit. However these levels have been almost consistent since I have had blood tests done. Will see what the ‘tweaking’ achieves for my next blood test. Will let you know results in 6 weeks time. Love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28 and Winterwolfsoul [edited by admin] Also taking the Liposomal Vit. C.  Practitioner recommended Acerola Cherry Powder so I got Viridian from Revital which I am using on alternate days alongside the Allergy Research Group Micro Liposomal Vit C, liquid, 5ml.  Just realised that I haven't been taking enough of the Acerola on those alternate days.  Only been taking 1/4 teaspoon which equals 180mg so will up this to match the liquid intake.  Did notice the chemical element of this as Sodium Ascorbate but since I was taking this before the blood test of 3 January (for oncology) which only heightened this level by 1 point I am not too concerned - I think. Put into the mix the stopping of the Magnesium and I may see a fall in Sodium intake. Also bought some Lipolife Vit C online – keeping that in stock until the Allergy one runs out. Servings Allergy Research Group Liposomal Vit C, 5ml = 1000mg (1250%) Viridian Acerola Cherry Powder, 1/4 teaspoon = 1 gram (180mg) (to up this to 7 x quarter teaspoons = 1080mg) Lipolife, 5ml = 1000mg (1250%) – get a measuring cup with this one! Practitioner also suggested foregoing my bought Orange Juice although it does state 100% OJ.  Instead squeeze 1 (one) orange a day.  So finishing off the bought OJ and already bought 4 oranges!  Love my OJ in the morning. Therefore experiment ongoing! Take care ladies
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Ladies and Gents What a week I have had!!!! So where do I start. It’s a long post so get ready! Food Intolerance – started to have cramp in my legs during the night which wake me up! Decided to go back on the Magnesium so started today. Try to find another source to my high Sodium levels to cut. Oncologist appointment – saw her (one of three I have seen so far of which this one I am not especially enamoured of) and advises bloods are okay. Unfortunately for me I have had a ‘bug’ that has been going around and the Tuesday before the Wednesday appointment had spent most of my time asleep!!!!!! Must have spent 20 hours asleep that day and I did have a temperature. Feel tons better today. I hadn’t printed off my summary of past blood tests to ask questions about some high and borderline levels and just could not think right. So I had to pass that over for the next time. She advised that my lymph nodes had grown and they wanted to do surgery. No I said and put forward a list of other treatments being used in the NHS that I would consider giving my preference to which ones I would like to be considered first. Ooops, wrong thing to do. She was clearly affronted by this but said she would take it to the team. Anyway I advised that I also had a swollen armpit and it was causing pain. Obviously inflammation, at least in my opinion, and could have been caused by this ‘bug’. She did look at it. So we agreed to stop the Everolimus for a week but I may stop this for longer. I am also suffering from numbness mainly in my arms and legs and looking at the side effects of both Exemestane and Everolimus it is the Exemestane which has this side effect. I have decided to stop this temporarily as well to see if that resolves too.   Skin issues still ongoing but will be resolved by stopping the drugs. What the oncologist failed to advise me during our session was that the ultrasound on 9 Jan advised that the original tumour was now 7x3mm nor that one of the supposed ‘affected’ 4 lymph nodes had just ‘disappeared’ from the radiologists report? This had been a very comprehensive US that had gone over the whole of my breast and axilla at every o’clock position to create 40 images. Once again sleeping most of day before I had failed to bring that summary as well. I did remember that the CT scan reported that I had an ‘umbilical hernia’ but I hadn’t been told about this. She advised that it was so small that it was nothing to worry about. I replied that I thought it was something that they should have advised me about as it is my body and at the very least I would be aware of it. If I didn’t get copies of the scans with the reports I would never, ever have known about it!!! Is this something, you say, I should worry about in the context of already having BC? I think it is a part of the ‘whole’ so of course it is important. This CT report also said ‘no internal mammary adenopathy seen’!!!!!! In defence of this statement, when I lie down on my back my boobs disappear, as most likely yours do, so it was probably not able to be seen by the CT!  But I feel it should have ‘found’ something. The US report also identified the other ‘area of concern’ which had ‘increased’ from 7x12x7mm to 7x14mm. Oncologist never mentioned this AT ALL. Good lord! And you wonder why I am forever asking questions! This ‘lump’ I can feel and in my estimation it has reduced significantly. From my early beginnings of taking these drugs and having to stop because of the hives and the severe distress they caused me this is the longest period I have taken these drugs consecutively even at the reduced level to allow them to do their work and living with the consequences of their action on my body. I so want this to work. My sister who had accompanied me, bless her, thought that stopping the Everolimus meant ‘curtains’ for me until the oncologist came back saying no. It’s only temporary and there is another drug that could be used but that she didn’t ‘think’ that it would be beneficial, requiring an injection every so often – Fulvestrant. Little snippets you just keep picking up…….. So the ‘bug’ is clearing out of my system. The armpit is resolving. I’ve stopped the drugs for the moment and hope to start to feel normal again shortly. My one known breast tumour has shrunk. The other, I think, is reducing. I’ve ‘lost’ a potentially infected lymph node. I have no mets anywhere else (but who really knows). Am awaiting feedback on potentially a different treatment for BC. Watched a documentary on The Truth about Vaccines (based on USA medical establishmentaria). One lady was questioning the doctor about them and he simply turned around and said that if she didn’t agree to the vaccines for her child then she was ‘fired’ from the doctor’s practice!!!!! When she saw another doctor for her child he simply said 'be thankful'.  Could this be my cue for walking! Let’s wait and see. As always my love and virtual hugs to everyone on this journey.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi all you wonderful ladies (and gents) Haven’t written on my thread for the longest time but have been encouraged to do so. This will be in 2 separate posts. At the last count you will recall that I was having a ‘bit of difficulty’ with my NHS team.  It wasn’t augering well.  I made a decision to try to ‘work’ with them but still keeping a step back from undertaking any surgery procedure they still wanted to do.  Since then I am currently on a break from the Everolimus only (due to side effects) but still on the Exemestane which, by the way, both have some of the same side effects.  I could just as easily be suffering those side effects from the Exemestane!!!!!!!  Anybody else see the problem here!  The side effects HAVE lessened but with both giving some of the same they are not totally eradicated.  However, I am carrying on with the Exemestane as I have consistently been on one endocrine therapy or another since my diagnosis in 2012. My next oncology meeting is on the 4 July.  In the meantime, I have had a DEXX Scan 19 June.  An Ultrasound is earmarked for 27 June, a Mammogramme, for 28 June and an MRI of which I am awaiting the appointment letter.  At the latest consultation, the oncologist wanted to exchange the Ultrasound for the MRI around the same time-frame to which I agreed but Ohhhhh the Gadolinium they want to use.  So in their cause I have agreed as its basically a re-staging that’s being done.  You will learn why in the following posting.  However their system still says that the ultrasound is still booked.  I found this out when trying to get a date for the MRI!!!!!  In the meantime had a call back from my oncology nurse who is going to sort out the appointments as I haven’t had much success with the appointment people.  She said she would ring me Thursday but has failed to do so, so far.  Also received a letter from the radiology appointment people asking my status, ie date of last period, pre-menopausal, menopausal or postmenopausal???????  Sheesh, all this is on my records.  Waited on the appointment phone line for 15 minutes yesterday with no success so gave up on that one.  Will try again today though just to see if anything has been sorted. Love and hugs to everyone on this journey
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Where to start! Firstly right boobie is a bit mis-shapen – still. Have undergone a battery of tests by my hospital as a result of my SPDT treatment. They think that the Exemestane and Everolimus not working! Still under the impression I have cancer as they had had the results of the Mamm and MRI back. However they also wanted to do more tests – CT Thoracic abdomen pelvis (for metasteses), ultrasound biopsies of the tumour and structure of interest (I call it my ‘area of concern’) and an NM Bone Scan (report of this has come back negative for bone mets). These all now done and just waiting for the reports on the CT and biopsies. Appointment with oncology 1 August for their new diagnosis!! Was supposed to have it 25 July but they didn’t think the results of the biopsies (they took a few) would be back in time and certainly when ringing records Tuesday (24th) these results are not on the system. I also requested the pathology report on a FNA done 2 July 2016 and this is not on her system so the clerk is having to chase these with pathology for me. So the 1 August – 2 days before my birthday – will be my birthday present!!!!!! Could it be a black or red letter day!!! I am hoping for the latter. Keep fighting people,
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Carolyn28 Went onto your astrology – food for good health – site and think I have just had a EUREKA! moment. Magnesium is cell salt it says – I take the supplement Chelated Magnesium. This could be linked to my high Sodium levels. So just taken the decision to stop these 1 a day tablets (today included) until I get my new intolerance test. In the interim my blood test before oncology meeting 31 Jan might give a clue to a reduction in this level before then. By the way, I’m a Leo and the chart is showing a lot of what I eat already. Therefore I may just be overdoing it with the magnesium supplementation. Shall also continue to improve diet - eating a lot of my Rainbow salad. Note your humour. It did make me laugh. Checked out the Thriva web site. Unfortunately the test sample page results just kept re-loading/flickering out of sequence so I couldn’t get to see what it entails. Will try again later. Loads of love
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Further to my last post, I mentioned about some numbness in my arms and legs. It was actually in both my hands and feet but a different numbness had also been encroaching along my left side starting first in the arm then leg, up the thigh, into my bum, up to the waist and towards my armpit and is also on the left side of my scalp. I had tried to google but couldn’t find anything. Rang NHS line 111 to be told to get to GP’s immediately. Saw GP who said I had to go to A+E immediately. One of my long-suffering sisters agreed to take me. We went to Kingston Hospital because I am under a consultant there for my central retinal artery occlusion (stroke of the eye). I was taken into hospital as everything pointed to a stroke. The emergency room people said that the CT scan showed this. I had seen the stroke consultant as well on the Wednesday who was adamant that this was not a stroke and passed me over to see a neurologist. They sent me for an MRI and asked me to get my stroke consultant look over the MRI scan. So by chance, it was during my follow up appointment today (Thursday) that my stroke consultant brought up the MRI (or CT) scans (can’t tell which is which from the pictures) where he saw the ‘infarct’. Seems there is something called a lacunar infarct, in my case in the thalamic area, are also known as a sensory stroke, which gives the signs of a stroke but can only be numbness. He will discuss the MRI with the neuro-radiologist who he advises is shit hot in translating these. I will get a letter of their findings. I will also be getting a follow up appointment. Now to add the next bit…. They used a contrast called gadolinium which ‘shows’ ‘an edge’ to the ‘infarct’. I only saw a white blob, I guess this is what is known as taking a ‘selective’ view but the inference being that it could be a metastatic BC tumour!!!!!! Therefore the consultant is sending the images to the Royal Free for my oncology and MD team to go over. My next appoint with them is 21 February. I had mentioned some of this numbness to my oncology team but they had put this down to the Everolimus drug which she said to stop for a week. I am now 2 days past the date I should have started……. I am not sure if I should start again but clearly something else may have caused the numbness rather than the drugs OR maybe it is the drugs!!!!!! I am now home after 3 days in hospital. I have/had no other symptoms of a stroke of the brain which include, weakness of limbs, unable to speak clearly which I certainly can, no droopiness of the face or anything else. One thing, though, is that the MRI I had last year with regard to the eye showed no evidence of anything on the brain so this is a bit worrying. However it seems that there will be a lot of discussion about me over the coming weeks. I should have some answer at least on the 21 February if not by letter from my stroke consultant in the interim. It just keeps giving don’t it……
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi people Many thanks for all your kind words. Now on Day 7 including the day of the first infusion cycle. Taste buds are going. Felt generally unwell when I got up and I do not like that. No hair loss, yet. Guts are moving from laxative, thank heavens. THAT has given me more stress than I would have liked. Never been a ‘sicky’ person so may hold off on any further emetics they give me in the future until I do have a reaction. Ondansetron was the culprit for being bunged up when I talked to a nurse from the emergency line. Nearly forgot my 2nd Filgrastim last night! No bone aches yet. Chemo brain!!! Noticed that after the chemo infusion on Friday that I kept nodding off whilst I waited for the MRI. Maybe one of my reactions to chemo is that I go to sleep! Certainly I tend to nod off after the evening meal whilst watching TV but been doing that for a long time. Now at 1.30pm I am coming round the mountain. Feeling much better than this morning. There is light at the end of the tunnel. Will do some walking, might just kick start the energy back. Ali owl – blimey, 12 x weekly paclitaxel infusions. That’s a lot and I thought that my schedule later on for having 4 x 2-weekly was bad. It’s the word ‘taxol’ that gets to us and we fear its consequences. Hope you are doing okay on this. Love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi people Been a long time in getting back to you all. I have had issues and disappointment. The SPDT has not worked on the tumour/s, in my case. In fact they have GROWN from the biopsies that were done. THAT I truly believe and has been borne out by other medics I have been seeing. It was just that I wanted to know WHAT was going on in the lumps when I undertook all the re-scanning and biopsies as I wasn’t getting any proper answers anywhere! The ‘interference’ from the biopsies very likely broke into some form of encapsulation around the tumour/s causing them to grow outwards out of the ‘bulge’ I told you about. As you know one of the lesions is TNBC which, obviously, is a bit more of a ‘stinker’. The RGCC Breast Cancer test I had done on 6 September 2018 did come back good however. Back in April the circulating tumour cell count in my body was 4.0. It is now 2.5, a reduction, which is GOOD despite all the interference. The one GOOD thing I can hold onto about this treatment. The private clinic had been receiving all the test results from the NHS I had had done and when I went to see them they stated that I needed to do chemo and surgery. In the mix is possibly radiotherapy but we are a long way from that. The clinic COULD have said try another SPDT therapy, but did not, so not all private clinics are only in it for the money! It was clear to them from the scans that I needed to do something else. When, from 2 corners, it is advocated that you do something then I think you just have to resign yourself to do it. I SO wanted to save my body from the chemo and surgery. As a result I am undergoing chemo – EC-T (Paclitaxel). Had the first chemo of EC on 21 September 2018. 3 x EC every 3 weeks to come followed by Paclitaxel - 4 cycles every 2 weeks. Tried the cold cap but that is just so awful. Brain was freezing, probably the skin on the head too but it just felt ‘oppressive’ to me. Not good. Got 3 types of anti-emetic, 1 steroid and the Filgrastim (GCS-F). Anti-emetics have bunged me up!!! Now need a light laxative to get rid of. The ‘gifts’ just keep coming don’t they. Now I feel, after the first chemo dose, in limbo. Just got no approx. timelines of when I should feel the side effects or what from the chemo! I need to know. Found on some discussion that hair loss could happen in 13 or 17 days. At least I have that to go by. But will I lose my hair? Would I be one of the lucky ones who only has thinning hair? I consider myself an average person so think I will lose it. Have researched the headscarves and wigs already – just not got them yet – in case! Felt a bit ‘wabbit’ this morning but that has gone off. No aches or pain in the joints and muscles, no other side effects that I can feel. So I ask myself is that good! Or is this chemo accumulative so that you then have the known side effects as you go on? Yes, everyone is an individual I know and this can’t really be gauged. Must read all of the Chemo thread/s for more information on patient response on this type of treatment. That is, after all, just what we all want to know – just what other things we can expect to experience as it is killing the cancer! Curiously, you will note that I am not getting the 5-F, Fluorourcil. Asked about that and said that it wouldn’t really help with me, they said, and has loads of other side effects. It is a drug that was discovered in 1957’ish from mustard gas! At least I escaped that one. Still going on with a positive mood, I hope. Boob at one point sort of ‘hurt’ when I laid down in bed, before the chemo started, as the lumps ‘pulled’ on normal breast tissue. This seems to have stopped so maybe there is a reduction in the lumps already! That thinking I am staying with! So that’s it. I am on chemo. It was a hard choice but I made it and will live with it. The rest of the potential treatment will be up for in-depth discussion by me after the chemo. Got to keep them on their toes you know! My love to you all on this journey.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Update. So now I am on Day 12 (including the day of the first chemo injection/s) of EC. Think, overall, I have escaped so much. Nausea/sickness – not had any. Maybe the anti-emetics did their job. Digestive tract – this has been a problem. I got ‘bunged up’. However on the Wednesday (Day 6/15) I did manage to pass some on my own. Chuddy rock hard! Still I passed it naturally. That night I took Sennakot (never before in my life) and in the morning started getting rid of the ‘back up’ which was so much easier to pass. Had rung the chemo nurse that Wednesday for advice and she advised a mild laxative. Only took 1 tablet for 2 nights. Said it was Ondansetron they gave me that caused it. Nice! Belching so much though. Understand that this can come from the Filgrastim injections. Last one of these already done. Taste buds – well these have gone particularly with drinks like my green tea. It tastes like I am drinking liquidised food! Had a Matcha green tea with Mint and it tasted like the MINT SAUCE you put on lamb. Yeuch! Couldn’t finish that one. Coffee seems to be doing okay but still not as I remember. Keep taking the green tea, even now, but not the same. Mouth is really like the back end of a bus! Mouth ulcers – none of these. Taking extra care here and found I did have a plaque on tongue so used the Corsodyl. All clear now. Bone/muscle – no aches or pains in these. However, I did have some painful ‘spasms’ around my lower back. They were worse, coming in waves, when my heart pumped blood around my body! That’s only how I can describe it. This happened Sunday evening (Day 8) and overnight to Monday morning (Day 9). It was so debilitating. I was contemplating getting an ambulance! Took paracetamol, 2 big tablets twice and it didn’t really touch it. On Monday morning tried the Ibuprofen, just 2 tablets, and blow me if it didn’t work! Complete resolution. Also don’t know if going to the loo might have had something to do with it. Could have been ‘pressing’ on a nerve down there. Hair – still got this and not losing any on the pillows in the morning but for how long! Already have numbness on the left side of my body from lacunar infarction. Can’t tell if the numbness in the skin on the skull is because of impending hair loss! Scalp does ‘feel’ different and hair ‘feels’ dry to touch. On Monday tried to arrange to go to a Hair Loss group at the hospital on Wednesday for free scarf and how to deal with hair loss at the hospital.   No answer yet. Health – generally very good. Woke up Wednesday and Thursday feeling a bit weak when I went downstairs. Simply watched TV until I ‘came round the mountain’ as it were. Was determined to get to the Macmillan coffee morning on the Friday and I certainly felt a lot, lot better on that Friday. It does do you good to get out of the house. Temperature – seems to be either just under or over 36oC. Boob – well, I do think that the chemo has ‘softened’ the tumour/s. They’re not as hard. I had been experiencing some grumbles, some to the point of having to adjust my boob as I laid down in bed at night to get comfortable as they were ‘pulling’ on normal breast tissue. Thankfully I now don’t have to adjust my boob to get to sleep! There are still occasional grumbles which make me ‘aware’ but not pain. At one point before chemo I had so much inflammation in the boob I could have very cheerfully gone into hospital and said ‘whip it off’. It hurt that much. Checked the Chemo discussions and got some pointers. Find that I am eating far too much and must put a block on that. I am choosing foods that will give me the taste but they are also loaded with calories. Having done so well on weight loss I am loathe to put it all back on. So, is this it! Is this what I can expect of the rest of the EC cycles! Next cycle due on 12 October. We’ll see how we do then now that I am more ‘armed’ with the side effects of EC on my body. I’m retired – ooooh, how old that makes me feel – and gives me the time to concentrate on myself. I have only absolute admiration for anyone who also has to work during chemo. Give yourselves a great big pat on the back. My love as ever to everyone on this journey, [edited by admin]
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Had my MRI Liver and CT Thorax Abdomen Pelvis scans. Come back with suspicious lesion on the liver so no distorted image here! Also a smaller one more deep seated. Now want me to have a liver biopsy. Yikes – reading up on this and not happy about it - it can cause seeding of cancer and this from the UK British Liver Trust! If anyone has had this can they come back to me on how this went for them? Have watched a video on YouTube on how they do in America which has given me a sense of what is to come. Was a bit ‘alarmed’ that this is a long day procedure and that one of the worst things to happen was that I could have a major bleed from it!! Having said the above you will be aware that I am now taking innohep injections for the blood clot on my lung. No advance preparation mentioned by oncologist on what to do about these like stopping them now or explaining IF this is the right way forward given the risks! They also want to do another Breast MRI to see if there is ANYTHING that the chemo is doing. Awaiting appointments for both of these. Boob was doing well but some new lesions beginning to show – one particularly near the surface. It has red capillaries pushed to the top of the skin and are noticeable. If it gets any bigger it will break through the skin to become a fungating cancer lesion! I am a little alarmed that the medics not paying as much attention to this as with the liver. Did ask about any treatment for this in the interim and the only thing they said was to have some radiotherapy on it. Immediately refused - though I am still thinking about it. Mentioned a few other alternatives in their field like HiFU, Radiofrequency Ablation, Laser but nothing came back from oncologist. KNOW, from research, that Radiofrequency Ablation being used in America on the breast. NHS just so slow on the uptake as with the example of Proton Therapy. Government shamed into getting 2 of these built, 1 in Manchester, now built, and 1 in London, being built, from the time when that young lad was ‘kidnapped’ from a hospital in the UK by his parents and taken to Europe to have it for his brain tumour. Kid is doing really well as a result. We just don’t get enough options from the NHS or maybe it is just this hospital which doesn’t have the options. Will ring other hospitals to see if they do something. Ok, rant over. Otherwise I am in good health if becoming a bit of a ‘pin cushion’ with bruises from the innohep injections, the collapse on my bathroom floor, hair loss, dry hands, 1 bout of diarrhoea – all from this latest cycle of chemo. Lovely! Today, I have had my 3rd chemo cycle anyway. Until the new scan result and biopsy are known it seemed this is the best way forward for the moment. All my love to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Hair Loss group This was a blast. Arrived early, about 10.45am. One lady already there. No-one else expected. Two ladies doing the session. Form filled in. Received a list of items we will be looking at. Two further ladies roped into the session from waiting room – so 4 ladies and 2 hair people. Arranged by Macmillan with a group called HeadWrappers.. A bit cramped in the Macmillan consultation room. On with one of those hairnet things you see actors and actresses put on first below their wigs, for health and safety reasons. When you use your own scarves you wont need this. Cotton is best for staying in place. The first lady had such negativity about colours and the faffing that is required when we started trying to put headscarves on. It didn’t let up either. Still she had a lot to deal with as she has metastatic cancer throughout her body now and with this chemo round she was starting to lose her hair which was causing her a lot of distress. She wasn’t dealing well with the cold cap a few sessions in either. So having tied the basic cotton scarves around our heads with other little scarves acting as ‘foils’ we moved on. One lady was called out of the session for her appointment who had been roped in and never came back, the other lady kept popping out as she felt sick. Did come back one or two times but eventually didn’t come back at all. Only we two original ladies were left. Good we had one-to-one attention. We then proceeded to ready made scarf hats. These would act as a base and we could add things over the top making them different each time. I found these much, much better to get on and off and less of a faff and so did the other lady. These looked like some of the things I had seen on websites. There were also a few hair pieces. One was a fringe that just peeps under the scarf. Another was a ‘half’ wig, shoulder length, dark colour. It had straps over the top of the head and it’s combined with a hat. Other lady really liked this as she still had shoulder length grey hair to start with and with a ‘pre-made’ scarf hat over the top it was very effective. You would not have thought there could have been a bald head under there. Tried this myself and went ‘Chuddy hell!!!’. TWICE!  I looked 20 years younger!!!!! - and back to the time when I did have shoulder length hair. There were further examples of showing us how to enhance the hats/caps, etc. Two and half hours we were there and left with the free chosen cotton headscarf we had used during the session, an accessory and a bit literature which I have yet to fully read. You order the items that looked good on you from the websites these hats had been supplied from. That was the purpose of the list of items we would see and tried on to note the ones that worked for us. They are quite cheap. Had forgotten my mobile. What a time to forget! The session ladies said that when I order the stuff I liked that suited me I should send them a photo so gotta get on the web pages to order BEFORE I lose my hair (if I do). Still keeping positive on that one but also want to be prepared. Does anyone know if this is a new thing? But I do recommend that if you see these sessions advertised in your hospital, have a go. Love and virtual hugs to everyone on this journey.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Okay, where to start. Tuesday evening, 13 November, got cramps in left foot which just would not resolve. With that also had an ache in left leg, off-centre of the shin halfway down towards outside edge. Uh oh. Potential DVT? Rang 111. Had to wait for a doctor to come back. Cramps eased off by time he rang but said to get to A+E. Sister took me and 3 hours later I discharged myself. Yes, I know. Wrong you think. But I had had enough of the waiting around. I was very hungry having not had anything to eat. At the time of the cramps I was trying to get my tea! He said in leaving to get some food I would be discharging myself! Nurse who had taken bloods before I saw the doctor hadn’t taken enough so Phlebotomy would not process. Doctor had to take more and did. This would have been another hour of waiting for them to come back after being there already for 3 hours! Then the doctor had the nerve to say that because I would be discharging myself the new bloods taken would be binned! And they probably have been. I tell you, that’s when I really exploded. First cannula was beginning to hurt which was in the back of the hand, the stress, anxiety, etc, just got to me. They took 10 minutes to send a nurse in to take out the cannula. I had calmed down by then and she was nice. She wasn’t any of the people at fault. I had to give my details 5 times – reception, triage nurse, A+E reception, nurse who took me in to A+E and finally the doctor who saw me. Unbelievable. The cannula was taken out - a lovely bruise now forming. Off home. REMINDER TO LADIES ON CHEMO – SHOULD you EVER need to go to A+E, make sure you tell Reception YOUR ARE ON CHEMO. You are fast tracked and SHOULD be put into a cubicle with a door. This is to keep you away from ANY germs/bugs that people may bring into A+E. My local hospital also has an Urgent Care Centre all within the same area. I didn’t advise that, and is probably why I was there for so long. It still took around 40 minutes for the doctor to see me though! Now to the Radiology/Oncology appointment on 14 November. Upshot is that I will be having radiotherapy on the boob. This will be whole breast treatment. I will have a CT scan with planning session on 23 November. That same day I am due to have my last EC chemo but this is an unknown factor at the moment whilst the radiology/oncology consultant talks with my oncologist to see if this will be necessary. If I do have the EC I will need the following 3 weeks to get over it before any radiotherapy can be given. Doc says she will need this time to do the computations. Expected start time for radiotherapy 14 December. Radiotherapy will consist of going only once a week! Doctor said it will be 5 sessions in one! Has anyone heard of this scheduling? As I told you I had started to get lesions going red/pink on or near the surface of my boob. I had wanted something done about them! Radiotherapy was the only thing they could offer. Refused at the time. But they have gotten worse and new nodules are appearing in the outer quadrant and below. My research has not turned up anything else. Mainly, refusal to be given answers from well-known hospitals. Disgraceful! Get a referral from GP, no reply to emails, etc, etc, are their stock replies. So, once again, I am having to take a route I did not want. I just hope I get through it alive and in reasonable health!  See those attending on Saturday with big hugs. Love to you all
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Thanks for the responses kacang and Optimistic.  Have received Allevyn Gentle Border plasters which are the same.  Have been given 2 sizes.  One covers the main area, the other will cover all.  However I find that the smaller one is better provided I put Savlon instead over the nodule just above the crease line.  This one hasn't broken out yet with bleeding or exuding lymph but had been rubbed/pressed upon the boob with the plaster being put on by the nurse in a diamond shape adhering to the body below it.  As with anything that gets irritated it gets inflamed and painful.  It sorted itself out when I applied the Savlon and no dressing.  I just hope it stays that way.  Plasters in themselves don't cause me any irritation. Glad that other people have had the bolus.  I thought I was unusual!  Just never seen it mentioned by anyone on here nor is it in the literature I was given on radiotherapy treatment! Ah well, we continue to learn more as we go along!!!! Love and hugs to everyone
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Well, I asked the question, didn’t I! Prognosis. They said I had 18 months left to live! Responded with, ‘Well, I have bucked the trend so far and intend to continue to do so’. I think they thought I was going to break down in tears. Didn’t. Unsure if this prognosis will be as a result of everything they will be doing in the meantime. Positive thinking will get me through all of this. As a result of the lesions forming under the skin and on it, quite a few now, I am being fast tracked for radiotherapy. I have had my CT and planning session and first radiotherapy will be on 4 December – not sure yet of further dates planned. 5 x weekly sessions giving 6Gy per session. This will ‘irradiate’ me with a total of 30Gy. Normally it would be a daily dose for 5 days of 2Gy per day over the week (Mon-Fri) for 5 weeks giving a total of 50Gy although when I questioned Radiologist she quoted 40.2Gy as a standard. As I was having pain and the lesions finally being recognised as ‘growing’ they realised what I had been saying for weeks during the chemo. This is why you really need to have a consistent oncologist on your case, not just another member of the team, to see how the breast is doing physically by one person, not just through the scans. I have ordered the latest so should get them soon so I can have a gander. Was told that radiotherapy would give a ‘good result’. At last consult with oncologist, got them to quantify the ‘good result’, percentage-wise. They said 85% but can ‘range’ up to this %. So long as it reduces the surface lesions I will be happy. These were what were ‘bothering’ me the most. Last cycle (4th) of EC chemo was cancelled. That would have been on 23 November. If I had had it they would have had to wait another 3 weeks for me to recover from this before radiotherapy thereby delaying it further! They seem to think that chemo is resolving ‘scarring’! Or that the total area of cancer is ‘softening’. That’s why they kept me on the chemo so long. BUT clearly it was not addressing the surface lesions. Just don’t know which of the cancers I have that is doing the growing! Liver lesion has not changed on the dedicated Breast MRI done on 19 November compared with the Liver MRI on 24 October, I think. Having said that they may have compared it to the Ultrasound on the liver on 9 November where measurements were taken. They said that they hope that chemo will deal with this which means, I suppose, that I will be going back onto another chemo (or the Paclitaxel which would have followed the EC) after the radiotherapy which may also deal with the rest of the tumour in the breast. Oncologist will think on this. Surgery - this would be difficult due to tissue viability from incisions at the point where the lumps/nodules are forming just under the skin on the crease below the boob. Suppose we will have to wait and see what the radiotherapy does and any further chemo I may have to undertake.  Have been a bit chesty lately which has seen me a bit down these last few days and mollycoddling myself until I read my Stars: “Trust your hunches and aim high, as anything is possible at the present time. If loved ones act as devil’s advocate, listen but don’t be put off. Believe in yourself and you’ll go far”. So today is Day 1 to pick myself up, dust myself down and start believing in myself again. I can do a lot more to enhance my lifestyle. Diet has not been good and can be easily rectified. Must do more exercise. Could go and get ozone therapy and/or even Vit C IV injections – this latest one not had yet – may do some good. I WILL bounce back and defy the odds. Watch me. Love and virtual hugs to everyone on this journey
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All Update – You could say I am okay but then I am suffering from radiation burns/peeling. As you are aware I had lesions at the surface of my breast and contracted a strep infection – had to have another week of the penicillin. I was told not to put any creams on the breast. Wish I hadn’t listened. But then what do I know. Well, with regard to radiation burns, absolutely nothing. Last radiation was done on 31 December 2018 and there was a pinkness there. This has now gone to bright red and peeling of the skin with associated, sometimes, pain, always discomfort, and of course the requisite incredible itching. Was using the R1 gel and R2 cream but this was not enough. I had what you might call chapped skin which ‘broke’ when I moved myself or even my arm. The ‘chapped’ areas were on the chest and just under the armpit in that general area. On Friday I started lashing on the E45 cream and, oh boy, did that start to work. Over the weekend I have ‘peeled’ off so much skin – only that which lends itself to being lifted although there have been 2 times when I wasn’t taking enough care and peeled skin off which wasn’t quite ready – OUCH! I get itching after putting on the cream but this is the loose flaked skin which has ‘blobbed together’ causing irritation, this is what I remove. Am now lashing on the E45 at least 4 times a day. Tomorrow I have a Community Palliative Care Nurse coming in the afternoon to discuss all of this. They also like to work in conjunction with District Nurses. I had complained about the pain I was receiving from the lesions on the surface of my breast. At this moment in time I don’t seem to have any of these though get a couple of ‘gripes’ occasionally. I can’t yet distinguish whether these are from the peeling skin or the tumours themselves. They are so similar. Feels like something sharp running across/in the skin and is so acute it stops me in my tracks. Been discharged from tissue viability with Radiology though I think this was far too early – passing the buck to the lady above. Still we had a good chat when making the appointment to see me so things might be better going down this route. Had 2 of the Paclitaxel treatments so far. 3rd is on Thursday. Have a 1 week rest from the Pac the next week but have Oncologist appointment instead. Have been too pre-occupied with the radiation burns to notice anything from the Pac. Certainly I have no peripheral neuropathy, have some fatigue but then the radiation burns/flaking is really getting me down. Still on the low dose morphine. Both times at Paclitaxel treatment my blood pressure has been way down on normal, potentially stopping the treatment but have still gone ahead with it. Seems it could be the Ramipril (blood pressure tablets) so now have to take BP before taking them. Without them my BP is in the normal range so not taking these pills but need to do a med review with GP. We’ll see how we do after BP taken on Thursday morning!!!!!! Still on the innohep for the blood clot on lung which might just be enough to also control BP. Med review with GP may clarify this. So I am still here. Still go onto the Macmillan site and read the discussions though don’t respond as much as I did. Too pre-occupied with myself!!!!!!! Love and virtual hugs to all on this horrendous journey – well for me it is!
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi all Well, what can I say. Had my MRI and CT scans yesterday. Done with no problem. Went home. HOWEVER. Had a call back from the hospital to go back in. They need to give me a prescription. NOW WAIT FOR IT – I have a blood clot on the lung!!!!!!!! Radiographer from the CT scan saw it. Now have to take innohep injections every day in the tum, indefinitely. Blood clots in lung can progress to pulmonary embolism which can be FATAL. Effing hell!!!! Asked if this was the chemo and is certainly mentioned in the side effects. Medics said it can be as a result of both the chemo and myself. What! Had no indication of this before chemo!!!!! Certainly reading up the signs of a blood clot in the lung don’t mean anything to me as I haven’t had any!!! Sheesh! I really do feel fine. Hair loss – still continuing and could be classed as bald. Still quite a few tough little ‘stayers’ though all over and can still make a semblance of hair at fringe, sides and back under my hats. Keep on in there you tough little stayers! Boob - sometimes aches/pains me. Taking the Paracetamol stopping this though only taking intermittently now and only if I feel a pain. No Ibuprofen though as it can mask inflammation/infection. Had some pau d’arco under the breast – this has now gone – chemo must be working. Can feel the Lesion 1 (ER3/PR6) but the whole area does seem to be softening and some of the nodules have gone! Lumps near the crease have got smaller! Keep it up girl! Taste –it’s only my green tea now which is still a problem. Food tastes fine. So there you have it. Me on this chemo train and it’s joys! Love, hugs and positive thinking to all.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi All So what can I tell you. Chemo – had the 3rd dose of 2nd cycle of Paclitaxel 21 February 2019. This week is rest week. What I don’t know is actually how many cycles of Paclitaxel they are intending to give me which is frustrating. A question for my Oncologist 6 March. Fatigue – overwhelming, haven’t had the spark to do or even entertain doing anything! Think there is a cumulative fatiguing effect of the Pac. No wonder you have to have a ‘rest’ week. No other health conditions that could account for it. Today, 26th, was the first day I felt I could actually DO something. Boob – radiation recall now resolving/resolved though I do still have areas around the boob which are darker than the actual boob! I have no open lesions but do have a lump just above the crease at the 5o’clock position where neither the radiotherapy nor the chemo is having any effect! So what is it? The other 2 that could be felt easily, in my estimation, have been partially ‘eaten’ by the strep infection! Another question to ask the Oncologist.  Boob is softer, 'hangs' better and is looking more like a boob! Weekend away – had a weekend away from Saturday 16 Feb to 18 Feb to Lake Windermere where we stayed at a hotel to celebrate my brother’s 70th birthday. 5-course dinner on Saturday evening. I didn’t feel stuffed at all. Up for a hearty breakfast Sunday but I didn’t really eat that much and then an hour later the guts began to ache! What a time I had. There was no way I could leave the room, had to be close to the loo and just slept most of the day. Was just able to manage getting home on the Monday but for the rest of the week I was trapped indoors. Just did not want to do anything. I have no idea where this came from. At the moment I am inclined to think that it has something to do with a cumulative effect of the Paclitaxel. So no big dinners for me until the chemo is finished. Sigh! Type 2 Diabetes – District Nurse came 4 Feb to ‘change my dressing’ on the lesions. These were clearing up under my administrations so she didn’t have to do anything. I had stopped the plastering of my boob with the silicon and Allevyn plasters and just ‘plastered’ my boob with the E45 cream to deal with the intense itching and peeling. Just ‘knew’ somehow that this was the right way to go. The District Nurse did take my blood glucose which was 8.5 – far too high. However this has to be measured against eating breakfast within the 2 hour window. Another District Nurse came on 23 February where the reading was 6.0 – in the normal range. I had checked up on this and made the investment into a blood glucose machine to rule out this type of diabetes as a cause for my fatigue. Type 2 diabetes causes fatigue and they say there are no outward signs to tell you you have it. Well there are. Just search the web. Peripheral neuropathy – think I have a bit at the end of my thumbs and forefingers, both hands. Nothing much to worry me but they do feel a bit ‘dead’. Lung clot – still taking the tinzaparin (innohep) for this. Now finding that any blood taking or chemo infusion is leaving massive dark bruises. Hadn’t been doing any bruising until blood test on 14 February which still hasn’t gone! Anyone know why this is happening now? Are my veins breaking down? Do we continue with the tinzaparin? Is this an effect of a resolution of the blood clot in the lung? So many questions. More questions for the Oncologist. Hair is still growing though a little too short (and still cold enough) so I still wear my hats, no mouth ulcers but I do have a metallic taste sometimes in the mouth, Yeuch!, not taking Ramipril (blood pressure tablet) as Pac KNOWN to reduce blood pressure, not taking the oral morphine now – there are still grumbles in the boob but only light twinges which pass quickly. So, at the moment, I am ‘becoming’ well again, I hope. I also hope there is nothing more down the line to come! Need answers from Oncologist! Love and virtual hugs to all on this journey.
Posts.Title: To have the op or try alternative

Posts.Content: Hi Patsy plum I am on neo-adjuvant Anastrozole and have been since 31 October 2012.  My tumour was 13 x 7 x 21mm and is now, or should I say at the last count (1 August 2013)  5 x 5 x 7mm.  My write up under my name gives the full story.  In order to get a more up to date 'sizing' I would have to undergo MRI, ultrasound and mamm which haven't been offered as yet.  If I feel the need for this I am sure my consultant would facilitate this. So, of course it works or you wouldn't be getting it (although in rare cases it sometimes does not work).  It's an alternative way to reducing the tumour before surgery if you elect to have surgery - if you have ER+ and/or PR+ hormone positive cancer - which is a whole load gentler than having chemo.  You may have to put up with a lot of side effects from the Anastrozole but luckily for me I only had the hot flushes and those are lessening. In my research Anastrozole's cancer busting properties is set at about 90% whereas Letrozole is set at 99% and therefore has more side effects felt by the recipient.  Heather77 experienced a lot of these but on Letrozole. What you do need to know is that different brands of Anastrozole give either more or less side effects. I thought that the Accord brand caused more problems for me and stuck to Teva but this brand is sometimes very difficult for my pharmacist to get hold of.  However I can now take Accord without the additional side effect which was joint pain in my wrist and thumb. I wish you well in all your future treatments. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Anastozole, neoadjuvant treatment

Posts.Content: Hi Crystal kitty Have been drinking green tea from Clipper in unbleached bags for over a year now and have also been taking garlic capsules.  Another good one is turmeric capsules that contains curcumin another cancer 'kicker'.  Totally agree with the need for stress reduction so if anything in your life is giving you stress kick it into touch permanently.  Look forward to hearing of the delicious cookies - am stuck on plain chocolate for sweet fix. .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: A few tips from my Cancer Survivorship Course

Posts.Content: Hi tmcmahon Big hug being sent your way.  Cant help you on the surgery and radiotherapy as I haven't had any - and intend it to remain so! - unless something drastic happens.  On the endocrine therapy though (Anastrozole) and doing whatever I can through diet, exercise, supplements and limit of environmental toxins to help me on my way.  If you click on my name at the top of this message you can see a brief summary of what, why, where, how!!!!! etc. Having to wait again can be frustrating but think of it as a time to recharge your energies so you can charge to the fore when the second surgery comes around.  Having radiotherapy has probably zapped your energy levels so take the time to get completely well. All the best .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Help! surgery after radiotherapy on other boob - when, How long?

Posts.Content: Hi All Yeowwww, just looked it up online.  So many side effects and dangerous as well.  Still if it does work on getting the immune system up and working well - and if you survive the side effects....... .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: New Keytruda cancer seeking Immune boosting drug

Posts.Content: Hi Devon Dweller You or your wife need to get back to your consultant 'toot suit'.  At the very least your wife should have started the endocrine treatment.  If the cancer is rapid growing I would have thought they would have been in touch to get something done.  Keep on at them. ..... still fighting this nasty little critter.....
Posts.Title: Getting really scary now.

Posts.Content: Hi Chrisb.84 I had mastitis (and mastalgia-pain) in my left breast (cancer in my right).  Went to have it aspirated - no local - but 'dimmy' doctor couldn't get to it.  Had had the antibiotics but was not recalled again to the hospital even though it continued to hurt - sort of like when the seat belt pressed on it.  Eventually a mastalgic cyst made its way to the surface in the areolar area showing a small 'blister' and broke open with me ending up mopping it up, putting pressure on it to ensure all gunk was out which was a mixture of lymph and infection material.  After that I was hunky dory. If you really are worried then go back again to the docs.  That's what they are there for. .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Worried partner :( Mastitis or worse?

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy4u Just to let you know that I get copies of the letters that are sent to my GP.  However if you want copies of consultants notes, reports on the scans, and copies of the digital scans on disc you will very likely have to pay for them as I have.  But you are within your rights to have copies of them. .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Copy of notes

Posts.Content: Hi mamasatch Think I know where you are coming from. I had a bit of a shock at the last consultation when they found the cancer had reached the sentinel lymph node after a biopsy had been undertaken at an US scan.  BUT in my own inimitable way I am 'dealing' with it - putting a hot water bottle on it - little critters can't take heat, as well as with other things.  Still have anxious thoughts about it though but most thoughts centre on having the biopsy rather than having found out it was in the lymph node!  They are, after all, there to catch these 'nasty little critters'.  The immune system just seemed not to have recognised them as such.  I had such a bruise after that biopsy and that concerned me more. One of the things I do is that until I actually know there is a problem I wait and see.  This keeps me balanced.  There really is no benefit to your present mental or physical health and as you are well aware we are more than stressed out about having or had BC in the first place. You know we are all here on this site to help you. Just keep writing and this may help to release the stress. Sending you cyber hugs ... still fighting this nasty little critter ....
Posts.Title: Ultrasound. ...it might be back !!!

Posts.Content: Hi Raegan I think this really does need looking at.  Ring your team and ask to be seen.  This is causing you anxiety and you want to be sure, through tests, or aspiration, that all is as they say.  Only then can you move forward.  NO, is this instance, is not in my vocabulary or yours.
Posts.Title: Everything

Posts.Content: Hi Lizzy4u This is a hard one (for me).  But looking at what is involved in a DIEP I think it might be safer for you to have someone to take you and then collect.  And I would suggest that another talk with the team is in order on this.  Just as it is the Add Aspirin trial that you also need to consult.  I wouldn't have thought that the voluntary daily 75mg Aspirin I take would have any effect but I would have asked them in the first place before an angiogram.  As you are on a trial I imagine it is a double blind so I don't know if you are actually taking it!  Best to ask. Take car of yourself.
Posts.Title: Angiogram

Posts.Content: Hi Lesleyhelen Well done for getting that off your chest.  Time now to move forward.  I do feel that the medical establishment just don't have the time to deal with our cancer as well as sympathetically holding our hands.  I know some do their best but ultimately it is ourselves who have to get us through.  Family and friends can be well meaning but unless they have walked in our shoes they cannot truly understand.  If I need to talk to someone then I turn to a Breast Cancer group or the one lady I know who has gone through this journey.  Don't forget that we are conditioned to 'take a pill' and we will 'all better'.   Not so with cancer.  The fear of another journey is always with us. Look to and after yourself from now on.  Those who respond positively to you keep close but definitely ditch the rest. Love and hugs to you.
Posts.Title: Is it just me? - I'm just ranting really ;)

Posts.Content: Hi Marine20 I have just had a consult where things were 'arse about face' - consult then US then consult - 3 appointments on different days with long journey times and waits as well for all.  For my next consult we have organised an US and mamm BEFORE the consult and managed to get both US and mamm scheduled for the same day.  Remember, the muilti disciplinary team like to discuss your case before your consult appointment.  Suggest you talk with BC nurse to check things out.  They may want to do a mamm or not.

Posts.Content: Hi Beachutter Probably a stupid response but is there any way you can get a clip, ie those long things that fasten plastic bags or one of those hair clips, so that you clip it at the top leaving the seat belt loose where it comes out across your chest but enough to keep you secure!!!!!!  That way you will have the room to move without it chafing. .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Still in discomfort

Posts.Content: Hi All Noticed this discussion.  I was given some Simple for Christmas but having checked the ingredients on them they contain parabens so had to give them away.  I am now soooooo conscious of what goes on my skin.  I have found Nivea Soft (moisturiser) with Jojoba Oil and Vitamin E free of parabens and toxins for my face.  When I get in the shower I use paraben free hair shower products - some from Tesco and some from a health shop.  I was also given for Christmas 'faith in nature' pomegranate and rooibos shampoo and conditioner which are also free from artificial colours and fragrances, no parabens or SLES. (cant remember what that is - sodium lauryl ether sulphate, it's a chemical.  And the only other thing is the water which has chlorine - which is NOT good and is the only thing I clean my body with.  Use a Dove soap for my hands when needed but also have a bar of Oliva which I believe is also paraben free. UK water is chlorinated - cheaper.  The French who have less cancers have ozonated water but it could also be down to them eating a lot of garlic! - a cancer fighting natural 'herb'. As for deodorant this is interspersed between Dove invisible dry or a Crystal body deodorant stick which has to be dipped in a little water then put underarm - its hypoallergenic and fragrance free.  Got that one as a present so no idea where to buy it.  For my teeth I use, from phyto shield, propolis, botanical oral care toothpaste from a health shop.  In this way I keep personal care environmental toxins out of my body. Having said that, as you are aware, I have not gone down the route of conventional treatment - just the Anastrozole - so I don't have any recovering wounds and the deodorant could pull on the skin. ... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: well thats not gone to plan !!!!!!

Posts.Content: Hi Birda No, you didn't mishear.  Yes there are 'One Stop Shops' where all tests are done so you know in one day if you have breast cancer.  On the other hand you will also know in one day whether it is benign.  Such a difference from my days back in 2012. Screening Mammogramme found the lump - 8 August 2012 Recalled for another mamm where they did biopsy - 20 August 2012 Told me that they found cancer and wanted to do surgery - 28 August 2012 Referred to a hospital closer to home, consult - 7 Sept 2012 Appointments for further scans - MRI which I crapped out of the first one due to having eaten before and was laying on my tum with boobies dangling - 17 Sept and 21 Sept 2012 CT Scan - 20 Sept 2012 Consult for treatment plan - 26 Sept 2012, with long talk with nurse afterwards on what to expect Stopped surgery and sentinel node scan planned for 11 Oct 2012  - 3 October 2012 Appointment with oncology to do hormone therapy - 31 October 2012 Certainly my case is completely different from the norm and yours might be also.  However in one day you will know what your lump is.  The waiting between appointments has been the 'bad' part for most of us with its uncertainty.  You at least will get an answer on the day - that's good in a roundabout way!.  I should imagine what happens after that is that you will be scheduled for a meeting with the consultant on the treatment plan they have come up with for your type of breast cancer and that only if you have a tumour!  It could just as easily be a cyst. Anyway, how this works is new to us 'oldies'.  So come back on here and let us know how it works unless one of the other writers on this website knows otherwise. Best of luck and sending you virtual hugs

Posts.Title: Timescale confusion from gl

Posts.Content: Hi Godblessdiva I have had to pay for all my records, ie all Mamms, US, CT, MRI, Bone plus any reports.  DVD on scans cost £10 each but I imagine that all your scans could be put onto 1 DVD.  (I have a number of DVDs now as I have requested and paid for them as I have gone along.)  Additionally copies of all reports are the cost of photocopying them.  This could be £10.  So not much really.  Another hospital I have requested copies of my records for other health issues and this has been a flat fee of £45 but this will go back a few years.  This hospital also quoted that they will do it within 40 days!!!!!  In my BC hospital they only take a matter of days.  But you do have to fill in a request form and pay for them.  They shouldn't refuse you.  See if you can't get them through your insurance.

Posts.Title: NICE draft guidelines on treatment of primary breast cancer

Posts.Content: Hi Comper22 Yeowww, getting the call must have frightened you out of your wits!  From what I can gather you have a cancer tumour in your boob of 6.5cm size with 1 lymph node affected with some other 'spots' in your boob around 1mm in size.  You also have, potentially, cysts on your liver for which you need an MRI to determine positively what they are.  You will be undergoing FEC T chemotherapy first (I assume to reduce the tumour) followed by surgery then radiotherapy assuming liver will turn out to be okay.  All correct so far? Wow, what a lot of information to soak in!  6.5cm tumour is quite large and having chemo first should reduce its size.  Remember to watch out for side effects!  I am sure there are more people on this site who can offer you further help/commisseration.  Please remember we are all here for you and just talking with other likeminded people who have been and are going through it does help.  You are not alone as you know. ... still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Results of scans

Posts.Content: Hi Mirabo Because it is so costly (not in our terms) even GPs will not give you the originals.  I don't know how many packs you have tried or how many packs of the same brand you were given (say 3 monthly supply) but you could order only 1 pack of each generic brand to try them out.  Keep your diary of side effects which can only give evidence of your intolerance to the cheaper/generic brands.  Seems no-one in the powers that be want to understand the massive impact these have on individuals.  For Anastrozole I have done a chart of the different stuff that is in each brand.  Some say the same but do not have a number next to the ingredient.  It is possible that there is a cheaper version of that ingredient which is causing the problem.  Certainly I have heard that a hypromellose ingredient caused some ladies a lot of discomfort. If it gets too bad then just go back to GP with your diary. Best of luck
Posts.Title: Letrozole issues AGAIN! Need advice

Posts.Content: Hi Heather Sorry to hear you are going through the mill.  My thoughts are with you now and tomorrow at your appointment.  Hope it goes the right way. Love winging its way to you .... still fighting this nasty little critter...
Posts.Title: Quadrantectomy and LD flap

Posts.Content: Hi All I use Dr. Organic Hemp Oil.  Its  24hr rescue cream.  It's sold at Holland and Barrett.  Goes on like its thick but is soon works its way into the skin.  All organic ingredients of which there are quite a few - hemp seed oil, aloe vera leaf juice, borage seed oil, sweet almond oil.... and the list goes on.
Posts.Title: Looking for a good light (thin) Moisturiser ?

Posts.Content: I'm with Crystaljuju on this one.  Getting the teeth sorted out first is the priority.  With so much bad teeth in the mouth you will get rid of a source of bad bacteria which could affect the benefit! of chemo.  Her next good idea was to consult with your oncologist.  A very good idea particularly if they can see how bad your mouth is and weigh the pros and cons of whether to do chemo first or the teeth!  As your immune system hasn't been depressed yet with the chemo you have a good chance of healing better now after teeth extraction rather than after having the chemo first. ....still fighting this nasty little critter....
Posts.Title: Dental verses chemo before lumpectomy

Posts.Content: Hi Mirabo Found an old discussion which has a link to a study about the effects of generic Tamoxifen.  However this can be quoted for Letrozole. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/?term=tamoxifen+brands The Conclusion clearly states that side effects can be significantly altered by change of brand - better or worse! AND it was written 18 months ago!  Medics just not up to speed on this. When I was on Letrozole I started to log on a spreadsheet all the ingredients of the tablets.  You can get sooooo many variations of just one ingredient, ie. Macrogol - coating, Macrogol 300, 400, 4000, and in Femara says Macrogol 8000!  And they all have TALC - something which has been on the news of late. Just some information to arm yourself with. Love

Posts.Content: Hi All Love the 'ornithologist' and 'nymphnodes'.  Must remember them! .... still fighting this nasty little critter....

Posts.Content: Hi Lizane Read your discussion and so sorry for you at being given a lot of mis-information.  There is a website dedicated to AV so I hope you have googled it.  There is also a clinical trial however it is for the femoral head so I don't know if this applies to you.  Something for you to read up on and take with you to your appointment.  All my love, hugs and very best wishes for you tomorrow.  Do come back with an update. ....still fighting this nasty little critter
Posts.Title: Told I was misdiagnosed and it's NOT bone secondaries, it's Avascular...

Posts.Content: Hi Kazash56 Was on Anastrozole but was changed to Letrozole when Anastrozole stopped working.  However Letrozole didn't work for me at all so may be going on Arimidex.  Will know today.  Alternatively could be put onto exemestane.  Only ever had the hot flushes with these hormone inhibitors. However I note that you have been on Anastrozole for 19 months and I suspect that you have had various brands in that time.  Did you notice if any particular brand gave you less side effects?  Alternatively you could ask if you could be put onto Arimidex to see if you get less side effects or none at all!  Anastrozole is the generic form (patent now expired meaning other pharma can now make it) of Arimidex and it's the fillers that cause the side effects. It is always worth an ask.
Posts.Title: Changing from anastrozol
